Since we were on the top floor, we only heard the drums and anyone with a stereo system, but compared to our screaming neighbors and motorcycles back at home, this was nothing.Some of the goods, even if just the minor details: shampoo/conditioner/soap/lotion was provided in a lovely citrus tone (mandarin & mint) which were refilled almost daily (maybe b/c we had 4 ppl in a room?!); two free water bottles and coffee daily; and the service lady was very friendly. Because the towels were so thin, she gave us extra towels for the ladies to dry their hair with (we don't like using the hair dryer, but it's provided in the room as well), every day of our stay without another reminder! Some days she would leave more than 2 bottles of water~Parking was included (after paying that resort fee, of course) and there always seemed to be plenty of space. Though b/c it was December, there were a lot weddings happening, so if you were out late, you might not find one. But we asked the parking attendant and she always let us park in the reserved spaces~Wireless connections is only reachable in their computer "room" down in the lobby, but they also have computers/printers/fax of their own (4 desktops). However, you are only given 20 free minutes PER DAY, and then you need to start paying up~We only ate at the Pikake Terrace once for their expensive dinner buffet (well, compared to hotel buffets, decent price) and stocked up on crab legs. Delicious! But keep on eye on them; some batches are left longer under the heat lamp and the ones on top became dry and chewy. We sometimes waited for a new batch! We did have one batch that was super-salty, not sure if it were the crabs or the person cooking them. Their roast was tender but really salty! Salad and fruits was clean and fresh, and there was plenty of other entrees, sides and desserts! Our waitress was bubbly-nice, but some of the others around us would look glum and/or stand in the middle of customer traffic (who are trying to get food and go back to their table) talking to one another. Not sure which section they were supposed to serve, but slightly rude! Because the dining area is mostly outdoors, stay clear from the corners of the giant umbrellas when it's raining; you will get wet. Just sit closer to your table =P I don't clearly remember the furniture as it was dark (there were only candles and tiki torches), but just your typical pool stuff. And if you get small portions per trip, you're always getting up so I don't see why I needed a plush seat or something!All in all, a wonderful stay. If the price is right, we wouldn't mind staying here again. I think I was more happy because my mom got to enjoy herself; she rarely gets to treat herself to a resort hotel after years of motels/day inns. Which is perfectly fine when you have plans; you can spend more on food or things to do...don't really need the fancier resort hotels. So, unless we win some grand prize from somewhere, we won't be going to one of those hotels any time soon. Princess Kaiulani was a nice enough treat to ourselves!

not much to talk about the hotel .. front desk sucks, absolutely inefficient and slow checkin process, nobody to assist as you get in.,old & unkempt , needs to be spruced up. However, lot of space around.And location is great, right in the market, 1 minute to the beach, bars, market!

We stayed at the Princess Kauiulani for 4 nights on our way from Australia to go skiing in the US mainland. It has a great location. The rooms are OK, but really really tired. We stayed on the 15th floor overlooking the ocean. We ended up with bed bug bites all over us! Disgusting. We didn't use any of the facilities of the hotel, as we were out and about all day and literally used this as a base to shower and sleep. The breakfast buffet we walked past was $26 to sit around an old pool area with tired pool furniture. We walked across the road to the iconic Dukes most days and enjoyed their buffet overlooking the beach for $15! All in all, not sensational. Would I stay here again? No. The only reason we did was that we paid for it with Amex points. Oh and it's really really loud, but I assume everything on Kalakua ave is.

The hotel was nice and walking distance from the beach and many shopping areas. We were very pleased with our high level ocean view room. The room was clean but we spent most of our time on the beach. The hotel staff seemed a bit impersonal and many times they weren't smiling & didn't greet guests as they walked around. Room service was delicious. We had no issues with checking in or checking out and we enjoyed our stay.

In early December 2011, may wife and I returned after years of absence to the Sheraton Princess Kaiulani. Although we would not rate it as a luxury hotel, it is first rate, reasonably-priced and remains our favourite hotel in Honolulu. The hotel's palm-lined garden is attractive leading to the lobby and restaurant area. It occupies the former Ainahau Estate, where Princess Victoria Kaiulani lived until her untimely death in 1899. Her large portrait and several smaller ones and photographs of hers ornate the open lobby. In the pre-Christmas weeks, Chef Bauer and his elves labour for many days building a winter scene with sugar and ginger bread. This display was larger than in the past, and is the most impressive and magnificent make-believe winter scene we have ever seen. It also includes two miniature railways. The original hotel opened in 1955, followed in 1970 by the 29-floor Ainahau Tower. Thanks to the SPG Platinum/Gold desk, we checked in quickly, welcomed by a gracious clerk, who had reserved a nice, comfortable room with balcony on the 25th floor of the Tower, overlooking parts of Waikiki Beach, Diamond Head etc., and beautiful sunsets. If the rooms had double-glazed doors, they would be quieter. We always enjoy eating at the hotel. The Pikake Terrace offers reasonably-priced sumptuous breakfast and dinner buffets. The waiters and waitresses are friendly and very competent. As of 18:00 h, it has nightly entertainment, usually featuring local bands and Hula dancers. The adjacent "Splash Bar and Bento" offers a-la-carte dining and entertainment. Its Happy Hours from 15:30 to 17:30 h offers tasty snacks and sub-tropical drinks. It also serves my favourite Fire Rock Ale from Kona. Regrettably, the Japanese Momoyama Restaurant was closed (for good?), and so is our favourite Hano Hano Restaurant, previously on the top floor of the Sheraton Waikiki.Perhaps because of the predominant Japanese clientele, oatmeal is not on the Pikake buffet; however, tiny Kim, bent by age and 35 years with the hotel, brought me oatmeal upon request plus brown sugar, without my asking.Ravenous pigeons are a negative. The hotel has tried a feeding area, but their seemingly limitless appetite attracts them back to the tables. The Mauna Kea Beach Hotel and Hapuna Beach Prince Hotel on Hawai'i and the Westin Casuarina on Grand Cayman are wrestling with the same problem. Perhaps, someone should record a pigeon's death cry and a hawk's cry and have them played intermittently.As always, I liked the hotel's large and very deep oval swimming pool. Its water was quite cool, but pleasant and refreshing. Its low temperature is ideal for extended swimming, because it relegates most guests to the lounge chairs. A big improvement over beach mats are the hotel's portable collapsible "sand chairs". Although they are low, they are comfortable and keep guests off the sand. We carried our chairs across and down Kalakaua Avenue for a few steps to Waikiki Beach. The hotels sends twice daily a young man and woman, drawing a cart with cold bottled water and fruits for hotel guests (identied by the "sand chairs").The always busy hotel attracts Japanese tour guests in droves. They were scurrying out and in, laden with shopping bags from Macy's and other fine stores along Kalakaua Avenue. Our most memorable visit was in early Decmber 2001, when the hotel rather resembled a morgue, because shell-shocked and air-plane-phobic by the collapse ot the World Trade Center, tourists avoided Hawai'i. At the time, the hotel had placed us on the 29th floor of the Tower in a large and sumptuous suite, worthy of the Emperor of China, had he lived.Although the hotel has no beachfront, it always attracts us like a magnet. We were sad, when we moved from the hotel to The Royal Hawaiian, but if our lives are spared, we shall return, because the hotel has created a feeling of "belonging".
Very nice clean hotel in a great spot,close to the beach,shops, nice friendly and helpfully staff great stay

I spent 4 nights at this 3 star hotel. It is right across from the beach & in the middle of all the action. It's located around the corner from the main strip, which reminds me of NYC. Tons of designer stores & restaurants. The hotel's lobby was under renovation, but that did not slow it down. I was supposed to stay in a room with balcony, but because it was overbooked they offered me free breakfast buffet tickets for 2, for my entire stay.... I was very pleased, since the buffet is a lil pricey. I was also able to use the breakfast tickets for dinner. The food was delicious. My room was ok, a lil dated, but my view of the mountains was beautiful. It was not hot enough to use the pool, which was ok. The pool is kinda small and closes at 6pm. The only thing I did not like was the pigeons!!!! Because it is outdoor seating, the birds will attack if you leave your plate..Other than that, it is a nice hotel, but I would want to stay in a 4-5 star on my next trip...

Perhaps I'm picky? I'd say this hotel hasn't been renovated or even updated since it was built in the 50's. It's drab, dirty and overpriced. Our bathroom had mould in some of the cracks. A complaint resulted in a visit from maintenance but no action as promised. The staff are generally indifferent but occasionally rude. One of the poorest hotels I've ever stayed in.

Second time staying at the Princess Kaiulani, again we loved it! All of the employees that we had contact with, were great. The pool and the surrounding area were great. It truly felt like we were coming home.

The location is the best part of this hotel. We paid for the upgrade to have a partial open view with a balcony and we are glad we did. The noise was very loud from the street, keeping us awake at night. The chambermaids were very friendly as were the bell men. Cleaning is minimal- towels were changed daily at our request however the washroom was only wiped down once during the 10 day stay. We did not eat at the hotel due to the lack of options and price. There is a breakfast buffet however, it was not a great value. There is a mini fridge in the hotel room so we bought some breakfast items from a local store to have in our room.

We checked in on New Year's Eve and our room had a great view of the fireworks on Waikiki Beach. It was a wonderful place to be to ring in the New Year. We had dinner at the hotel but the staff were definitely overwhelmed and service wasn't their usual. The beds are amazing- feels like falling in to a cloud. The hotel lobby features an amazing Christmas gingerbread display complete with model trains and Christmas figures. The hotel location has an interesting Hawaiian history as well. Housekeeping was great as was the front desk staff. We didn't mind the the resort fee as we could call anywhere in the world for free - we talked to our daughter in Australia every day so we didn't mind the fee. The fee also gave us free internet access which we didn't have last time. We were quite happy with the room, the staff, and the location. We booked some months back and requested our corner room again but disappointed that we didn't get it. The front desk staff said that there was no way to guarantee a corner room but you could request it. Last year we walked in off the street and were given the corner room - guess it is the luck of the draw but the corner rooms on the higher floors offer amazing views and sunsets. We really enjoy everything Hawaiian and the energy and people on the Waikiki strip are one of the things we like to experience for a couple of days. The Sheraton is a great choice to experience Waikiki without needed a vehicle.

The Sheraton PK is a great value compared to similar hotels in the area. While I've seen a lot of comments regarding the quality of the hotel and yes, it is dated, but the room was clean and the housekeeping staff was very effecient. In addition, the room had a HD flatscreen with HD content, which is not always the case.If you're in Waikiki for a conference, it's tough to beat the value and location of this property.However, the one complaint I will continue to harp on with for all hotels is the "resort fee". It can sneak up on you and really should be included in the rate so costs can be compared. While this resort fee includes self parking and internet. I get free internet at starwood hotels, took a taxi to the hotel which left me with what amounted to a 12% tax on the room.

We have stayed in hawaii many times before and were not very pleased with this hotel. When we walked into our room we found little black hairs on our doona cover, moldy ceilings and a longs black hair in the shower. The people at front desk a bit rude. the breakfast is actually not bad. beware of the homeless that can tend to wonder around the front, begging can be a bit distressing. would recommend to stay at the outrigger waikiki. pk was fine but would rather some place else.

We just returned from 6 nights at the "PK" with our 20 year old son and his girlfriend. Our trip was booked throught Off2Hawaii. The hotel is NOT newly renovated but it was FINE. The rates were very reasonable and included free parking. The beds and linens were very comfortable. The hotel is across Kalakaua Blvd. from the beach and right next door to The International Marketplace. Reasonable breakfast at Keo's was 1/2 block away, Subway was across the street from the hotel entrance. LOTS of fantastic restaurants within easy walking distance. The elevators are quick - our ocean view room was on the 23rd floor. The woman working at the "Tour Desk" was very crabby. Didn't even look up to say hello. We booked our tours outside the hotel or did our own tours. We enjoyed "Creation", the Polynesian show - had to do it!!!

We are residents of Hawaii and we only stay at the Kaiulani!! Regardless if we live in Paradise its great to get away once in a while. The service and employees are excellent. We recently stayed for a night and used are accumulated Starwood points for a free stay. We got upgraded to a suite!! Talk about great timing. Keoni was helping us and again great customer service. We also got to know Angie. She is a server at the pool area. GREAT PEOPLE!!

Last visit Sept. 2008. Great room, top level small wing, overlooking pool, ocean views. Meals were fine. Loved everything about it and returning in March this year, so after reading some of these reports, hope we won't be disappointed.

When we arrived we were given a partial ocean view in the Ainahua tower. The room was right over the International Market Place. It was a bit noisy during the night as people were partying. The room was clean and the bed was really comfortable. We had a king size bed. The next day we asked to be changed to an ocean view and were given a spectacular room. Room 2260 overlooking the pool and with a fantastic ocean view. We only had breakfast included with our package and the omelets were awesome, We found a different place to eat every night. We visited the Polynesian Centre which was quite an experience. If you do go there, the luau was soso. I wish I had taken the Prime rib. There is a $12.00 day resort fee, but this gets u a room safe, 1 hr international calling and internet in your room.

We stayed at the Princess for the second time in the last two years. The hotel is beautiful, however they did not treat the theft in my Kid's room seriously at all. I reported to them the theft of my son's souveniers from his room and they never treated it seriously at all. The security checked out the room and they said they would get back to me prior to us leaving in a couple of days and they never did. My son was devastated everything he had boughten in two weeks was gone. The value was menial to everyone else at about $40-$50 but to an 11 year old kid it was devastating. They could not even take $40 out of petty cash so he could buy this stuff back. I had to this so his trip would not be ruined. Poor treatment of non Asian people.

My husband stayed at the Princess Kaiulani for a week January 5-11, 2012 to attend a convention. The rooms were blocked for our group, so the rate was reduced to $159/night, which based on the condition of the hotel seemed about right as the hotel is across the street from the beach in the heart of Waikiki. The Kaiulani is very outdated, with lots of nicks and scars in the walls and furniture in the guest rooms. The carpeting looked fairly new, however. The pool is pretty small compared to others in the area for what is considered a luxury hotel. The water of the pool is not heated, which suited me, as I am a lap swimmer. However, they put a buoy across the shallow end so swimming laps is pretty awkward. The pool is only open from 8am to 6pm, so early morning or late night swimming, which would be great, is not available, plus the pool is smack up against the lanai eating seating, so you are in full view of everyone. The dining venues are very limited, mostly to an expensive buffet for breakfast and dinner. We did not eat anything at the hotel, so do not know how good the food was. There are tons of restaurants within an easy walk of the hotel, so you can quite easily find just about any kind of fare for varying prices. There are classes available each day for things like hula lessons, etc., and there usually is some form of entertainment--bands, hula dancers--every night. OUr room on the 23d floor of the tower was average size but the bathroom was fairly small and in severe need of remodeling. The countertop stone was pitted and dirty looking, plus the sink had a crack in it. They provide a flat screen TV with lots of free channels. The worst problem with the hotel is the noise from all the tourists milling around below the area until very late at night and into the early morning hours. Bands play in the area below the hotel until quite late too, so you hear the drums playing loudly unless you close your sliding glass door. The noise even penetrates the room with the door closed, unfortunately. The bed linens were crisp and clean and the beds and pillows were very comfortable. Lighting was very good throughout the room and bathroom. There is plenty of hanging space and there are drawers for storing your folded clothes, although the drawer space is a bit limited. There is a safe and a refrigerator in the room, so you can buy juice, cereal, snacks, etc., to make eating a quick bite a bit easier.

Obviously an older property but reasonably well maintained (had to fix minor problem with sink plug). Very close to Waikiki beach and in the heart of the shops & restaurants. Even a decent supermarket within a few minutes walk. You can even walk to Ala Moana Shopping Centre in about 35 minutes (although we are fast walkers).We had an ocean view room on level 8 and we were very happy with the view! The king size bed was very comfortable. It was a struggle getting out of it in the morning!This hotel also puts on interesting activities like hula dancing and ukalela lessons at no extra cost. Don't miss the pineapple carving! Maybe they will add line dancing in the future (hint, hint).Check in was a bit slow for tired travellers, but check out was quick and efficient. The staff are very friendly and helpful, particularly front desk and bell men.No problem with the resort fee although not sure if we got full value as we didn't have a car, but the included long distance (and international) phone calls is a bonus and the high speed internet was great.There is an ice machine on each floor which is great for drinks in your room. Amazed by the fridge also...looked like a typical motel bar fridge, very small. However it worked like a demon and could freeze bottles of water in a couple of hours.Would we stay here again? Definitely we would if we came back to Waikiki.

I booked one night at junior suite - I thought it was normal double room, what is going on?Room is bad shape, need lots work to look nice. Painting on the wall peeling, floor with lots of stains, swimming pool that smells like pee. Only good things about this hotel is they have good japanese breakfast corner where you can get natto!If you book in advance, you can get good deal, but do not expect anything but a shed.

Pros: Location was excellent, just across the street from Waikiki Beach and right on the main shopping drag. Price was not unreasonable ($235/night) when you consider we stayed from Dec 26-30. The resort fee of $12.57 was very palatable as it included parking (too bad we didn't have a car), 100 minutes of long distance a day (too bad there wasn't anyone we wanted to talk to) and 2 bottles of water daily. Excellent view of the ocean, hotels, mountain from our lanai.Cons: The wind noise that roared and moaned through our room was unbelievable, especially as the days weren't particularly windy ones. Luckily the wind died down at night. One of the phones in our room crackled so badly it was good there wasn't anyone we needed to call. The decor was definitely island nostalgia - turquoise or pink painted built-ins and rattan tropics. Bathroom was not someplace you wanted to spend time in but clean enough. The beds are tiny doubles - really too small for our family of four. There didn't appear to be Express Check-out of any sort so plan accordingly if you're rushed at check-out time - you're in the same line as the people checking in.

Definitely dated but seemed to be clean and reasonably priced for the location/amenities.Amenities – nice workout area and a number of regular activities.Location – across the street from beach and major store fronts.Stayed here recently as part of a package. As a result, we were originally not informed of the hotel resort fee option which covers internet/parking etc. for less than daily parking (depending on # of nights you stay but it’s a good deal if you have a car since parking is typically 20+/day).Elevator/layout was kind of frustrating from Ainahau Tower. There seemed to be way too many guests for the number of elevators/weird layout and stairs were not a viable option. At times the wait was 10+ minutes. We were on the 6th floor but the Ainahau Tower accessible stairs only seemed to the fourth floor (unless you take the fire stairs which were locked to get back in.

We spent 2 nights at SPK and it was the worst hotel i have been to (even subpar comparing to roadside Motel 6). It was like stepping back in to the 70 with the room deco! Except the room (and probably the whole wing of the hotel) also experienced 30 something years of useage and abuse. Everything was outdated and dirty. The room we had is facing the parking lot and pretty much on top of the dumpster so it was stinky and noisy. The only reasons i gave it ONE star were because i used my SPG points for it (plus maybe for the location). It was partly our fault for not planning ahead and book a nicer hotel ( we spent the whole Xmas week in Kauai and decided to spend New Year in Waikiki at the last minute)Do yourself a favorite and plan ahead so you dont end up at this hotel. Starwood should be ashamed of operating this hotel ( maybe they will decide to do some renovations if enough people complain)

we stayed here based on location and an airpoints deal that I got and were very pleasantly surprised with the standard and value. The location was excellent (next best thing to direct waterfront) and the view from our high ocean view room was great, although still noisy on the 27th floor which just seems to be a waikiki thing... Room itself was fine, view was outstanding. Pool was good and not busy at all. staff were fine, and it was nice to be identified on the beach by our sheraton towels and offered complementary fruit and water. We didn't eat at the hotel but it looked typical for the hotels in the area - maybe a couple of bucks cheaper than the moana surfrider across the road (which is a great place for a beer by the way)Any negatives are probably typical of waikiki, we enjoyed the buzz of people and activities, but the noise is obviously typical of a busy built up area.

I have reservations for 1/24/12-2/2/12 and am very excited about the opportunity to stay at this hotel for a seventh time. I will be so sad when the major renovations, destruction of this property occurs. It keeps getting pushed back and hope it continues to get pushed back another 10 years. It has the feel of a real Hawaiian hotel, not a 5 star in Manhattan. Yes it's busy and old but the positives so out weighs the negatives. Can't wait until our visit.

I am sitting next to the pool right now and it couldn't be more perfect.For me safety and security are the most important thing for my family and it's just that here at PK. The people and friendly and efficient, rooms are clean and tidy,comfortable beds great views, not noisy like many said but overall have had a great stay.

We stayed on the 17th floor facing Diamon Head and so we had a great ocean view. The view from the opposite side was nice, but nothing like our view (teenagers had room across the hall). Yes, you can hear the live entertainment from ground level but I enjoyed it....what's better than listening to live Hawaiian music? You could hear occasionally people in the next room, but we weren't in the room much for it to be a bother. Very close to the beach (2 min walk) as well as next door to International Market Place. ABC store across the street but then I think there is an ABC store across the street from every hotel in Waikiki! I agree with other comments about the front desk staff - the gentlemen who checked us in really looked like all he wanted to do was go home. Totally opposite to our reception at our hotel on Kauai. If we were travelling with kids again and if the price was right, I would stay here again. If just my husband and myself were travelling then we would stay at a different hotel.Breakfast buffet was very good. Also the Creation Polynesian show was good....loud, but good.

Before coming to stay here I read some of the other reviews and was concerned at what I may find. But I have now been here for a week, and have had a wonderful experience. I am traveling on my own, and have found both staff to be friendly and helpful at all times. My room and the view from the balcony (ocean view) exceeded expectations, my room is thoroughly cleaned every day, and the whole experience has been just great. Fantastic location - this whole experience has been fantastic from my stay in Hawaii to the tours the staff have recommended to the people I have met. Thank you Sheraton Princess Kaiulani I would stay here again! Ann

My wife and two kids stayed here for two nights on a trip back from New York to Sydney, just to break up the flight and give us a chance to relax. We had an ocean view room which was incredible, with sweeping views over the Pacific and Honolulu looking towards Diamond Head. The room itself was dated and had that 1980's feel but this was fine for us as we were only using it to stretch the legs after several long flights with two small children. Service was fairly ordinary, most employees looked overworked and the expressions on their faces suggest they may as well be just as happy working for Apple making iPhones in a Chinese slave factory! There were a couple of exceptions but overall it didn't feel very welcoming. The breakfast was quite good and I would recommend an upgrade if you can. The location was great, being right in the action. I didn't hear too much noise as we were up on level 28 of 29.Overall it served a purpose but I would not stay there if I was in Honolulu for an extended holiday !

This hotel is definitely dated but has a great location directly in the middle of Waikiki strip and across from the beach. We had booked last minute on Priceline for around $85/night which we felt was an okay price for this time of year. Initially, we were checked into an unrenovated room that was dreary, musty, and dated. The carpets were dirty and the washroom was dismal with no counter space! You should definitely be aware that this hotel charges a daily resort fee of around $12.50. The fee includes wireless internet, a welcome drink (sugary non alcholic drink), self parking, and 60 mins of free phone calls including international calls. We were aware of this fee and was fine with it as we had a rented vehicle and the parking rate itself would be considered very reasonable in comparison to other Waikiki lots. After our first night in the unrenovated room, we were fortunate enough to speak to the front desk and be moved to a renovated room (still quite dated but definitely better than the first room that we were given). Our stay improved greatly from this point. I did have problems accessing the wireless internet but I spoke with their technology assistance team via the front desk and they were able to get me up and running on my netbook and iPhone with some slight adjustments to my settings. I never used the pool as the beach was nearby and we preferred getting out of Waikiki during the day. If you are on a lower floor, the noise might be an issue so I would suggest requesting a higher room. The Starwood Sweet Sleeper bed is excellent and is provided in all the rooms including those in unrenovated rooms. We also happen to be at the hotel during a pineapple cutting demonstration with free sampling and a lei making class (I assume this is part of the "resort" fee?) This hotel is definitely in need of a major overhaul but the same can be said of many other hotels in Waikiki. As a Starwood hotel, it definitely doesn't fall in line with their standards; however, if you want a good location and a comfortable sleep, this place meets that bill.
My wife and I loved the Hawaii and Honolulu is one of the best places ti visit and this hotel has a very good location !

The hotel is a good location across from Waikiki Beach. The location is fantastic. The property looks a little aged. The green carpet is not a good choice. It makes the rooms and lobby look a little dirty. The bedding at all Starwood hotels is great. The view from my room was embarrassing - but I did not stay there for the view, and booked the most basic room.Furniture is very basic, but acceptable. The refrigerator wasn't stocked. The hallways look very "cheap".The property was very busy for New Years, it took some time to catch an elevator.The pool was acceptable for Hawaii, but would not be up to standard in other parts of the world. It was disturbing to expect guests to have a "towel" card ready when picking up a very simple towel. I wasn't given such a card at check in, and had to wait for a manager to get a towel for my 5 minute pool time.The manager gave me a towel card, but did not explain, nor did I sign and agreed to the small print. The small print alerted a guest of a charge for the towel if the slip was not returned at check out. Enforcing this would disqualify a guest from using the express check out - and the lines were long.I am a Gold member for the SPG program. Getting points or status nights is important. I tried to book the hotel on the starwood.com website, but nothing was available. I called the hotel and was told the hotel was sold out.I was able to reserve a room on Orbitz.com, but was not explained Starwood would not honor SPG benefits.I did not receive points, nor did I receive status nights. Guests should be warned to be penalized when booking a Starwood hotel with travel agents and tour operators. I can't believe the travel industry is not boycotting Starwood Hotels & Resorts.I was not mad aware of a mandatory "Resort" fee until I checked into the hotel. I understand several hotels and resorts now charge such fees. I feel such fees border on extortion and may be illegal. One of the benefits was a complimentary juice drink at the pool bar. After the tip, this drink turned out to be expensive for a watered down fruit colored drink in a small plastic glass. The resort fee did include 60 minutes of phone calls. Well - my cell phone is free. The resort fee also included internet, but WIFI in my room was not available, only Internet cable. Since I did not take my computer but my I Pad - this was not an option for me.The resort fee did include parking, what was great for me- but unnecessary for most tourists in Waikiki. Most tourists would not rent a car.I am puzzled why Starwood is upsetting their guests with such "mandatory fees". Such "fees" are nothing but a mandatory and hidden increase of an already agreed room rate. Has anyone ever challenge this in court?I stayed at the Hyatt across the road many times. I will continue to do so, unless they ever follow the lead of charging a resort fee.

I am still here at the Sheraton Princess but I have to write my opinion right away as I am very upset. It is very true as others have said: Very bad service at front desk. First, when I first check in, I found out that the room was so small and smelly for my family of 4, I asked for upgrade as Starwood member but No, I was willing to pay for the upgrade but also No, if the hotel was full I would understand but the attitude of the front desk lady was very nasty and condescending like what do you expect from a "Motel 6"". Not a Sheraton, worse than Motel 6 in service. The only positive is the location & the bell boy service. The front desk staffs should all go back to training. They don't care about about the customers. They make me stand in line 5 times just to get a different room. Wifi also is very bad, cannot connect most of the time.

I stayed here for a week with my wife and two kids. I've been to Waikiki several times and have stayed at many hotels in the area. What strikes me as the most impressive feature of this hotel is that they deliver the value that many other places do, but you don't feel like they are trying to nickel and dime you. Also, the staff were really great with the kids. One of them took 45 minutes to show them around and let them feed goldfish an hunt for lizards. My kids are still talking about it. All in all I would say this is not the sufrider, but the rooms are very clean and comfortable and the location is fantastic. The breakfast buffet is fine and reasonably priced. My only criticism is that roll-away beds seem very expensive, but I assume that is because they have to upgrade the room to fit them in. Yes there is a small resort fee, but it definitely pays off if you use the towel service at the beach and plan to park a car. I would take my family to the princess again anytime. It is exactly what we were looking for.

We stayed at the Sheraton Princess from the 25th of December to the 29th. The location is great - it is one block from the beach and very close to the International Market. The hotel itseld was ok - our room was quite dated - but I understand that the hotel is in the process of trying to renovate all the rooms. We were on the 17th floor and it was quite noisy- you can hear all the noise from the street below including the live music. It didnt bother us - but people should be aware that this is not a quiet hotel to stay at. The hallway and rest of the wing was also very dated and the rooms are not very sound proof - we could here the person in the next room on the phone. The cleaning service was not very good - they woke us up twice at 8am trying to get into the room to clean - despite the "do not disturb" on the door. Also, when they did clean, it was sub par. They literally just made the bed and that was it - twice we had to call and ask for fresh towels - it was pretty poor. Overall, for $250 a night - the value was not there. I would only recommend this hotel for its location - it is VERY good. If you can deal with the price, the noise and lack of service, then definitely stay there - just dont have igh expectations.

Pros:- Excellent location (5 min walk to everywhere - beach, market, dining options, etc.)- Cheaper than other starwood or hiltion properties in Waikiki- Resort fee of $12 includes internet access (wired only - at least in our tower), beach towels/ chair & parking (we used the parking a fair bit, driving in & out multiple times)- clean rooms with a decent shower / bathroomCons:- Ancient rooms, with furniture & furnishings in desperate need for renovation. (the door to the balcony in our room was rattling all night due to the winds, the towel holder in the bathroom came off the drywall)- TV doesn't get most cable channels- 4 elevators are not enough of them for all the guests in this tower (Plan at least 5 extra minute wait every time you want to use the elevators)- May be overpriced for the regular rate they charge- This is probably only relevant to vegetarians, others can ignore this one: the lobby stinks of seafood all day / night long, no way around itIn summary, if I had to pay to stay here (used starwood points), I probably wouldn't. Even using the points was a rip-off (this is not category 4 hotel by any stretch of imagination!)

This hotel has obviously stood the test of time. But it shows in the decor and the buildings. It is also bustling with a mini-armada of staff and guests in the lobby as people come and go at all times. But, it is actually a really good value hotel in the centre of the Waikiki strip so you can walk everywhere. Some of that value comes as it doesn't have direct beach access. That wasn't really important to us, so this seemed like a good choice for a couple of nights stay after returning from the islands and before going home.

Best thing about my stay, I only have 4 more nights. Worst thing about my stay, I still have to endure the next 4 nights here. Upon check in the front desk agent was aloof when speaking with us and told us we were upgraded already as a Starwood platinum members. She has put us in a "renovated" room and that the hotel is fully sold out. When we opened the door to the room, the last renovation was probably during Reagan administration. The wallpapers were peeling, theres mold near the ceiling, and rusty fixtures in the bathroom. I was appalled how this was a category 4 hotel when we typically stay just across the street at the Moana and that's just one category higher! For similar prices stay at the Marriott or even the Hyatt were they don't charge you a "resort" fee $12 (which I totally don't mind paying if this was truly a resort, which it's not). I was handed a stack of coupons and cards upon check in for happy hour and for towels and chairs. The chair rental is at the end of the strip about a 15 min walk, not across the street as one might assume. I was about to pack my bags and just go to the Marriott where they would have a room for me there right away based on my platinum membership and treated me with concern and valued my business. My wife spoke with the manager in charge and miraculously she found another room for us, one that doesn't have Goodwill donated furniture. Apparently when we were told "renovations" it only applied to the LCD tv and new bed linens, well thank heavens or else I'm guessing the linens would be from the 60's when the hotel opened. The bell man told us they are demolishing these towers next year so it's all the same condition. So Starwood let me ask you this. How can you attach the Sheraton name and call this a cat 4 hotel misleading loyal guests to this facade of a resort hotel. I've stayed at Four Points in the middle of no where that have better rooms and better service than one would expect from a tourism driven city.

This hotel is in a great location and most of the staff is very nice. But the truth is this hotel leaves a lot to be desired. First, it's NOT on the beach. To get to the beach you need to cross the street and walk around several other hotels. Second, it's very crowded and dated. Wallpaper was peeling off the walls in our room and the bathroom had built-up crud on the floor. Third, the rooms are small and few of them have any sort of view. But you CAN hear music all night long from the neighboring hotels, making it hard to sleep. Finally, the parking is very inconvenient; the structure is quite a walk away from the hotel. And there's no elevator to the higher levels. Next time I'll stay somewhere else.

I stayed in the Sheraton Princess for 5 nights between the 25th Nov - 30th Nov. The service was excellent. We booked a Pool view room and were upgraded to an Ocean view room in the Ainahau tower, the room was in need of some renovations, especially the bathroom, it appeared to be a little shabby & old, but in good condition & well priced. The room safe required a service when we checked in and the service man was there to fix it within 5 minutes of our phone enquiry. The view was just beautiful, overlooking the Moana Surfrider hotel & the ocean, it was a delight waking up to every morning. The Hotel is in the best position, I have been to Hawaii 3 times before this holiday, this being my 4th, and have to say this was by far the best location as we were in heart of eateries, shopping & across the road from the beach.I definetaly would recommend anyone wanting to stay in the heart of Waikiki, on a budget and requiring a decent, well serviced hotel to stay here. The staff were very friendly, helpful & grateful. 3 out of the 5 days we stayed here we had the Buffet breakfast, the Ainahau Buffet breakfast which was $27 per head, which included scrambled eggs made on the spot, bacon, sausages, hash browns, pastries, fruit, cereal, coffee & juices.. My husband was not with me on vacation this time, as I was with a friend on a shopping & ladies getaway, and it happened to be my birthday on the 28th Nov, while I was there, he called the hotel from home and ordered a bottle of Champagne & chocolate strawberries to the room as a birthday surprise and was also so impressed by the staff taking his order, they were more than happy to look after the order and went out of their way to call him back confirming it. I recieved it as Rooms service in the evening, and it was such a beautiful surprise, the preparation and typed up birthday card from the hotel was just fantastic. I cant speak highly enough for the hotel staff. The $14.00 added package fee daily, was well worth it, we recieved, 1 hour of international phone calls a day, it didnt matter if we made 3 phone calls of 5, they just had to add up to 1 hour. Hotel parking (which we didnt use or need), 20 minutes internet usage a day & 2 fresh water bottles. There was a misunderstanding with the internet usage as we thought you used 20 minutes in the day, not in one go, it wasnt expalined to us properly when we checked in, and when we complained about the additional internet charges & the misunderstood procedure of their usage, the lady in the front desk took it to the Manager who deleted the extra internet charges from our bill almost immediately. It was a misunderstanding as it wasnt explained upon check in properly. I do recommend this Hotel if you're looking for a place to stay in the heart of Waikiki and on a budget. It is definetaly in the best position and well priced.

We stayed here while visiting our son a week before Xmas. The staff was very courteous and helpful. The beds were very comfortable! Next time I would book a room overlooking the pool because the city side was very noisy at night. Being right in the middle of Waikiki Beach is very convenient. All the busses picked you up right across the street. The hotel also is right next to the International Marketplace (good foodcourt for a quick take out or sit down lunch). The pool area is great and has nightly "hula" entertainment. They provide beach towels, chairs, fruit and water for their quests to take across the street to Waikiki Beach (included in the daily resort fee-$12.00) as well as parking and 20 min. free internet service.

This was my first visit to Honolulu and the hotel was found to be in a good location and immaculate throughout,the staff were friendly and the gingerbread village that was constructed in the lobby was stunning,a nice Christmas treat,I did not eat here but the happy hour mai tais were always good,only downside were the hookers on the corner just a few yards away from the hotel.

A good hotel close to all the Waikiki action. An older Sheraton, now a little dated, but very good value, considering the location. We have stayed there about five times over quite a few years, Last time we stayed, the staff said they had been trying to close the hotel for major renovations, but the popularity of the hotel kept on pushing the redevelopment plans back. We would stay again if the opportunity to holiday in Hawaii came around.

We stayed here July of 2008 and it was excellent. Our room was a high ocean view overlooking the pool on the 17th floor. I don't remember the wallpaper being dated or anything, but I really don't go to Hawaii to take in such things. Being right in the middle of Waikiki Beach there is definitely more to look at. We also booked events through the internet and were pleased that all the busses picked you up right across the street. The hotel also is right next to the International Bazaar. After a multi night discount I think we spent $175.00 a night plus parking. Next time we go to Waikiki I'm not renting a car. We didn't really need it, although we did take a trip around Oahu with the car one of the days. Eat at dukes!

Our stay (mature couple) was split into 3 nights in a 6 th floor room and 1 one, a week later, at 19th level. Both were "beach view" -from balcony. Rooms appeared clean but were certainly in need of care. Bathrooms were shabby in terms of 'finish' around pipe-through-wall openings and the handles , draincovers, etc.(one basin was cracked (not leaking). Beds were comfortable. One 'gripe' was that staff did not seem to know internet fee structure ( wireless). We called Guest Services, were told to disregard the posted fee ($14), that it would be 'deleted from our account'. We had previously asked both Bell desk and Concierge - both had answered 'we do not know'.At checkout, we were being charged full internet rate - that was eventually forgiven - but only by determined protest on our part.We eventually found out from a Globus Tours guide that the fee is $ 14 but an added 'package' form parking etc includes internet use. The whole process was VERY confusing! We did have a comfortable stay .... the rooms adequate but not more!

The Sheraton Princess Kaiulani is a very average hotel, with very dated decor, that is never going to be described as "luxury" or "glamorous". It's more or less clean - your room may look dingy, but that's the age showing. If you need 4- or 5-star accommodations, look elsewhere. Almost every room is described as "ocean view", but that might require creative alignment of your balcony's chair. But it you're just looking for a good clean bed and hot water, then seriously consider the Sheraton Princess Kaiulani - because its location makes it an insanely good value. Literally less than sixty seconds to walk to the Pacific Ocean from the lobby, even though it's not considered "beachfront". Right next to the International Market, with its shopping and food court. And right in the middle of countless restaurants and clubs in downtown Waikiki. (Side note - Waikiki isn't quiet at night, and the hotel's rooms are nowhere near soundproof. I travel with earplugs.)As is common with any hotel nowadays, the Sheraton Princess charges a $14 a day "resort fee", but at least this includes both high-speed cabled (not wireless) room Internet, and parking for one vehicle. There are numerous hotel-organized activities for the family and the kids, and the hotel has an adequate pool, if you don't feel like walking over to the beach (they'll spot you a towel, too.) There is an indoor/outdoor buffet-style restaurant serving breakfast and lunch, but I found it to be pricey - the breakfast buffet at Duke's Waikiki, which is literally right across the street, is $10 cheaper.So in summary, the rooms and facilities of the Sheraton Princess Kaiulani are average and adequate. The service is pleasant, but sometimes struggles to keep up with the load (lines are common). But it's a sensational deal. This hotel is frequently discounted, and participates in Priceline and Hotwire. And its location is platinum-coated 5-star. If you just plan to use your room for sleeping and showering, and budget is an issue, it belongs on your short list.

This hotel has the best location for the value. Yes the rooms are a bit dated, the views are not spectacular and the pool is small but the value of staying right in the midst of Waikiki is great. You can walk to all the restaurants, shopping and beach. When you go to the beach, you can borrow sand chairs to sit in and twice, Sheraton employees come on to the beach and give you a bottle of water and a piece of fruit. One day, they had a pineapple cutting demonstration in the lobby and you got to sample fresh pineapple. We had a drink and watched the music one night by the pool.And it's right across the street (almost) from Duke's which is a great place to have a drink, a burger and see Diamond Head in the background. The resort fee included parking which we used, internet which was spotty, bottled water everyday and a welcome soft drink. The hotel was great for us and we would stay there again.
This hotel is in a GREAT location in Honolulu, just steps away from Waikiki beach. The room was plain and had a musty smell to it, and an overall layer of grime on everything.

The Starwood Sheraton garantee? The hotel needs a big update. Rooms are a joke. Front desk not impressive. Ice machine on tenth floor not working (my floor) Room had a particular odd odor. I would not recommend this Hotel to anyone because of the poor quality of the rooms.

I spent a one night stay with my sister. Checkin was quick as we were the only ones at the desk. A very tired decor greeted us, all part of the Hawaiian charm though!Agree about the additional 'resort charge' being a ridiculous way to scalp more money from guests.This is not a resort - there is only one small pool at the front of the hotel which is beside a main road and is a thoroughfare between the road and the hotel. Hardly relaxing or inviting. Nothing resort-like about it.Disappointing experience compounded by the guest next door who complained to management about noise coming from our room at 9pm (we were talking in low voices INSIDE the room). Check out took over an hour to process as there were not enough concierge staff.

Stayed here for 7 days along with my family (separate rooms). Got an ocean view room on the 21st floor (smoking). The view from the balcony was great morning or anytime. We also got a fruit basket which we devoured. At night you can hear the band playing by the pool, the street performers, and sirens. It doesn't stay noisy too late. Had the buffet one night and it was so so. Very overpriced. The hotel staff was great and very friendly. We would stay here again! The beds and pillow were incredibley comfortable....

This Hotel was above my expectation after booking it and then reading many negative reviews! The room was clean and had no problems, In fact on arrival they upgraded us from a pool view to a Dlx ocean view room and also they sent us a fruit basket and chocolates from the manager which was VERY nice! We Never experienced rude staff or any problems. We did find the WIFI in the rooms often didnt work. But it also depended on the device we had. For example the iphone worked but not the smartphones! But it wasnt a make or break deal as we are on Vacation! And shouldnt be on our phones the entire time anyway! We found the bedding to be hard and the beds we had were doubles which were small for 2 people. The pool was very cold which is why i found people never swam in it. But maybe they like this so it less cleaning? We only ate at the hotel twice and never buffet! We ate at the bar area and the food was good! The Volcano salad is yummy! Prices are yes high, but everything is high in Waikiki! The Daily rate charge was okay as we had a car and alot of other hotels do charge parking! My kids loved that we got fruit and water given to us at the beach that was included in the daily rate! I saw the rate was going up to $18. Now i feel thats getting a little bit much. I would stay here again! Loved the location and the friendly service! Thanks for a Lovely trip!

I was offended at check in by the representative that repeatly asked me if I am sure that I want to use a debit instead of a credit card. He even went on to tell me how much it would cost me. Other than that, the hotel staff was great, always smiling and will to help including getting one of the kids swim trunks that fell off the balcony. The pineapple tasting by far was a favorite of the adults and children, they have several other free classes each day in the lobby area. They buffet prices were more than I wanted to spend, approximately 20.00 for breakfast and 30.00 for dinner. Burger King and Subway are right across the street along with KFC. The International Market was less than a block away from the hotel with at least a 100 shops, mainly souvenir items. In addition, within walking distance is many other shopping places and restaurants to include Gucci, Fendi, Cartier, AX, Macys, P.F. Chang, Hard Rock Cafe and Cheesecake factory. The hotel rate was the best I found in that area for an average hotel room, but very pleasant with free Wi-fi and parking.

This is our first trip to Hawaii and the beaches are beautiful. I could go on and on about the beauty however this review is about the hotel. I'm very disappointed. The daily resort fee? Really! The staff who could not help with getting on the in room wifi. We ultimately had to go down to the lobby and use the computer and guess what? Yep had to pay for what felt like dial up. Not one staff member advised of things to do (lei making, ginger bread house class) I found this by chance by seeing the class happening. The wonderful breakfast buffet - NOT. Unless you like paying $23 for less than 10 hot items and having pigeons on your table before during and after you eat. Then heaven forbid two of you go to breakfast and only one wants to eat. I am not a big breakfast person my wonderful husband gave me a bite of his breakfast and his coffee the waitress came right over to our table and advised that if I eat off his plate she will charge us for another meal. Ok ok, we finished. My hubby went to wash his hands in the restroom the waitress was waiting for him to find out our room # Why? We paid cash. Now our room, small, out of date. I work in a hotel and understand the meaning of no service. On our 2nd day the maid chased me down and said I must have service. No, I don't want service. I can only assume she made me have service because she is paid per room. Overall I am not happy with this hotel I feel like an intruder vs a guest. Our stay is not over so let's hope it gets better.

We go to Hawai once or twice a year and most of the time stay at the Princess Kaiulani ,which is a decent and pleasant hotel .We usually spend only the night there for the room ,even if slightly spartiat has comfortable beds,we appreciate te possibility to use all the services of the all the other Starwood hotels in Waikiki.I did not appreciate the fact that we were billed 12 $ a day for services we were not using.Worse when I decided to use my I Pad there were no WIFI connection in the building where my room was located and was obliged to go in the lobby.I am always glad to pay for things which are working or which I use...if not I still like that princess

I have stayed here many many times - - - but have NEVER been able to get a room before the check-in time of 3pm. They always say you can check your bags and go have lunch. I think they are trying to create a job for the bell-boys and trying to drum up business for their empty dining area. They have a daily resort fee and why I do not understand - - I don't call this a resort !!! Rooms are very small and so are their bathrooms. Make sure you get a room with a balcony. I found that the desk-clerks are not very friendly and very very slow in helping others.

My wife and I just returned from a first ever vacation to Hawaii. Hawaii had never been on our "bucket list" but we're delighted we went. I'm going to review a few elements of the trip but this will be the first and I'll try to identify other elements which will appear in separate reviews. The other elements I'll CAPITALIZE so if you're interested you can find them on Trip Advisor (TA).First, the Sheraton Princess Kaiulani...we'd read lots of TA reviews so our expectations weren't too high. We were pleasantly surprised. The reviews that comment on the fact that the hotel is 'somewhat tired' are correct - but it's great nevertheless. The location is ideal. If there's any location complaint it's the noise on the street but Kalakaua Ave. is Waikiki's main drag. The people watching is outstanding. If there's one complaint it's the street vendors. They're everywhere. But I digress. I'm going to write another review of HONOLULU/OAHU/WAIKIKI but this one should focus on the hotel.Our room on the 21st floor faced Waikiki Beach. It was wonderful looking out at the surfers that were there from the minute the sun came up to when it was too dark to see. The room was clean and comfortable - if a bit tired. No complaints!!!The people at the hotel are what makes it. Everyone we met that worked there was friendly and helpful. The all seemed to work hard to make our stay there special and relaxing. I have no complaints. The folks at the front desk went out of their way to ensure we had our every wish fulfilled. The housekeeping staff did a great job. All in all, everyone was terrific. I'd say, such a commitment to customer service starts at the top so congrats to senior management.Location wise it's excellent. Located right across Kalakaua Ave from Waikiki beach is great. Since we rented a car (at the airport) for the three days we were there we found it easy to navigate around the city and around the Island.The Sheraton charges a $12.00 per day "resort fee" on top of the room rate. It includes a variety of things like parking, beach chairs, water and fruit brought to you on the beach, a free welcome drink. Aside from the free welcome drink, the only thing we used was the parking and with rates in such a built up area as Waikiki we were glad of the parking garage.I want to do a couple of other reviews of the trip that have nothing to do with the hotel so if you're interested where I've capitalized certain things, there will be a review of it somewhere on TA. One thing is the WESTJET FLIGHT to Honolulu, another is the NCL CRUISE we took from Oahu to Maui to Hawaii to Kawaii. Four islands, unpack once. Great way to do it.I'd also be remiss if I didn't comment on two other hotels in separate reviews - the ASTON BEACHWALK HOTEL at Waikiki and the COAST AIRPORT HOTEL in Vancouver.If you have any questions about this or any other post I'm happy to get your email and I will respond to your questions.

My daughter had a competion in Hawaii and we stayed and had a great time. We got upgraded to a better room status and the rate was reasonable however the resort fees are ridiculess. They charge you for every day you`re there even if you`re out of the hotel all day every day like we were because of her competion.

We stayed here because friends we were traveling with got us a really cheap rate. If it wasn't so cheap, I would not have been happy at all. Our room was so tiny, I jokingly called it the "kleenex box" all weekend. It was so small that the wall was literally a couple steps from the bed. Also, there was a piece of masking tape holding the curtain together! Aside from that, the room was very clean & the staff very helpful. My sister had gotten a room with two queen beds and it was huge & overlooked the beautiful Sheraton Moana Surfrider. Guess some of us just weren't lucky! Overall it was clean, the bed was comfy & it was very near to the action & great restaurants of Waikiki.

Stayed at the hotel for 8 nights during Thanksgiving holiday. The lobby, the common area downstairs are lovely and great parking garage at the back of the hotel. We stayed one night in a king size bedroom and then moved to a double bedroom. Both rooms are very aged.The bathrooms are old, fixtures gold plated had rubbed off to silver. The beds are warned to the point that my husband woke up with a backache in the morning.The daily maid service was inconsistance. some days were better than others. One day we came back to the room and our shower curtain dissapeared!!We are Starwood gold members and we stayed at Sheraton around the world. This one definately sub standard for Sheraton.

I had a last minute change of hotels due to the resort closing down for renovations. I worked with a travel agent who offered the Sheraton. I thought the Sheraton is a well known name amongst hotels so how could I go wrong and I really wanted my first trip to Hawaii to be issue free. My first issue with the property is that it is in need of remodeling. The manager of the hotel sent us a fruit basket and chocolates which was nice. The food within the hotel I thought was too expensive. The street noise was bearable because we were on a high floor. The staffed helped you but were not overly friendly.

We extended our vacation by a day and our hotel (Moana) didn't have availability so we move to the Sheraton Princess for the last night since that was where the Moana had parked the car. There is a Sheraton down the beach from the Moana where we had spent a few afternoons/evenings so I didn't think twice that this particular Sheraton would be as disappointing as it turned out to be since it was across the street from the Moana and 1 block from the beach. 1) Our car was broken into2) One of the ladies at the front desk was dismissive when trying to check in - luckily, there was someone else that was much more pleasant and ready to work3) The parking/towel process/coupon is a huge pain and makes one feel instantly under suspicion4) The rooms were old, dirty, and had peeling wall paper5) The front desk is non-responsive to phone calls from the room (a few calls over a 15 minute period - one call was actually picked up and then immediately hung up by the staff) and the guest services rep suggested that I just keep calling and letting the phone ring. I suggested that she leave a message for someone to call me back. Fortunately, that person was responsive.6) The pool area is small7) The lobby was full of vendors8) The holiday decorations were over the top and tackyI would not stay here again and I will contact Starwood for suggesting that this Sheraton would be a good way for a Platinum member to use an award night.

Hotel was in a great location, right off the main strip. The accommodations were pretty sub par I stayed on the 3rd floor room 317. There was this loud mechanical noise that pretty much hindered my sleep. The hotel was full so we couldn't change rooms. I'd stay clear of this room if at all possible. Room and bathroom weren't very clean. I give the low rating for the room quality. I'd assume if I got a better room on the higher floors it would have been a better stay.Overall the property was nice, great location in Waikiki if you're staying in the area...you can pretty much walk to everything in the area.

Great location. We stayed in the 5th level Kaiulani tower, whilst it is in need of a renovation was clean and well priced when considering the location and the price of the Moana across the road. Pool and resort area was good with entertainment every night. Did not use the restraunts there but they seemed popular with people. Balcony view was of the car park below so did not use this at all but we were out most of the time anyway. Room could do with a little furniture ie extra chair. Would certainly stay there again.

My first trip to Hawaii to celebrate my 35th birthday and I'm currently staying at the Sheraton Princess Kaiulani. This is our first day and we got no maid service. Bed is still unmade, bathroom not cleaned. I'm pretty low maintenance, didnt want nor expect fresh linens, but make the bed! I am not impressed. I hope we get some maid service tomorrow, but I wouldn't recommend this place so far.

No, it's not as fancy as the Moana across the street...but you can use all of the Moana's facilities. I have stayed at the Sheraton PK six times and of all the hotels I have stayed at in Waikiki (7 hotels), in provides the most consistant value. Where else can you stay in Waikiki within two minutes of the beach for less than $150 per night.No the facilities in this hotel are not four or five stars, but it's price and proximity to the beach make it a better value than any of the beach hotels. Most hotels in it's price class are several blocks from the beach, not one block.Great bang for the buck here. I highly reccomend the PK to those wanting the proximity to the beach for half or even a third the price. Plus, you can always dine at the Royal Hawaiian, Moana, or Sheraton Waikiki and charge it to your room.

We stayed at the Sheraton PK for four days on o stop over on our way to New Zealand....The locations was fantastic!!!! Close to everything...Stores close by and Restraunts galore to choose from.Our room on the 26 th floor had a view of Waikiki to die for...watching the surfers on the beach at six every morning was surreal and I would recommend it to anyone.Our room was very good and the bed and linens were top notch....okay the hall ways are stuck in the seventies ..but you only use them to get to your room....really people if that's all you have to complain about ...you really need to get out more!!!!! After all you are in Waikiki. We had no complaints!!!!Give it a try!!!

We stayed here for the first two nights of a ten night trip to Hawaii. Looking at the website we kind of knew what to expect - touristy, a little tacky, but in the middle of it all. Having read Tripadvisor we knew it'd be a bit tired but would do the trick. We found reasonable rates on the Sheraton website and bit the bullet - we really just needed somewhere to stay for two nights so weren't too fussed.Upon arrival we knew it was going to live up to expectations. I guess that if you don't travel a lot then you could love this place. It was a bit garish and when we checked in we didn't really get the level of attention you'd expect at a better hotel - there's a little bit of a tourist conveyor-belt approach to things. Our room was tiny - absolutely miniscule. We were on a low floor, in the shorter tower, and faced a car park. I think our special rate got us one of the worst rooms available. The rooms in the main tower could have been better - they all seemed larger from the outside and had balconies. In the end room size didn't matter much - the first night we were there we were very jetlagged, the second we were a bit drunk. The hotel and rooms are incredibly tired and in desperate need of a makeover. They are definitely "nineties in Nagoya" themed and the beige overload still gives me nightmares. The room was a bit grubby too and in need of a major spring cleaning. The bed was great - a decent Sheraton bed. I did sleep well. The bathroom was tiny and the shower head could only be attached at two levels - one too low and one really high - it was very odd. The bathroom was tiny too and reminded me of Japan. We didn't have breakfast at the hotel as I think it was $25 per person for the buffet - which was far too expensive, even for Waikiki. You can get similar buffets at some of the 5 star hotels nearby for the same price. The gym was pretty good. It was large, well-equpped and very clean. This is one of the hotel's best features in the end. The pool area was alright but nothing you'd want to go to more than once. The resort's pool towel policy was a bit strict too - a little bit Butlins from what I can imagine - but I suppose it is necessary. The hotel is in a very good location though - very close to the beach and all activities. When we returned to Waikiki for the last 4 days we got a great deal at the Trump which ended up not costing much more than the Sheraton. If you have standards and want a good quality hotel I'd recommend shopping around or waiting a while until you find something a little fancier.

aloha we stayed at the princess from 2-9 nov 2011, and we had a fab time.we did read some of the reviews before we travelled,and was worried about some!but we need not have.we stayed in room 950,which had a,pool,road,&sea view.the entertainment finished at 22.00,so was not a problem,as we were out most nights. our room was kept clean by elydia,who changed our sheets every day, who was very friendly,as were all the staff.YES,the rooms,and the hotel is dated,but was kept clean and tidy,and need some t.l.c,but saw no mold,no roaches,and no fleas!!!!!its our second time in hawaii,and it wont be our last.mahola.

very fast check in polite staff location is in the middle of Waikiki communication great had to change booking all completed correctly via twitter no need for me to call from Australia at great cost small gift at check in very nice touch

We checked in on day one of our five night stay and we are given probably the most disgusting hotel room I have ever entered. There was a strong putrid mold smell coming from the air conditioning vents. We call maintenance and it takes them 30 min to come to the room to confirm the existence of the mold. They show us a couple other rooms that had the same smell we saw the mold growing in one of the closets. Meanwhile my wife was having a terrible reaction to the mold. I told Greg (sic) that there is no way we can stay in this hotel and that it is unsafe and not fit for habitability. He said that if we left he was going to charge us for the 5 nights regardless. I was dealing with hotel management from about 6pm until midnight trying to resolve this issue. It was apparent that hotel management had no care for its guests health and was only concerned about their bottom line. When I told Greg that I have to take my wife to the emergency room because she had a reaction to the mold, his attitude was indifferent and kept repeating that he's going to charge the 5 nights. This was the worst hotel experience I have encountered. I was left with no choice but to book a last minute stay at another hotel and had to pay the difference.

Wonderful Friendly staff. Big busy place. Great location for walking to Waikiki beach, shops & dozens of great eating places. Rooms were clean.AC works great. King bed was VERY comfy. A nice surprise..a very well appointed Gym on 2nd floor open 24/7. Only disappointment here...the Sheraton PK's dining / buffet menues ...were out of this world expensive...we chose to eat at other places much more reasonable.(judging from the small crowds for dinner etc. so did most of the other hotel guests). Drop your prices & fill the place... a no brainer to me. Other than that...highly recommend this hotel. Good value in the heart of Waikiki.

I recently stayed at the Sheraton Princess Kaiulani for three nights. My overall experience was extremely pleasurable and there were very few complaints that I can offer. I can say that I would definitely stay here again.I booked my reservation directly through the hotels website and was able to purchase a buy now rate at a significantly cheaper rate than making a normal reservation. Meaning, I prepaid for all three nights upfront and it was non-refundable.The hotel does not off shuttle service so you will need to arrange transportation from the airport. Check in was fast, efficient and the gentleman who checked me in was very welcoming. The one improvement I could offer the hotel is to provide an envelope to place drink vouchers, towel cards, room keys and daily resort info card into. I was given paper after paper with no where to put it. I was also very happy when I learned that my room received a complimentary upgrade!I stayed on the 5th floor with a lovely view of the ocean, pool and entertainment stage. I was able to enjoy the band and watch the hula dancer each night from my balcony. By the way the entertainment was free! The room itself was a standard 3 star hotel in my view. I had upgraded bedding, flat screen tv, chair, ottoman, desk, mini-fridge and safe in my room. The bathroom was nothing exciting. It was all white and pale colors and the water pressure for the removable shower head was strong! The one thing that needed improvement in the room was the wall paper in the bathroom. It was peeling away from the wall and near the toilet it looked like mold was growing.The hotel is right across the street from the beach, right next to the International market, shopping centers and eateries. I cannot stress to anyone how amazing the location of the hotel is. If it depends on you paying an additional $20-30 per night for a room, consider this place... the location in itself is worth it!Other positives:- housekeeping staff were ALWAYS friendly, greeting with a smile- the hotel was well kept- grounds were niceOther negatives:- front desk staff were SLOW at check out (huge line) and they weren't very friendly, as they were at check in- menu prices for room service, poolside and buffet were very pricey- pool closes at 6pm- was never told where to go for beach side service or chairs- doorman or greeter talked to shuttle driver about tattoos instead of helping me carry my bags to the shuttle- no one offered drinks or a menu poolside, figured there would be waitstaff

I stayed one night in Waikiki and this is a good hotel for short stays. Got lost trying to find this place, but what a great location once you're there. Check in wasn't a long process at all. In fact, the front desk were quite pleasant. The hotel is smaller than other hotels I've been to, but you're next to the International Marketplace in Waikiki, and right across the street from the beach. When I checked in I received welcome drink tickets which was nice. You are surrounded by stores there. If I hadn't had other places to visit, I would of just taken a taxi or hotel shuttle and saved the $$$ from the rental car. It's just so close to everything.When I arrived, I had parked the car in self parking which was $12 a day, which was included in the resort fee. That was cheap compared to what I've paid at the Hilton Hawaiian village which was about $25. I see that everyone stated the internet was included in the resort fee, but when I tried to log in, it said a daily charge of $14 for internet and wifi, but maybe I was so busy with wanting to hit the nightlife, that I didn't notice the passcodes? After stepping foot off the elevator to get to your room, I felt like I was in a 1970's hotel. The rooms were clean and had very comfortable beds, but the rooms decor was very dated and are in need of remodeling especially the bathrooms. We walked by the buffet and decided against it since it was kind of pricey and there were other places to choose. Since you're on an island, everything is pricey. Although, I think this hotel has a great location, I found it to be average due to the hotel being dated comparing to other hotels I've stayed at. A remodel should be in the works. I do think their employees are very friendly and helpful which is a plus.In 5 hours I was able to drive around the island and have dinner in Kahuku @ Giovanni's, take pictures of sea turtles and the beautiful beaches, shop in Haleiwa, eat Shave Ice @ Matsumoto's, eat cake @ The Alley in Aiea and pick up some cookies for the trip home!

My husband and I recently stayed at this hotel. We had pre-paid for the accommodation and presented the hotel with a voucher. When we checked out of the hotel after 5 nights we paid the bill for incidentals (including the resort fee). When we received our credit card bill we found that we had our credit card charged for the accommodation for which we had already paid. We rang the hotel directly and was told that they "lost" the voucher and so charged the accomodation to our credit card (without authorisation). Be warned.
Stayed for 7 nights, everyone was very friendly and helpful. So close to everything including the beach! Have already booked my next stay!

Great location. Quick walk to the beach. The resort fee of $12 a day is a steal. Beach chairs, towels, two bottles of water, free self parking and Internet. Avoid the buffet there. You pay far too much for low quality food and birds all over the place scavenging.

My wife and I stayed here this summer, based upon a recommendation by another couple who had previously stayed there. We loved it, you are in a great section of Honalulu. There is a bit of noise at night, but it wasn't bad. The staff was very nice to us and I thought a benifits was the resort fee which included parking. Parking is very pricey in Hawaii, so you get your value from that alone.Stay away from the buffets, they are very overpriced. The seafood buffet was not that great, but oh my was it expensive. There are many other places in walking distance that are very reasonable.

This hotel has a great location in the heart of Waikiki on the street with great nightlife and much to do. This was my third stay and I was very disappointed in the service. We arrived early and they had a room available but only if we downgraded from my reservation. The room we got was old and not vey nice. Did have a nice beach view from the 17th floor.The second day we returned to the room after 4:00 pm and room service had not been there yet so we had no clean towels. We had to call the desk to get room service. They did not do a thourough job, left melted water in the ice container and did not leave any cream for coffee the next morning. The breakfast buffet was just terrible, cold hard eggs and pancakes. The juice glasses are really really small. Way over priced. Same with the evening dessert buffet. When we arrived for dessert we were charged full price & they closed it ten minutes later. I recommend skipping the food there and going across the street to "Dukes", which has wonderful food at better prices.If your looking for a hawaiian tropical beach vacation instead of city nightlife, try Maui.

Upside of this hotel is the great location and they have been banking on that for 50 years. (Hotel was built in the 60's)The rooms have not been modernized since the Golden Girls were on TV. The decor is white wicker and teal carpet. When I complained about the awful state of my room in a hotel with the SHERATON name I was told by the front desk manager, "yes, we know, we get that a lot and that is why we are scheduled for demolition next year". It's so bad, the best answer is to tear it down and start over.They kick the kids out of the pool at 6PM for the cheesy lounge singer to perform on the artificial grass stage next to the pool, really? You can stay at the Hyatt right next door for the same money. If you want to be on the beach, pay the differance for the Sheraton Waikiki across the street, it's beautiful.

LOCATION: The location is perfect if you like the hustle and bustle of the city.
