We have stayed here each of the last nine years and we always enjoy the stay. While it may need a refurb it is ideal for our requirements. We are always warmly greeted especially by Bo, Lyndsay and Yan at the pool. The position is excellent as it is close to everything with the beach just across the road. There are plenty of restaurants so finding somewhere to eat is never a problem. The parking fee of $25 per day is high but if you have a car you need a park. The parking building does not have an elevator so you need to drop off luggage at the ground level and when leaving to the same by collecting it at ground level.

This is one of the oldest properties on the island and the rooms are tastefully decorated. Alot of japanese tourists at this property. Staff is very senior and have a wealth of experience. The property is closing in 2012 for complete remodeling and teardown and is being rebuilt. The parking garage is small and has no elevator and is 25 dollars/day for self parking.

The Sheraton Princess Kaiulani is right at the heart of Waikiki... you can step out and go to the beach, shopping, restaurants within a few steps! You pay $12 /day for resort fees but then that also includes parking--great deal!The rooms are just ok... I think it's a bit dated but clean. Beds are comfy and you get a balcony and a fridge in room. Rates are a fraction of hotels around the area.I actually had reservations at this hotel before my trip. Cancelled it to book a 2 br hotel room somewhere else but reservation fell through last min. I called and talked to the manager (Chie?) at Princess Kaiulani and she was sooo nice enough to let me reinstate my reservation. My family is so grateful because we were left hanging at 10pm with a sleeping toddler and tons of luggage! We will always remember that. Customer service Rocks!

I travel and stay in hotels frequently for both pleasure and work. The organization I was working with selected this hotel for me and what a disappointment. I went into Honolulu a day before to enjoy the area before my conference started, lookinf forward to a nice pool and beach experience. Honestly I've had better rooms at a Holiday Inn Express than this place. My room was a hodgepodge of mismatched furniture with two chairs stuffed alongside the curtain and bed. There was no desk chair at all. The lamp had a burned out bulb. The room safe was locked and I had have to have security come open it. Plus their "resort" fee for internet is a bit confusing when you go to log on in your room. They need to get that clarified ASAP. But a guide in the room so people know what to do! The benefit is that all the staff I encountered were very nice but this place is tired and in need of a serious renovation. I can't believe Starwood would let a property drop to this level. The location is great but invest a few dollars and make this a worthy Waikiki leisure and business property. Everything about my room was like the Bates motel. Would NOT recommend this place to anyone.

I stayed at the hotel for a conference and a few days on holidays afterwards. I did like the hotel and staff were very friendly. It can get a bit loud as there seems to be a club behind the hotel. Internet was not free, but in the lobby, there is one provider which only costs $20 for a week, the room internet was quite expensive.

Location, location, location. Close to beach, eating, shopping, transportation.. First room had no a/c, but they gave us another room. After that one cooled down, we had no problems. Rooms need remodeling - especially the bathrooms. But everything was clean and everyone was nice - including the trip/event and hotel help desks. We had a really nice trip. Meals were a little too steep, we ate elsewhere.

Aloha - Just returned October 18 from Honolulu/Waikiki and had a wonderful time. Was accompanied by a teenager and young adults. First time to Hawaii and can't wait to return. Will make the vacation a 2 full weeks though and will venture to Maui next time. Our stay at the Princess Kaiulani was very good. The lower level tower that we stayed in (there is a taller tower) is dated no doubt but it is not horrible by any means. A three star rating is where I would but the room at. The walls are not the most soundproofed either so if you have quiet adjoining guests you are okay. The staff, houskeeping, front desk and conceirge are very helpful and pleasant. The location can't be beat right in the heart of everything. The beach is across the street but it is such an easy walk. The buffet breakfast is okay nothing special for the price ($14.00 with a half off coupon) there are other eateries outside to chose from. Easy to get around to attractions and shopping with the trolley bus system they have as well as the local bus system which does go up all the way to the North Shore. The North Shore is a lovely day trip stopping to enjoy the scenery and the different beaches along the way. Top it off with a plate of delicious shrimp from Macky's shrimp truck and then to the famous Matamotsu's for the delicious shaved ice cone - yummy! For this trip we rented a car and a GPS with a tour card and this made our day real easy. We should have started earlier in the morning - like 8 a.m. Parking is hard to find but we parked at a public lot and paid $12.95 for the overnight which was good until 7 a.m. the next morning. They number their parking slots so if you pay the evening rate and go out of the lot you have to ensure you get the same numbered spot when you return (but I reasoned with the attendant saying it should not matter what slot I take when I return because I paid already and they were okay with that). The day rate is $15.95 so a 24 hour rate would run about $30! Tons of shopping from high end Prada, Gucci to affordability of the local stores and markets. There is tons to see and do. If you are interested on the cultural aspect of Hawaii then you must do the day trip to the Polynesian Cultural Centre (PCC) gives you a taste of the different islands. There are different packages to chose from so do your research before booking it. It is really hard to wake up and look out to the beautiful blue skies, sunshine and blue water beach. Until next trip. Aloha!

Great service, nice rooms and great location. Perhaps not the standard of a "Business" Sheraton hotel but very good all the same as a resort hotel. Surprised that there was no room service after 8pm. Would be more than happy to stay again at the right price.

Whilst not maitaining Sheraton standards,still a excellent value for money hotel with a comfortable bed in an wonderful location,One's ability to sleep is somewhat comprised by the noise levels from adjacent streets.

The hotel lobby is open and has the older Hawaiian feel. We didn't eat our meals at the hotel. The hotel is so centralized that we just walked and ate at nearby restaurants. There is an ABC convenient store right across the street and another larger grocery market is within walking distance for quick bites and souvenirs. The hotel also offered free ukelele lessions (which we took part in) and had local artists selling crafts (i.e. wood carvings, paintings, jewelry etc...). There was also music/hula shows by the pool and bar, which offered a nice Hawaiian ambiance. One day, one of the head chefs gave a demo on how to choose a good pineapple, how to slice one up and had samples for us. And most importantly, the hotel is only across the street from Waikiki Beach. It was very convenient to stroll our little ones around, even though we had a rental car for our further day trips.We didn't have much of a view from our hotel room, though it was supposed to be partial ocean view. We had a "sliver" of the ocean if you walk out on the balcony, turn your head 90 degrees to the right looking between 2 highrises. We were in the tower but the rooms were still very dated. However, our room was pretty roomy and tey were Sheraton quality clean and the beds were comfortable. We didn't mind the view (or lack of) because we were mostly out for the day.

We spent 3 nights in Honolulu at the end of an around-the-world trip and were looking for comfort at less than premium prices. We enjoyed the location just a block from the beach with the International Market close by(as well as all the other shops). We wanted to do some day/evening trips and the concierge and trip advisor were both particularly helpful. We had to check out at 11.00 am but our flight did not leave till 11.00 pm so the hotel staff were helpful with baggage during the day. The poolside entertainment was great and made staying around very pleasant.The only downside was the very loud steel drum band for the road which could be heard 22 stories up!

I have stayed in this hotel twice and have enjoyed myself. While not the most ideal rooms (they need renovations big time), the location and price is great value for money! I will be back next year, and have booked Princess Kaiulani once again. Why pay triple to stay across the road? The ocean view room was more than I expected!

We have stayed in this hotel 5 or 6 times over the last 20 years. Every stay was great until this one. (December 2009 - January 2010). The location of this hotel is excellent and the price has always been reasonable. Rooms are okay size for our purposes and we have always had a lanai with nice view, whether it is the pool or the city. There has always been adequate storage for clothing/belongings. We never noticed any noise from neighboring rooms.This trip it all went downhill. The room furnishings, which used to include tv armoire with large drawers for clothing etc. were replaced with a small stack of drawers attached to the wall in the closet. (kind of like small kitchen drawers). Not enough room to unpack. (We were staying for 2 weeks). We asked about this at the front desk and were told the old furniture had been replaced with this upgraded furniture from some other hotel in the Sheraton chain. So we lived out of suitcases for 2 weeks. The small refrigerator in the room was filthy on the outside. It was fine on the inside. The handle was so dirty, that I used a cloth to open it everyday.The noise at night from the neighboring room was horrendous. Every night the parents and small child came home around 11 pm and just starting to scream at each other for the next few hours. This went on for several nights until my husband knocked on the door and told them to keep it down. This could be a fluke. You never know who is staying next door, but I've never encountered people at this hotel who would be so rude as to scream all night. Staff was always extra pleasant on prior visits. They weren't unpleasant this time, just kind of neutral, which is okay but I missed the extra pleasant attitude. So, although you cannot beat the location and price, I will not stay there again due to the dirtiness and the noise.Also, this is the first time we used the gym. It was pretty good for a hotel gym, but they kept all the doors to the outside closed, so it was very hot and we didn't get to enjoy the beautiful Hawaiian breeze.

We arrived late, in the night. I was a little surprised on the reception. They were not all that friendly, but I accounted that for being how late it was. The hotel was affordable, convenient to all the hot spots. The entertainment was ok, at best We went to the Mona Surf Rider a lot for their patio instead. The pool was super cold! Unbearably cold. All in all it was a good stay for the price.

My wife and I stayed at the Hotel for the long weekend at the beginning of the month. Our room was originally booked through a travel agency and was located on the 4th floor of the older tower. It has a view of the parking garage. After mentioning to the hotel front desk that we were there on an anniversary weekend, they upgraded us (for a small fee) to a room on the 22nd floor in the newer tower with a balcony and a partial view of the beach. It was all that we expected of a Sheraton hotel. The location of the hotel was perfect. It was close to center of Waikiki and near everything else that you would need in Oahu. The beach is right across the street and it was nice to watch the sunset from one of the restaurants located in Sheraton's Royal Hawaiian Hotel which is their sister hotel located directly across and by the oceanside. We regretted that we didnt stay longer.

We booked two adjoining high ocean view rooms. To view the ocean you had to lean over the balcony and look between two other building to see a sliver of the ocean. We were not given connecting rooms which we paid for ahead of time at a cost of 31.41 per room per day. They said we could not get our money back for the connecting rooms since it was paid in advance. I had to call our travel agent and have them contact the hotel. We were moved to connecting room on our third day. We will never stay at this hotel again.

This Sheraton property is terribly outdated. We are on our honeymoon and for our first week stayed at the Sheraton in Maui on Black rock. Whom upgraded us to a junior suite for FREE which averages $3400 a week! Upon our arrival at this Sheraton here on Oahu we were terribly disappointed. You can tell not only from the outside but the inside as well the age of the hotel. They did not offer us any upgrades-- instead told us we could pay an additional $80 a night for a "suite upgrade". We looked at the room just to see and were horrified.. The room was old, it smelled it's age, the bathroom was foul, and to be frank not even close to worth $80 a night. My husband nor I would ever recommend this hotel and had their website photos not been misleading wouldn't have booked in the first place. We have put a call into our travel agent to try to change hotels. This was unacceptable. The restrooms on the main floor are also gross. Since this hotel would not let us check into our room early the offered to hold our baggage. Which we assumed would be in a room... It is actually just a roped off section of the lobby which I thought to be sketchy. After removing all of my valuables I hesitantly let them place our things behind the ropes. The bags were unattended the whole time I was watching and it would be very easy to swipe an item or two.-very disappointed honeymooners.

This hotel is located right in the middle of the strip, which makes it in a great spot. It's nearly a 30 sec walk to the beach, just cross the street and you are there. We got to our room, 911, which I didn't love that number. Anyways, one wall shared the wall with an elevator shaft, so you constantly heard that. TERRIBLE design. It was nearly all white walls, SO small of a room, and no counter in the bathroom, just a sink. Terrible. We couldn't stand it so we upgraded to a bigger room which was a smart upgrade. It was a cheap upgrade, something like 30 / night. Way worth it. In general, the hotel is still an older one that some things need some rennovation. The lobby, etc is fine, but some rooms are crappy. I would stay there again maybe if I got the sweet travel package that I got, but otherwise, I probably wouldn't.

My husband and I are on our honeymoon. Wegot a very tiny room with old furnitures. The first thing I notice is the bathroom. Very awful! Dirty looking sink and tub. Has an orange color stain on it. It made me feel very uncomfortable so I asked to be moved to another location. They said it was an upgrade but the next room we got was on the 7 th floor. Still very tiny but an LCD tv this time I stead of the bulky 1980's tv. The bathroom was still awful. The water would barely come out. My 4th night my husband sat on the chair and was kneeling over to the bed with it and it broke! Cheap furnitures! Lucky he wasn't hurt by it. Wish we had a better hotel for our honeymoon.

I stayed at this hotel with my husband at the end of a wonderful holiday as we travelled back through Honolulu. First let me state that there are two Sheraton hotels in Honolulu, and although we asked for ours by it's full name we were taken to the wrong one. Not their fault but a very annoying start, and we had to get a second taxi down the street. The hotel is central and right on the main strip, so the location is good. However, checking in took a very long time even though there were a number of people serving at the desk. We were given two keycards - only one of which worked. We tried to get a replacement but were ignored at the desk for so long that we eventually gave up and just used one. We were also informed during check-in that the room/bed type we requested was unavailable (disappointing since we booked months in advance). They offered to upgrade us to a "partial ocean view", so we agreed.Well, if this was the upgraded room, I dread to think what the original must have been like! It was very small, with tired decor, dents in the wall, odd furniture including a metal bedside contraption that was out of reach anyway, peeling paint and the oldest TV I have seen in a long time. The bottled water was the high point. The bathroom was likewise very old with some broken fittings, peeling seals etc. It was very clean but just didn't feel nice.We had a flight to catch the next day so we were looking forward to a good night's rest. However, even though we were on a side facing room (off the street) and on the 25th floor, the noise from below was disturbingly loud until at least 2am. The windows just didn't seem to keep out any noise. The AC was also ineffective for such a small room!I lost a personal item during the holiday. I can't be sure it was even left at this particular hotel, but I sent a query anyway. The link from the hotel's own website took me to the central office, who took a few days to respond and then requested more details. My details were eventually passed back to the hotel (who I had been trying to contact directly from the start!) and another couple of days later they responded that it had not been found. Again, not their fault that I lost something, but not the most efficient customer service in response.Our overall impression was that the place had not been well looked after for a while. In a hotel that size I fully expect a long wait for the lifts and the occasional blip, but our experiences added up to a pretty poor stay. While it wasn't all bad, I wouldn't recommend it to a friend or stay here again - the premium you pay for the Starwood brand just didn't provide the experience you expect from the name. Compared to the other hotels we stayed at during this trip, we were definitely underwhelmed.

My girlfriend and I live in Honolulu and had a friend fly in from the mainland for a visit. We booked a weekend "staycation" at the Princess Kaiulani and loved it. Even though we were across the street from the beach, we enjoyed an unopbstructed view of "Queens" and other surf spots from our balcony. The deep pool and courtyard was a nice bonus as well. Great location near the beach and shopping on Kalakaua. The all-you-can-eat crab buffet dinner rocked! This is a perfect place for locals to get away from the same old grind of daily life and play tourist for a couple of days.

Starwood pretty much owns Waikiki. Which is fine with me, since IMO Starwood properties are generally higher quality than Hilton or Priority Club properties. That said, a few always slip through the cracks....and the Princess Kaiulani is one of those hotels.This property is, quite simply, tired. Not at all deserving of the "Sheraton" brand...sticking Sweet Sleeper beds and LG flatscreens into ancient hotel rooms that look like they haven't been refreshed since the 80s just doesn't cut it. We booked a High Ocean View room, which are located in the higher floors of the newer (1960s) Ainahou tower....but when we arrived, we were told we'd been "upgraded" to a Deluxe View room in the older Princess tower. I was suspicious, but hey, an upgrade is an upgrade!The hallways were dimly-lit and bare....it looked like my college dorm. The room had completely bare walls, ancient green carpet, a tiny out-of-date bathroom, no chairs (!) and a view of....the pool. I double-checked the website and confirmed that, yes, this was the highest room category available...inexplicable. But since we were only paying $130/night, we decided to shrug it off, find some dinner and get to sleep.At 5:30am my wife and I were awakened by the couple next door. No screaming or shouting or singing, though....they were just speaking at a completely normal level. I could understand every word they said, even though there was a wall between us. Amusingly, they were talking about how they couldn't sleep. Neither could we, of course. :)We asked for another room in our original room category, and were moved to the 18th floor of the Ainahou tower. This building was clearly newer, and the view was incredible (see pics). The room was a bit smaller than our Princess Tower room, but had nicer furniture (still very old) and a larger bathroom. However, the noise level from surrounding rooms was still awful. Every time the phone rang next door, I picked up ours. I could hear their cel phone alarms. Once again, I could understand every word said next door, even at "indoor voice" levels. I could even tell what TV shows they were watching! It was so bad that we started taking Benadryl before going to sleep, which thankfully worked.So no, I don't recommend staying here. But if you must, remember to ask about the resort fee during check-in. For $12.94/day, it covers your parking, your internet access (at a woefully slow 256kbps) and two daily bottles of water. Separately, all that would cost you well over $40 ($25 alone in parking). It's the best deal in Waikiki. Too bad you have to stay here to take advantage of it...

My friend Donna and I stayed at the Princess Paiulani for 3 days before our cruise. Then after the cruise, we were going to stay at a different less expensive hotel one block further away from beach. While we were on the cruise, we canceled the second hotel and rebooked the Princess Kaiulani. We slept well, wonderful mattress and pillows. You can check out chairs, towels etc to take to beach. The price was great! Be sure and ask for Deluxe Ocean View. My favorite. Even tho the second stay was Labor Day Weekend, we were able to book at the same low price. We were upgraded to a upper floor, and each time room was ready early-didn't have to wait. And Management sent us a fruit basket for coming back!! LOCATION LOCATION LOCATION. And yes, there was street music on two different nights, someone pounding on his drums out on the street. But we overlooked a wonderful hula show every night. Did not use their meals. But as a Starwood Member we were able to go the the Moana-Westin and the Royal Hawaiian and charge our meals to our room key and receive a discount! We are going back next year.

My spouse and I had purchased a travel package through an agent and this hotel was recommended. I usually stay at Hilton, Marriott and staying at Sheraton properties are usually rare. This property is an older hotel, but the rooms were well maintained and cleaned.The $24 breakfast buffett was a bit steep, but we went out for meals. They do have three desktop computers for guests to access the internet, but there were usually two people waiting for the three occupied computers. I really didn't need to check e-mail because I'm on vacation! We purchased the USC package to attend the rally and game versus U of H, and found the hotel very quiet even with the number of Trojan faithful; Fight On!My small complaint dealt with the faucet in the tub would expel quite a bit of water when the shower was used. But overall, this hotel is a bargain and very close to shopping, restaurants, public transportation and the Waikiki Beach.

Unfortunately, this hotel was a bit of a disappointment and was expecting much more from a Sheraton.It is ideally located in Waikiki but that was it. Compared to the other hotels we'd stayed in this trip which were cheaper, we found this hotel shabby and old fashioned throughout.. Our room looked over the pool and we had a good view of the beach over the lovely old hotel across the road. Unfortunately, our room, probably no different to anyone else's, was noisey - the noise coming from the main street and also from it's own band in the courtyard which didnt stop until 10pm - would be a problem if trying to get kids to sleep. Hotel restaurant is expensive for what it is at $30pp buffet breakfast. Bar staff not real friendly either. Did try to use booking agent but couldnt be bothered waiting in the line. Definately need to lift their game.You'll get better deals elsewhere.

Pros: Great location 1 block from beach (ie. either you are on the beach like your hotel exits to the beach or you are one block away, where you cross the street and you are at the hotel that is on the beach. Great value if you are looking for a deal.Cons: For a Sheraton, would expect it to be in bette condition. Very dated. Needs renovation. Food was okay. Gold SPG membership didn't get any upgrades or improved room.

From the moment we arrived to the moment we had to leave, the staff couldn't have been more helpful! I care more about how I'm treated than if the carpets and drapes need updating! We arrived rather early in the AM, expecting our room would not be ready, but the desk person arranged for us to be upgraded and have rooms immediately. We were treated to a fantastic view from our balcony! Pool personnel were friendly, concierge extremely helpful when we asked about tours and transportation, bell captain took great care of us as well! I would not hesitate to stay here again! Mahalo!

We really enjoyed our stay at the Sheraton Princess. The location was absolutely perfect, central to everything. Our room was comfortable, no frills, but clean and cozy. We had a city view booked and they bumped us up to a pool view :) The hotel staff was incredibly pleasant from the front desk to the housekeepers to the restaurant wait staff. Restaurant was nice, but a bit pricey. Food was very good though! The only bone I have to pick is if you pay with a debit card (Visa/Mastercard drawn from a bank account), be prepared for the computer system to do funky things to you when you use it for the first time at either the restaurant or splash bar by the pool. I was not prepared for this, considering I had a $50 resort credit, and it kind of upset me. What the system does is it takes your first transaction and times it by depending many days you are staying. We stayed 6 days so it took one drink at $11 and multiplied it by 6. So it placed a $66 hold on my credit card, which is still being held a week later. That was $66 I had less of for my trip. They deducted the resort credit off my final bill, however.  Location is perfect. Across the street is some fast food places if you are on a budget like we were. Denny's is right around the corner as well as Chilis. You can cut through the pool to get to Kalakaua Ave where the International Market Place is just a few doors down and the beach is across the street. And, of course, there are ABC Store's everywhere.  Nightly entertainment by the pool was very nice and relaxing and over by 9:30pm, so no worries about being disturbed.  We would stay here again in a heart beat! Aloha!

The Princess Kaiulani has been my go-to hotel in Waikiki for nearly 20 years. I've tested the competition, but always return to the PK for it's wonderful layout, veteran staff of delightful hosts, nightly poolside entertainment, and 50-yard walk to Waikiki Beach.I will agree that some of the rooms have aged, however the quality remains quite good for the price.We make a point of enjoying the somewhat pricey, yet delicious buffet one evening during each stay.Because the hotel is located in the hustle and bustle of Waikiki, there can be significant street noise until the wee hours of the morning as vacationers soak up their share of aloha. I recommend requesting a room that overlooks the King's Village shopping square. Those rooms are on the relatively quiet Kaiulani Avenue and are better protected from the noise that emanates from the main thoroughfare and the International Marketplace (can someone *please* outlaw calliope playing??).Rooms facing the pool are particularly nice as you are able to sit on your balcony, enjoy the evening entertainment and watch the world go by.As a side note, I am very happy to see from the management comments below that Mr. Orr remains in charge of the PK. I had occasion to meet him many years ago and I'm sure his steady hand may be credited for keeping such wonderful staff members on board for years.

My husband and I celebrated our 25th anniversary and stayed at The Sheraton Princess Kaiulani this month for six nights. Our room was on the 23rd floor with a partial ocean view. I was a little disappointed when my travel agent told me we only had a partial ocean view. As it turned out, the view was perfect! We could see the mountains, the buildings, the street, and the ocean. We even had a view of the pool. At night we could hear the music coming from the pool area on our balcony. Each day we saw huge, magnificent rainbows.  The hotel is in the perfect location to the beach, shopping, and restaurants. We were able to be a part of the activity when we wanted and retreat to our balcony when we wanted to be alone. The hotel arranged transportation for us when we needed it.It was easy to get a towel for the beach. We enjoyed the coffee stand just outside of the pool. The room was clean and comfortable. We were able to receive $5 certificates because we requested not to have our room cleaned each day. ("Green Program")Champagne and chocolate covered strawberries from my parents were delivered to our room. One of the managers went above and beyond in making sure we received them.  I loved the location and the view!! I would opt to stay here again rather than be on the beach in a more expensive hotel any day!
This hotel gives you great value for money. We didn't really spend time in the hotel, so this was perfect. (but wouldn't recommend if you like lounging about in the hotel a lot)

I have no idea how this hotel has the Sheraton name on it. I am a long time SPG guest and am shocked by this hotel. Here is my listThe Parking Garage is 5 levels and has no elevator, hello people bring luggage When checking in I was not given the type of room I wanted and was offered to upgrade to a room I wanted for $20 a night thankfully SPG customer care was able to fix thisThe room, small, VERY out dated, dirtyThe vent in the hall has so much dirt on it I don’t think it has very been cleanedThe water stained wall paper it peeling off the wallThe bathroom floor looks as if it has not been cleaned in a yearThe Bathroom, do not expect a “Heavenly shower” not even close, the tub is plastic and $20 plastic shower head is 4 inches shorter then me (only 5’8’’)While I understand that the price is okay for the area I would not recommend this Hotel but I still love SPG

I stayed at this hotel due to price. The location was very convenient to tons of restaurants and stores. My room had views of both the ocean and the mountain, which was a nice perk. But everything else was very mediocre. My room (especially my bathroom) was in need of a redo. The lobby, hallways, elevators, and everything else was dated from the same out-dated era. Every elevator ride I took was crowded and stopped on as many floors as it needed to fill up. The gym was totally inadequate (too few free weights, too little air conditioning, no mat area for abs, ran out of towels and water, and very limited weight machines). The breakfast buffet had a good mix of healthy options (like omelets and fruit) and less healthy options (like waffles and bacon). The wind was very loud howling past my windows, but it didnt seem to keep me awake. There is only one computer and printer in the entire hotel for printing boarding passes (and no, the front desk wont let you email them from your room to print there). I waited 5-10 minutes to use that computer, only to find that the computer doesnt work for my airline (US Air). Go figure. This hotel was the best cheap option I could find, and I needed to travel on a budget. I got what I paid for.

This hotel is one of the best hotels I have ever stayed in. We stated here many years ago and it just gets better. They have not changed the good things about it and have improved the not so good things. Great helpful staff, fantastic location, great views, comfortable rooms. Reasonably priced. Cant recommend it enough.Classy!

We stayed at this hotel for our honeymoon, on our first visit to Hawaii, and were very impressed with absolutely everything in Waikiki, including our accommodation. This hotel was among the more affordable ones at the time, as all we wanted was a place close to the beach and clean. We were pleasantly surprised that it was *extremely* close to the beach, with a stunning ocean view and literally minutes away from the main street, restaurants and shops. It even had a swimming pool and we got free pineapple every afternoon.:) The room was very decent in size and, most importantly, clean. The complimentary honeymoon champagne was also a nice touch. I would most certainly stay at this hotel again.

My boyfriend and I stayed in a room on the 18th floor. We only paid for a "partial view" room but were pleased to discover we had a room with full ocean view, facing Diamond Head. Would certianly stay there again. The location is excellent - it is across the street from Waikiki beach. Had a mini fridge in the room so we could keep a few things. Very spacious, clean room and bathroom. Good food and service at the hotel restaurants also. Don't have any complaints about this place!
My daughter and I stayed six nights. The location was great. Right in the heart of everything. The bed was wonderful!!! Don't waste money on the dinner buffet, not worth the mone.

we booked at this hotel just for the location. the waikiki beach is a v short walk from the hotel, there are eating places n utility stores just across the road from the hotel. The rooms are basic n do need upgradation. TV is old n the rest of the furniture just functional. some rooms have an excellent view of the sea n also night scape. staff friendly. we did have an overcharge which was immediately rectified by the staff when brought to their notice.overall comfortable n pleasant stay

Travelled with my husband, my sister and brother in law. We had rooms in the Princess Kaiulani wing. We are non smokers and were assigned rooms overlooking the car park which were designated "smoking rooms". The room was shabby with old and worn furnishings. The wallpaper and carpet was worn and stained. The laminate on the bedside tables was peeling off. The plug in the vanity basin and bath was broken in one of the rooms. Noisey at night- esp toilets flushing in adjoining rooms.The safe wasn't exactly secure- We used the safe and it malfunctioned and wouldn't open- security came and broke into it VERY easily, so I don't reccomend you use the safes at this hotel. The nightly buffet on the Pikake Terrace definitely wasn't worth the $32.50 per head.There are plenty of places to eat close by that offer better food and value. Stood in a queue and waited for 30mins to check out as only 2 staff were manning the reception desk.. The hotel is in a great location . Close to the beach and public transport. Thats about the only thing its got going for it..

We went to the Kaiulani for our 25th wedding anniversary. Rented a car and then found out that it was $25 american a night to park in their garage. We were there for two weeks and the second last day had our GPS stolen from our rental car. They left behind a screwdriver and when we suggested it may be one of their employees, they got downright rude and declined responsibility. You would think with paying $350 in parking in two weeks they would provide some security for your car, BUT THEY DON'T. It seems like people from Asia get treated far better and get the nicer accommodations in the high tower. Where Americans and Canadians get the old accommodations!! Don't get taken in by the name "Sheraton" and expect quality!!

We stayed here July 16-20 after booking a package through Hawaiian Airlines. I was nervous after seeing the reviews. I am quite familiar with Waikiki having visited there several times and wanted the location of this hotel but was disturbed by some of the earlier posts. We could not have been happier. Upon check in we were upgraded to a city view room that also gave us an ocean view from the balcony. We had the most comfortable beds we have ever slept on and the room was large with a fridge and, safe and coffee maker. It was clean and quiet. The employees were very pleasant and helpful. I would recommend this hotel to anyone without reservations. We were very happy and loved the location close to restaurants and the International Marketplace, the park and of course Waikiki Beach!!

Overall, nice hotel with a great location in Waikiki. Good rate of about $160 per night (including taxes) for an ocean view room on the 23rd floor (with AAA discount). Food is overpriced for what you get. Breakfast buffet was good, but not worth $23. Lunch menu advertised a burger topped with an onion ring for $14.50, but no onion rings came with it even though later that day I noticed someone getting the burger with it (very minor, but it show the lack of consistency). Dinner buffet was about $32 and was was nothing special to justify this price. The crab legs were small, the habachi steaks were also quite thin and nothing special. Great atmosphere for dining by the pool with a stage with live music in the evening. Room was fine. Balcony was great to sit and look down at Waikiki Beach (it is worth it to try and get an ocean view room). I did not pay for parking, I parked at Kuhio Towers a few blocks a way for $12/night, and it is a public parking lot. They did charge for Internet, which I did not use, for they had 3 computers in the lobby for free to check e-mail and Internet. Also, it was a little noisy at night in my room from the hotel music and street acts below until about 11PM. Overall, this hotel was great, but beware of the extras (food, parking, etc.) that will cost you quite a lot. I would return to this hotel again.

We got a fantastic rate online. The hotel was very nice and located well. We were just across the street from Waikiki beach, right next door to the International Market Place & the King's Village shopping center, and within close walking distance to lots of top notch restaurants. I stayed there 38 years ago and it is just as nice now as it was then.

Best room was the in the high ocean view section of the hotel. I was on the 26th floor and could see spectacular views of the ocean and the city view. Room was very nice and elevators were pretty fast. I went back the next week and stayed in the other part of the hotel on the 6th floor. I was right in the middle near the elevators and could hear them during the night, so I asked to be moved and was the next day with no problem. Hotel staff was very courteous and accommodating with any request I had. Other reviews had said one could use the oceanfront Sheraton Waikiki's pools, etc. but we were told that was a no-no. Would be nice if this Sheraton had a hot tub. Everything else was fantastic and I especially liked the craftspeople who sold their stuff in the lobby. It was about the only way to truly get souvenirs made by locals.

This hotel is dismal. The walk from the parking structure to the lobby is foul. The guests seem like a tremendous inconvenience to the hotel staff. The rooms are small and the hotel needs to be remodeled. We had an early flight out of Honolulu (7am) so we wanted a good night sleep. The room shook with noise until almost midnight. ("Ladies and Gentlemen, put your hands together and MAKE SOME NOISE!" was heard at least 20 times in the night) The street performers might have just as well been in the room with us. Top if off with $25 self parking and you have one of the poorest hotel experiences I have ever had. Perhaps many Waikkii hotels are noisy, but this one seemed excessively so with no redeeming qualities to offset the racket.

My family enjoyed 8 days and 7 nights at the Sheraton Princess Kaiulani. Our room was on the 6th floor on the corner of the building. We had a mountain view, partial Diamond head view and a little view of the Ocean. Our floor was quiet during our stay. The hotel staff was great and accomodated us with our requests in a timely manner. Our room was clean and we used the green option which discounted our breakfast buffet for 2 adults and 2 children to under $20 dollars. I believe most hotels in the area charge premium for services such as phone calls, internet services, the safe and parking, just the price of doing business in beautiful Waikiki. Free internet sevice was available with hardly any wait if any for 15 min incraments. Parking was $25 a night. We parked 5 minutes away for $10 a night. The trip concierge was very accommodating. I believe her name was Marsha. My sons enjoyed the nice sized pool. The pool did close everynight at 7 for the evening entertainment. The hotel is in prime location with everything nearby including the beach.

Just returned after spending 7 nights at the hotel. A wonderful experience. Cannot understand any negative comments from previous reports. Some people just seem to complain at anything. The room (1941 in the main tower) was ideal on a non smoking floor, with a nice side view of the ocean and a beautiful view of the city. Very quiet with no noise at all heard in the room.Room serviced every day and such comfortable beds with a great television.The bar area was really nice with excellent service. Check in was smooth and all documentation was ready for us. The foyer was always full of various local items for sale.

Paid well over $200 for the night, babies crib came with no blankets, 3 local phone calls cost us over $60 Australian and to park the rental car at the hotel an extra $60US and seeing we were there for less than 24 hours... Will never return to Hawaii after the Sheraton experience!

if you read my 5 star review in review in 2006, you should ignore it. It is no longer valid. Hotel has deteriorated since then. I have stayed here in 1983, 1985, 1995, 2005, 2007, and 2010. The last 3 trips have been for 12-15 days each trip. There has been very little work done on this hotel between 2005 and 2010. It is in need of a total refurb. This hotel gives the feel that they are having $ problems. They have cut things like the free weekday newspaper that Sheraton/Starwood SPG Gold members are entitled to have. Gold members are also entitled to free bottled water, here at Princess Kai any longer. What is the purpose of being a gold member, if you don't get the benefits promised?I tried on several occasions while at the hotel to talk to the General Manager, Frederick Orr. He was never in. I wrote him after the recent trip, still not in - no reply! I am planning a trip for 2011, but why would I stay at the Princess Kai? I was hoping that I would be told that a renovation was in the works, and that they would start to live up to their obligations to SPG Gold members. I can only assume that there is no renovations any time soon. I choose to spend no money on non-room expenses. We ate most of our meals at the Ohana East (for breakfast or diner), and the Outrigger. I was quite impressed with the Hula Grill at the Outrigger. Great view. Food was reasonable (for Waikiki)I have witnessed the Princess Kai's decline from 2005 to 2007 to 2010! I am very surprised that Sheraton allows their name on this property. I would compare it to an older Rodeway Inn or Econolodge.

I have just returned from my 5 day vacation staying at this property. I work within the hotel industry myself and was surprised at the lack of attention this property has received for a Starwood property. The bed was the only good thing about the room. The aircon was not sufficient, the shower was terrible as it had no water pressure, the TV was far too small. I chose not to eat at the property and experience the restaurants that are in Waikiki – glad I did.  The only good thing about this property is the location. One block back from the beach and in the centre of town. Would not stay here again unless there are massive changes to the look and feel of the property.

As stated by others the hotel is in a good location. We stayed in the newer tower with a great ocenaview and a satisfactory room with a good bed. The down side is we have been locked out of our room both nights we have been here. The first day we go to our room with bellman and the keys do not work. Go back to front desk and are given new keys that don't work. Call security AND yes he agrees the keys don't work and will call maintenance to work on locks. Later main. arrives and works on lock and we are given new keys that work. Second night after dinner we go to our room and key does not work. Call security and he arrives 20-25 minutes later( two calls) to open our room and he says will take care of the problem with main. It is now the next morning and no one has arrived. .We are prisoners in our room since if we leave our keys don't work. We called again and the response is the same we will send someone. Still waiting.

Stayed 1 night at the Sheraton Princess - I agreed with other the other reviews - great location however the hotel needs reno to be on par as a Starwood Hotel. I had booked a standard room - I didn't arrive until 10:30 pm. Front desk upgraded my room to a partial ocean view room. It seemed like I was stepping back to the late 1990's - the room was very clean however it was very retro... The hotel is extremely busy - with lots of tour groups, etc - so be prepare for it.

I booked this hotel through the Airline booking sytem and my travel agent. The stay was intended as a short recovery stop before the last leg of my journey home.I booked a high level ocean view room. This is what I got. An excellent view of the beach and Diamond Head Point - but not Diamond Head. The room was large and well appointed. The air-conditioning could be adjusted.I agree with othr posters that Sheraton want to charge more than what the traffic will bear for services; especially telephone calls and the restaurants.Locations was excellent. It is the only time I have experienced housekeeping staff who serviced the room while out to breakfast.

we were there for our honeymoon and its what you expect. Its a bit of a walk to the beach, the view was fairly good, the room was on the smaller side, but it was ok~ no big complaints other than charging an arm and a leg for parking, but i guess thats how it is in a touristy downtown city like waikiki!

A clean room, hot shower, close to shops, Everything A-OK for us other than the Concierge all being Space Cadets or Clueless in Honolulu.Denny's and Smorgys right around the corner for food.This 63 year old with a 57 year old girlfriend had a great time.Would return!

This hotel was alright. It wasn't too impressive but was also on the cheaper end of the scale. It is in need of an update. Also do not confuse this sheraton with the more modern "Sheraton Waikiki". As far as I understand there are tiered levels for the rooms you can get. The cheapest ones (where I stayed) are alright but a bit cramped and the hallways are really in need of renovating. It was fairly quiet however and had a big balcony which was nice. Lots of older people and families at this place but it wasn't unfriendly to young people. The pool was nice and the bar there was ok. The location was exceptional. Very close to everything
Was a nice and pleasent hotel, but need a refurbishment for the Sheraton name

We were placed here through a travelzoo package deal. The hotel is located right in the middle of Waikiki and was an incredible value for us. That said, parking is a rip off. I'd advise using the Banyan garage down the street which will save you $15 a day. The service here is great. Both the front desk workers and the housekeepers do a great job and are very personable. There is a nice internet kiosk in the lobby that enables you to check in for your flights. The rooms are small. There is no climate control but the weather in Hawaii is so nice that you don't really need it. The beds are comfortable and the bathrooms have been recently renovated. If you stay here, request to stay in the back of the hotel. The sound from the street and lounge is overpowering in the evening.

Booked via travel agency, I read reviews on this place and was forewarned about the noise.Took earplugs and sleeping aids, but still the noise through the paper thin walls and inter connecting doors was sufficient to disturb me, and the noise from the shopping centre opposite was loud. There is a distinct class difference. Japanese tourists get the tall tower overlooking the ocean, while American and Australian tourists get the low rise, noisier rooms.The bedding was outstandingly comfortable, and totally clean, in fact, all linen was changed daily, excellent. Furniture was old and shabby but clean.Breakfast was first class and reasonably priced, and the entertainment at night by the pool was fantastic.Centrally located to the Markets and Macey's for shopping, and a good Japanese eating establishment across the road make this a good base, but, take the earplugs.

Great hotel for the money. Room was clean, well maintained, big flat screen tv, nice comfortable king sized bed. We had a nice balcony with a partial view of the water. Always ask for the new section. I never saw the rooms in the old section, but I understand they need renovation. The location is excellent. Lots of restaurants and good shopping close by the hotel. The beach is about half a city block away across the street from the hotel. Great music to listen to at pool side in the evening.

Nice property right across the street from the beach. Different buildings provide the feel of being part of a much larger resort.The thing that set this property apart was the personalized attention I received from the staff. In particular, the Front Office Manager went out of his way to be accommodating with respect to a room issue I had and actually bent over backwards to ensure that my stay was nothing short of excellent.Make no mistake about it: this is a BUSY property and the resting place of many airline crews, etc. As such, there is A LOT going on at all times. Given this, I was more than pleasantly surprised by the individual attention I received and the genuine "aloha" spirit that exists there.

This 10th anniversary trip was just more than a celebration of 10 years of marriage, it was a celebration of my own personal survival. We paid for this trip in advance, and checked several times online to make sure our hotel reservations were set. They were. Upon arriving at 2:30 am, we were placed in a room with a double bed, no air conditioning or window to open, musty smelling, right by the clunky elevator that never stopped, and a room I could not walk around the bed with crutches. This is not what we paid for. We paid for a king size bed, room with pool view, small fridge etc. When told that our travel agent placed in the "substandard room", I was upset but too exhausted to deal with it that early with no sleep. Because of the elevator, we ended up going back down to the receptionist and asking what happened and what are they going to do about it? She offered us $20. off per night to upgrade. So, we upgraded. They still charged us for the higher price in the substandared room because it was technically the next day. After talking with several other couples staying in this hotel, 6 out of 10 had the exact same thing happen to them! Beware, this may be a scam is what we all came to the conclusion of what was happening. After being told via email that our room was guarenteed, when we arrived, they said no it wasn't and that is what we were going to be stuck with if we did not upgrade. I will never stay here again.

The hotel is centrally located within walking distance of Waikiki attractions and across the street from the beach. The staff is very accomodating and friendly. I have never stayed at a hotel where the housekeeping staff greeted me by name while passing in the hallway. The hotel is well maintained, and the room and linen were very clean. The only disappointment I had with the rooms is they are NOT sound proof. In the six nights of my stay, I was awaken once at 5:00 a.m. by the guests in the next room. It was not that they were extremely loud, the walls are just too thin - so much so that I could hear their messages as they listened to their voicemail. My room overlooked the pool area. At first, I thought this would be a concern, but the nightly entertainment ended around 9:30 p.m. therefore it was relatively quiet except for occasional noise from the traffic. But who would want to sleep at 9:30 p.m. in Waikiki??? Food was also great! Everyday, local artists are located in the hotel lobby for those who love to shop for island specials. The hotel also offers activities (i.e. pineapple taste testing) in the lobby free of charge. Will I visit again the Sheraton Princess Kaiulani? YES!

My husband and I planned a 12-day trip to Hawaii to celebrate 30 years of wedded bliss! We booked this hotel on Priceline.com (so it was booked sight unseen) and we were moderately concerned when we read the varied reviews. The night we checked in, there was a knock at the door and management had provided a fruit/candy basket for us. How sweet!! The next morning, there was another knock at the door, and ANOTHER fruit/candy basket!! I thought the basket was a very nice touch . . . the second, of course, was a mistake.The lobby area is dignified. . . there is live Hawaiian music at night and free internet access. The pool area is attractive, large, and well maintained. All of the employees we encountered during our stay were helpful and went out of their way to be friendly. The room was on the small side with Ikea-like furniture, but it was attractive, clean and refurbished. We didn't eat at the hotel (two to three times as expensive as their competition) but it is in an area surrounded by great places to dine. It is directly behind the Moana Surfrider . . . it's an awesome location in the center of Waikiki it is just across the street from the beach. . . at $71 a night, what's NOT to like!! Also, if you don't want to rent a car for the first few days, you can take The Bus from the airport--$2.50 per person, but you can only take one standard suit case (I also had a backpack). It will drop you off within 100 feet of the hotel. Such a deal!

I booked a 11 day stay here. My husband & I travel to Waikiki many times per year on business, this was our 1st time at this hotel. We usually stay at the Hyatt, but Sheraton was cheaper and across the street. It was TERRIBLE. We stayed 1 night, canceled the rest of the nights and walked over to the Hyatt. The staff was awful, the room was stuffy & old, the extra charges were expensive and getting service at the pool or poolside restaurant was IMPOSSIBLE (we actually had to get our own food at lunch because the birds were headed towards it just sitting there waiting for a waitress). They lost our Fed Ex, and after telling us over and over that they never received it....."OH, here it is!". Unreal. Live and learn. I read the reviews and chose to ignore them, because 'how bad can it be?'. Well, it was bad. Don't stay here because other reviewers like the location, there are plenty of hotels within walking distance that are great.
Pleasant reception staff, nice airy room with King Bed, close to beach, we weren't disappointed.

This was our first holiday in 15 years, I read the reviews from those who want 5 star plus at budget prices, not phased by them - it's your choice!! We took a package 7 nights and opted for a room upgrade, 8th floor corner room overlooking Kalakuua Avenue and Waikiki beach towards Diamond Head - what an incredible vista!! Yes, she is the Grand Old Lady of Waikiki, a few wrinkles but clean, neat, sweet rooms and we were only there to slurp a few Vodka's on the balcony, sleep and shower. The housekeeping staff were attentive and the room spotless each day. With the corner room we were able to enjoy fresh breezes each day and evening, cool after dark, and the street entertainment below was worth it all. Low speed traffic sounds did not enter the closed balcony door and the entertainment from the pool area was relaxing and unintrusive. Took a hire car and parked at the hotel, reasonable rates given the typical fees on Waikiki, we did get a refund on returning the car a day earlier than expected, at least we were confident the car was nearby and safe. We certainly got value for our limited funds and would return without hesitation. You don't have to eat in the hotel, plenty of reasonably prices eating close by, we chose Smorgy's on Kuho avenue for a number of meals, a good breakfast and dinner sets you up for the day. Very Happy with our stay, those who weren't should just "Hang Loose"!! We'll be back! Aloha.

These people are so focused on screwing their customers, they are really pathetic. The phones cost $1.50 for local calls. The internet costs $14.00 per day. The drinks at the bar near the pool cost $8.50 and the bartender knows exactly how to give you less than a full shot. The buffet costs $30.00 for dinner and is very limited. The rooms are definately from 1970's the fixtures even have the chrome worn off. The mattresses are aout 4 inches thick. They charge you for using the in room safe. They dont even have real coffee mugs in the rooms, paper cups. To add insult to injury it costs $25.00 per day to park. All I can add is never again....

Charming atmosphere...Nice-sized rooms. The beds are perfect. So comfortable.The pool and outdoor area are quite attractive and clean. There's a cute fishpond.The staff is very friendly from the front desk to the valets to the housekeeping staff. They are always happy ot help. The only exception to all this aloha was the rude jerk who "helps" guests make lei - Mike. (According to the front desk, he's not an employee, just some sort of once a week provider.) We tried again a different day (and with a different lei-maker) with much better and friendlier results. This hotel is very near the beach. Some of the rooms have an ocean view, depending on which section you choose. Waikiki is great - beautiful and fun.There is a restaurant on site. Breakfast and lunch there were fine. (We didn't try dinner.)There is music pretty much all the time. Every night, there is live music and hula by the pool.We met several couples who have been coming here every year since their honeymoon 20, 30, or 40 years ago - lots of families on return visits, as well.Downstairs are computers to use for free, which is really good to find in Hawaii (though typical on the mainland).This was a great location and great value.We all plan to return - and are hoping it happens soon.

An average room in Honolulu, the place is very dated-carpet looks about 10-15 yrs old the bathroom is small and looks like from the 70s. The price is decent but don't expect any frills. Front desk staff seem friendly but my entire reason I will not be coming back is due to the cleaning lady. Our scheduled check out time was 2 pm, we left the room and returned at 11:30 am, she had our room blocked with her cart and would not let us in. She went on stating that we couldn't go in because check out is 12, and that someone else is coming to the room...really? Since we haven't even checked out yet? We mentioned we needed to use the restroom and it was still our room until 2 pm, which she responded with "there are restrooms in the lobby!" So....suffice to say, service goes a long way, but disservice goes further and faster. Will not go back again!!

The pictures on the web sites are 30 years old. It USED TO BE nice a long time ago. My room had OLD "early american" furniture. TIny TV. Tiny shower with a 20 year hand wand shower head. Grungy carpet in the halls. Also, Check-in does a bait and switch. I booked a "King-Partial Ocean View" and got 2 double beds over looking a street market. It took an hour of complaining to get the right room. Room safes have a daily fee. AC is ON or OFF; no temp adjustment.
Our band stayed at Princess Kaiulani during our trip and had great services. The rooms were well kept, and so was the rest of the hotel. I'd go back in a heartbeat!

The staff are rude and don't seem to be interested in customers. We were directed to 3 different places to leave our baggage with no offer of help. Showers and bathrooms are old and tired, shower would only shower from chest down. Was told my room was special with a sea view, well yes if you leaned over the balcony and looked sharp left, otherwise a view of the next hotel. Asked for a manager to call me back three times and no call was made. Asked for a cork screw to open a bottle of wine and was told to walk to a local shop and buy one !I am a platinum member of Starwood as well, so I feel really sorry for someone without status !
Location could not be any better, under 5 min walk to the beach, and to everywhere. Staff was amazing, and food was great. Would go back anytime!

We had prebooked two separate three night stays before leaving home, the first three nights were on the 11th floor (ocean view) over looking the pool, the rooms are not soundproof, very noisy, you cant get to sleep until after the entertainment has ceased & then you hear all the street noise from buskers. On our return for our second three night stay we requested a room that did not overlook the pool, we were up on the 26th floor so the noise levels were considerably quieter but then we realised you can hear everything that is going on in the room next door. The hotel is very old & needs updating but is in a great location. We would not stay again.

This hotel is centrally located in the heart of Waikiki and puts pretty much everthing within a few blocks radius. It "could" be one of the best hotels in the City - but it really does need upgrading/renovations as soon as possible/practical. We were quoted $106 per night as BCAA/AAA Members but opted for a partial ocean view at $121 (US) - a decent rate for Waikiki for sure!The entry/lobby pool area are really terrific, oozes "aloha" and feels very welcoming. These areas are clean and vibrant from the concierge desk to the small on-site craft fair (local carvings and jewellery were available each morning/early afternoon) to the poolside restaurant/stage area where Hawaiian entertainment played nightly - adding to the ambiance of the premises.Our experience with the Staff was generally very good. On arrival, we were met by the on-duty Bell Captain who was very friendly, courteous and promptly took charge of our baggage and had it up to our room in about 5 minutes! On the other hand, the fellow who met us at the check-in the desk should probably consider a career change as he seemed lethargic and a bit flippant (this is not typical of most Sheraton hotels that I have stayed in so this below average reception really stood out). That said, all other staff members (including the chamber maids) were friendly and displayed that aloha spirit that we have come to enjoy in Hawaii.We were first checked into the (29-story) Ainahou Tower which is supposedly the newer section of the Hotel. We were on the 16th floor but the noise from the adjacent properties air conditioning was quite noticeable. I had read about early morning street noise but thought being up higher we might avoid this pitfall - I was was wrong. At 5:30 AM the back alleys of Waikiki "come alive" with the sound of big trucks emptying dumpsters in thunderous procession (note some literary licence taken here). This sound reverberates up the buildings and with the single pane windows and we were easily awakened by this and ended-up being moved/upgraded to the the original 11-story Princess Wing with a deluxe ocean view - bonus! This wing has double-glazed windows and if you want to shut out the City noise (which is inevitable in Waikiki) - stay in the Princess Wing for sure.The beds are comfortable and the rooms decently appointed. The vents show signs of wear (visibly discoloured) and there were are some cleanliness issues which results in my "average rating" for this property which would otherwise be much higher. There is a plan (so we were told) to actually build/re-build a brand new Sheraton on this site as it truly is right in the heart of Waikiki with beach access across the street.There is a tour guide desk , a concierge for maps/bus schedules/directions and an ATM in the lobby. The large work-out room on-site is terrific with big screen TVs and modern equipment. The pool looks very nice and is the centre-piece of the Hotel's courtyard/restaurant & entertainment area.The beach, the dining and the shopping are world class and it is no accident that this little piece of urban paradise is such a grand destination (for a differing style of holiday - check out my installment on Maui for comparison). As most travellers to Hawaii soon find out, there are "ABC" convenience stores (a cross between a 7-11 and a gift shop) everywhere and we frequented this for our morning breakfast foodstuffs (fruit, milk & cereal) as well as our beach-lunches of sandwiches, snacks & beverages (they even sell beer, wine & other liquor - for the more adventurous - and the insulated mugs to put them in - hint - hint). All in all, we had a great stay here and I would recommend this hotel if a) you stay in the Princess Wing, or b) you stay in the Ainahou Tower on the side facing Diamond Head.I have attached a couple of photos to whet you appetite.Mahalo & good luck!

We were happy with this hotel. The rooms are average size and in good condition. As in most Waikiki hotels the bathroom was small but still served the purpose. We were in easy walking distance to the beach. The linens are nice and the room was cleaned daily. The beds slept nicely and the pillows were ok. We had a partial ocean view. The only disappointment were the prostitutes that hung around the store next to the hotel. They seemed to show up around 8pm or earlier. They seemed to be on most street corners later in the evening. It is noisy in the evenings and early mornings, but it is a busy place.

All staff are very friendly and helpful. They went out of way to get us a room after we had a look at the absolutely discusting room we had reservations for at the Aqua Waikiki Beachside (filthy, rundown, furniture falling apart and large patches of black mould in the bathroom) - not at all like the advertising photos !!!! Don't know how it stays open - should be condemmed. The Sheraton was very clean and very comfortable and price was good. We stayed for 2 weeks and enjoyed it all. The outdoor evening performances were great. I don't know why some people run it down - but then some people are very hard to please. I would certainly reccommend staying here !

The hotel was clean and had amenities, but the hotel is old and it was a standard room. Nothing special. I didn't spend much time in the room though. If you just want a clean bed at night, it will do.

The people here where so friendly and bent over backwards to make sure we all had fun and never missed any little or large event that was going on.And the pineapple I have never tasted pinaeapple so yummy.You can go yuppy if you want?But the amount of time you spend at the Hotel and in your room why waste your money.SPK as the locals call it has great staff great food a fantastic tour desk.And best of all it is right next door to the International market place and across the road from Waikiki Beach and its sister hotels Sheraton Waikiki, The Royal Hawaiian and Westin Moana Surf rider.And for the shopaholics your eyes are going to bulge out of your head when you see and go to the Al a moana centre. It literally has everything.

The best thing about the hotel is the location, in the center of the tourist area: beach across the street, shops all around, International Market practically next door. Hotel itself is shabby, needs an upgrade. Pool is shockingly bad: the surrounding buildings block the sun so throughout the day, don't seem to get direct sunlight. Chairs are tightly lined together and no floats in the pool (which is not great for families). During the evening there is always an awful band playing poolside and you can't escape their noise in your room. Think its obnoxious to charge $3.25 A DAY for use of the room safe! No Club Level. Front Desk always a line. They do have about 3-4 computers to use in the lobby, which is nice. And the concierge I did find to be very helpful. OH and there was a cockroach and ants in the room!!!! Got the room for $100/day so that helped. Go for the location and if an amazing deal, else keep looking around.

This hotel was a bit rough! The rooms, as mentioned in most reviews, are so dated and worn down. The higher tower is MUCH better, so if you have any option, be sure to stay in those rooms. The bathrooms are especially disappointing...I feel as if the entire hotel banks on the idea that most travelers haven't seen the hotel in person and book it based on the Sheraton name. They know they won't come back to Hawaii often, and so they continue to milk it for all it's worth before the whole thing just falls down or they renovate!However, I have to mention that the staff is FIVE STAR! Everyone was so nice and out of their way helpful. The front desk especially was stellar...I have been in the hotel industry for years and would pay their staff double to come work with me :) Food outlets are great, and the location was fantastic.Bascially, don't expect a 5 Star hawaiian hotel...expect a hotel that is heavily marketed towards the asian market with run down rooms. If you are simply looking for the cheapest hotel...book here!

This hotel is a real dump, despite the Sheraton name. Rooms with dirty green carpeting, furniture that is worn and torn, bathrooms from the 1960's and walls so thin the person snoring in the next room sounded as if they were in my room.I am a Platinum Preferred Guest (highest membership level in Starwood's frequest stay program) and was assigned the best available room at check-in. That did have an ocean view but it was more a horizon view over another hotel with no view of the beach. The room was tiny, smell and worn with two adjoining room doors and immediately in front of the elevator. I called the front desk immediately to get moved because adjoining room doors always mean loud rooms because the noise travels under and through the adjoining doors. Hotel said that was all they could offer since the rest of the rooms were being held for other guests. True to expectation, I was kept awake by the snoring man next door, then right before 5am, he started blasting his TV. I called the front desk to complain and about 5 minutes later, the TV volume was lowered only to be raised again to loud about 30 minutes later. Then, right before 7am, I was awoken again by doors slamming next door and the TV being turned on loud again. To be fair the the other guest, I'm not really sure if the TV volume was turned way up, but it was very loud in my room that I could hear the program very clearly.If the treatment and room I received as a top tier Platinum Member, imagine what your experience at this Waikiki hotel will be. My suggestion is that you try the Hyatt Regency (right across the street), the Marriott Waikiki (two blocks away) or the Hilton Prince Kuhio (four blocks away), but stay away from this dumpy Sheraton.

This had to be one of the worst hotels that I have ever stayed at. I am a self-admitted hotel snob, I enjoy the nicer hotels. But my budget doesn't always allow me to indulge my pleasures, so every once in a while, I am forced by my pocketbook to stay at one of these places. That's not an admission that I knew what I was getting myself into. It was probably my own fault though for not doing my homework on this place. But I figured the price and location would make up for everything else... boy, was I wrong!!I have found that reading through hotel reviews can be difficult without a point of reference, so I will write most of my review as a comparison between this hotel and the Westin Maui Resort and Spa, where we stayed for 3 days prior to staying in Honolulu. Room/Bathroom:The bed was clean at the Princess, with comfortable sheets that seemed to be clean as well. The Air Conditioner panel was simply a knob with a high/low/off setting that did not have the ability to control itself based on any room temperature. This was very annoying, since the night time was warm/cold at times. The in-room safe was large, but could only be used with a $3.50 fee, which was also very annoying. Talk about nickel and diming you all the way through! At the Westin, the AC was temperature controlled and worked very well, the in-room safe was free, and the bed/sheets were also clean. This may be due being on Maui instead of Waikiki, but who knows? The Westin also had a HD TV that was about 40 inches, whereas we had a 26 inch CRT at the Princess. I thought even 3 star hotels had HD TV's?! The patios at both hotels were pretty much the same, with a small table and 2 chairs and similar dimensions/space. An omission from the room at the Princess was a counter/mirror area at the Westin Maui where my fiance would do her makeup or anything she needed. This granite top counter was positioned outside the bathroom, next to the room door. It had enough space in front of the mirror to place all our toiletries, skin care products, blow dryer, etc. The Princess only had a sink and mirror in the bathroom, right next to the stinky toilet. This small difference made a huge comfort difference.Now, onto the bathroom. This was absolutely the turning point for me. The sink ran water that smelled like sewage!! My fiance and I laid down our first night after washing up for bed. We were in bed, winding down, only to find that we could smell a nasty stink on each others' faces. What an absolutely horrible experience, to know that we washed our faces in water that may have come from someone's toilet. The shower water smelled ok, so we had to use the shower faucet for everything the rest of our trip. Hotel Service/Staff:The hotel staff were extremely friendly and helpful for the most part. The concierge was absolutely an idiot, actually, all of the concierges that I ran into at the Princess didn't seem to have much local knowledge. They had knowledge about activities, restaurants, hot spots that I learned after only 2 days of speaking to other tourists!! A simple request for a local korean restaurant and I was told there were not many around and to go to the Waikiki Resort. The restaurant, called Seoul Jung, was absolutely awful with their commercialized food and awful service. I went online to find 4 korean restaurants in the area and one of them was right next door at the international market. Another request I made was for some info on trendy nightlife spots like a club where we could go dancing. The concierge said there were mostly bars around the area, but we should go to the Waikiki Trade Center. I speak to some other tourists and find that there's a popular club called the Level 4 right across the street at the Royal Hawaiian. I also had a big beef with the trip/tour booking person who is located near the concierge. In her quest for some type of credit for booking stuff for her customers, she told me to make sure I go to her in the morning of the Saturday that i wanted to visit the polynesian cultural center. I asked if I could go online or call to book a tour to the PCC instead, but she said no, I must go to her. So i did, only to find that she was sold out. So I ended up calling the PCC and they advised that I could have booked my reservation online during christmas day and ensured a spot. The selfishness... really?!?!Location:What I enjoyed most about this hotel was the location. It was right across the street from Waikiki beach. It wasn't on the beach like the Outrigger, Royal Hawaiian, or Sheraton (much nicer hotels by the way), but it was close enough. The International Marketplace is right next door, which isn't saying too much though. That market has many small stores that sell very similar items. Once you've gone through about 4-5 stores out of the 25 or so, you've pretty much seen them all. We did find a very good Korean restaurant near the opposite end (opposite to Waikiki Beach) of the marketplace called Mikawon. Hotel Lobby & Attractions:Many of the surrounding hotels (such as the Royal Hawaiian, Sheraton, Outrigger Waikiki, and even the Hyatt) had very luxurious lobbies with many stores (including name brand stores) and coffee shops. The Princess, on a scale of 1-10 with those other hotels mentioned being a 10, was a 2. The only reason it wasn't a 1 was because it had a nice, large christmas display in the lobby.The pool is absolutely ridiculous. It's a small oval, who's length you could cover with about 8-10 steps walking alongside it. That's about 25-30 feet in length, with about 10 feet in width. The shallow end was small, about 5 feet by 10 feet, which was particular bad for my fiance since she can't swim. You may not think you need a pool when you're in Hawaii, but you do get tired of swallowing salt water after awhile but still feel the need to be out in the sun. The Westin Maui hotel's pool, but contrast, had no less than 3 different pool areas, with all 3 pool areas having pools that were 4 times the size of the one at Princess. So I guess that would be a total of 12 times more pool area. Seems like an exaggeration, but seriously, it isn't. We walked by the pool at the Sheraton Waikiki and found those pool areas to be like the one at the Westin Maui. Needless to say, I was very disappointed with the Princess Kaiulani. I would not stay here again, nor would I ever recommend this hotel to anyone. I wouldn't wish this place on anyone that I know. I say if you go to Honolulu and stay on Waikiki, then arrange for a stay at one of the nicer hotels. It's a HUGE difference between places such as the Princess Kaiulani and the Sheraton Waikiki or Royal Hawaiian.

This hotel is old. It was built in the 60's and they haven't updated it. The maids seem to try and clean it...but 50 year old bathrooms have 50 years of gunk in the tile and crevices between the walls and the tubs and sinks.The AC is from the 60's also and barely works. You wake up in a cold-clammy sweat as it is a chilled water system that isn't quite chilled, and the fans are anemic and clogged.The bathrooms have no exhaust fans. There is a vent, but it has no draw, so humidity from a shower sets back your room to tropical conditions.Staff- Everyone I ran into was nice. The maids tried, but again 50 year old rooms are tough to keep up. Front desk staff was nice and quick. Pool- A 50 year old pool, no hot tub, and anti-kid rules at the pool. I get that sometimes adults don't want to hear kids playing....but there is no 2nd pool for the kids. The pool attendant was a complete dick and constantly hounded the kids. There is nothing for kids to do.The reason my rooms were free was because I used a bunch of hard-earned Starwood Points from my other stays throughout the year. Where they screw you is on the "fees." Parking is $40 a nite ($25 for hotel guests) and Internet is $25 a nite.
