The location was good, we were there for New Years Eve and could see the main fireworks perfectly from the fire exit! Close to the Cheesecake Factory!!! The pool area was nice, but don't bother eating at the hotel as it is very expensive, horrible food! Wireless in the rooms cost extra which was very annoying. All in all - a good value place to stay.

While the rooms in this hotel have seen better days, the staff come through to make up the difference. Check-in was quick and professional. Housekeeping staff not only did good job cleaning the older rooms in order to make them look the best possible but paid attention to small details and easily accommodated special requests for additional supplies. Management has also done their best by ensuring the beds are comfortable and installing flat panel televisions. Overall great staff, location and basic comfort outweigh the obvious shortcomings of this property.

I too was not expecting much. This was a great value for the location. Yes, the Sheraton on the beach might have been nicer, but we paid considerably less. This is an older property but very well kept. We were upgraded to an ocean view for no cost, and I really enjoyed being able to drink my coffee looking at the water. This is a very busy place with a lot of activity. Everynight they had entertainment by the pool. We did not eat at the hotel, but it looked very good. We found everyone to be very nice.

I read the reviews on the hotel and was kind of skeptical about booking it, but because of the price and the location (right across the street from the wedding reception we were attending), we decided to stay here. We stayed for 6 nights and it was a great time. The service from check in desk to the housekeeping staff was great. Plus they had a variety of free activities at the hotel so you didn't have to go out every day and spend loads of money. Plus the beach is right across the street, so you don't have to travel far to get a nice tan. And if you do do any activities away from the hotel, most of them come right to the front of the hotel to pick you up, another plus!The room was kind of small for a double, but you get a balcony which is a great plus. Our's looked over the pool and the main street in Waikiki which was also a plus. The walls are paper thin, we could hear the guy in the next room snoring each night. Overall, for the price we paid, it was a great value and i would definitely stay there again.

We did a 3 Island hop for our Anniversary last year. Oahu was the last stop before heading home. I spent extra money on the hotels we stayed at on Maui and the Big Island. So to save the budget we stayed at the Princess Kaiulani. I was expecting a "budget" motel and ended up with a gem!!! The Hotel is a bargain for what you get. Upon entering the lobby, you are greeted by a huge portrait of the Princess, and from there on in it only gets better ! The staff was great. Courteous and very friendly. The rooms are not 5 star, but just fine, not all beat up or cheap. The morning Buffet was good. We did the dinner show and I highly recommend it. The show was very good and the performers gave it their all. After the show, some of the cast hang out in the lobby for pictures. My wife had her picture taken with one of the dancers, a young Hawaiian "stud". I haven't seen my wife's smile that big since our Wedding LOL !! Another great thing is the convenience. You are right across the street from the Royal Hawaiian, which is all pink in color and very majestic looking. Very easy to cross the street and get to the beach. Also there is LOTS of shopping close by and within walking distance. If you have the opportunity, I highly recommend the Sheraton Princess Kaiulani.

We stayed at this property for a long weekend in January/February 2009.We immediately had a problem after checkin. I had reserved an ocean view/king bed room. We got an ocean view/2 double bed room. Reservation desk informed me that room request was a "preference" not a guarantee but she did find another room with a king bed -- and an ugly view of the city. So we were basically given the choice of two rooms, neither of which was the one we had reserved. We escalated the complaint to the general manager of the property, and that office gave us the same "preference not a guarantee" song and dance and basically left us with a room that was inferior to the one we had reserved. Too bad for us!I followed up later with Starwood customer service, and it turns out the property was WRONG. A reservation at a Starwood property IS a guarantee, not a preference, and if the property can't accommodate, they are supposed to offer some sort of compensation. This one did not, and as it turns out, they actually lied to me about Starwood's policy. I don't like to do business with liars. Starwood did offer me some points after the fact, so I appreciated that much.As for the hotel itself... the beds and linens were okay, and the view really was spectacular.Everything else was kind of dumpy. The decor had a 70s/80s feel about it. The walls in the public areas and in the room were scuffed beyond belief. The furniture was old and banged up. The wallpaper in the rooms was coming off the wall in my spots.The hotel REALLY needs some investment. I guess until the recent recession, the tourists just kept feeding the cash cow, so the property and its management didn't really care. Well, that's certainly changing -- and I would recommend against staying here in the near future. There are surely better properties in Waikiki.

Hotel is located across the street from the beach and beach access is available through the Westin as well, another Starwood Hotel.We found the staff very friendly, the rooms clean, if a bit dated. Usual great Starwood beds. Very good location and self parking available. Right on the main street so lots of shopping and restaurants nearby. Large and open lobby and many activities for guests. We didn't use the pool. NIghtly entertainment poolside and a different group each evening.

Hotel is over the road from Waikiki Beach but there is a mall/hotel directly opposite so there are only oblique views of the beach itself from the balcony. Or at least there were from our room.The reception area is huge and mixed indoor/outdoor but they had a fantastic gingerbread christmas scene mocked up for the 'holidays'. Never seen anything like it. They also had occasional evening activities in the reception areas eg design (and eat) your own Christmas cookies. Or photo op with santa in beach shorts. Great for the kids.Hawaain Law is a bit weird about alcohol so the bar insists you identify the person you're buying a drink for because you're not allowed to have more than one drink on the go at any one time. Get used to pointing at random women and claiming they're your wife if you want a second drink to go.Buffet breakfasts are outstanding and excellent value. Get to try a few new things as the hotel caters for the masses of Japanese tourists who are taking advantage of the weak dollar. Also get to wonder exactly where the Japanese women got the idea that wearing knee-high white socks with high heels was the epitome of western fashion. And that 'Ugly Betty' is not a look to be emulated.Hotel very handy for designer shops etc. Just leave hotel and turn right. Also, despite their weird laws on 'stacking' drinks they seem to have a far more relaxed attitude to firearms so there are a number of indoor ranges right there above the designer shops. Hammer away on your 9mm or AK47 (seriously) for only a few bucks and a flash of your passport.Kids thought it was fantastic.Staff are excellent and unfailingly friendly and genuine. Almost worth enduring US immigration to visit.Almost. It's been seven years since I last visited and I'd forgotten just what an unpleasant experience entry into the US is. It'll likely be another seven years before I repeat the mistake.

We stayed here for two weekds and absolutely loved it!! The staff was wonderful. They had to switch our hotel room so we were giving flowers, fruit baskets and chololate covered macadian nuts on our bed every Saturday. Our balcony overlooked the pool and we were serenaded by the show every night. The only downside was that the pool closed at 6:00 p.m. due to the show and you had to be 16 to swim without a parent or guardian. I would stay here again in a second.

This hotel has a great location in Waikiki right on Kalakua Ave. It has a normal pool in a setting right there off the street which added a little excitement to sitting by the poolside. The beach is across the street as well. The hotel is older but I found it to be charming. The staff is very friendly and seems to enjoy working there. The rooms are a little worn but are still in good condition. There are some great ocean view rooms on the higher floors of the original tower. The newer tower doesnt face the ocean so the rooms have a views of Diamond Head or Downtown. Overall it is a nice hotel but dont expect a resort.The dinner show in the hotel is excellent. The dinner is has some Luau type food, which was good. The show however was fantastic, the performers were very professional and were a sheer delight. I have seen other types of these performances and this is by far the best that I've seen. Every seat is a good seat, we sat near the back and were fine with that.

Just got back from a wonderful two week 3 Island Hawaiian Honeymoon. We flew into Honolulu because it was cheaper.We booked the High Ocean View-Ocean Promotion for $149 a night during our Honeymoon around Christmas. Best value around for the price and location is great. Stayed for 3 nights, and would not suggest any longer.We were in the tower on floor 20 on diamond head side which is better. If you book it, just call ahead and request it.The buffet smell was so pungent that it reached into the lobby and slapped you in the face. We never ate anything from the hotel. We suggest finding a nice restaurant in Wakiki, money better spent.Parking is $20 bucks a day, although all the hotels get at at least that a day for parking.Overall I would suggest it for a short stay. Great location!

Through hotels.com. I had purchased a HIGH OCEAN VIEW ESCAPE room. The booking agent told me that the room would be located somewhere on the floors numbered in the 20's so that we would be able to see Diamond Head, Waikiki Beach, and a grand view of the ocean. The booking agent also was careful to point out that he could not assign a specific room number but I could be guaranteed a spectacular view because of what I had purchased. However, the hotel placed us on a much lower floor in the single numbers without the Diamond Head View, beach view, and a limited view of the ocean -- even though I presented my written confirmation at the check-in desk specifically stating that the room I purchased was a HIGH OCEAN VIEW ESCAPE location. This was very disappointing that the hotel did not honor my reservation that I had made.

The location was pretty good as the hotel is in the midst of everything, and pretty much across the street from the beach.We stayed in the older part of the hotel and it is ghetto!! We were with a group and some of the other people were in the newer part which was an improvement, but not great, but what you would probably expect for the price. Our room/ wing is BADLY in need of a remodel or tear down. I think the bathroom is literally from 1950... the toilet is the kind that you get at a publlic restroom that you flush with your foot... the bathroom was not clean and it was gross. I did not want to take my sandals off and walk barefoot on the gross floor. The sheets were incredibly scratchy. The tv barely worked-- we constantly had lines and static, also it was an old 19 inch tv. The room was tiny as well. You might think that the room doesn't matter much since you don't go to hawaii to stay in your room... well, we thought the same, but it ended up being really rainy (pouring) for several days so we were stuck inside. The pool is pretty small and closes at 6pm. Parking cost us $200!!!! We didn't eat at the buffet in the hotel-- it was $40/per person and did NOT look worth it.. we instead went to a really nice steakhouse for the same price. Also, there is no spa at the hotel. Overall, I would definitely not recommend this hotel to anyone... I think there are nicer hotels for the same price range. We thought the fact that it is a Sheraton would help and make it nicer... disappointment. The staff seemed pretty friendly though.

For $129 a block from the beach, I have no complaints. The staff was very friendly, and without asking we got our Starwood Gold upgrade to a partial oceanview room. From our balcony we were able to enjoy the nightly live entertainment by the pool.My one complaint about the hotel is the slowness of the elevators. We had a very large group staying in our tower, and we often waited a very long time to ride in a jam-packed elevator.The fitness room is quite large, clean, and with decent equipment. We never ate the breakfast buffet, though it looked quite good, because we walked a couple of blocks to Duke's (on the water) for their excellent $15 buffet. We did eat the dinner buffet ($40) one night during the live show -- average, but we just didn't want to go out and wanted to see the show. You're only a block away from the beach, and we sat in the reserved area for the other Sheratons that are right on the beach. It certainly didn't see worth paying $100 more to avoid a short walk. This hotel is also right next to International Marketplace and lots of other shops and restaurants. Our room was clean and our Sheraton Sweet Sleeper bed wonderful.

We've just booked our third stay at the Princess Kaiulani for the end of December 08.In 2002 for our 40th anniversary we stayed at the Hilton hawaiin village. It was nice but not very special. The staff in the restaurants and at the hotel were not friendly nor particularly helpful.When we booked our next trip, we stayed at the PK and were very pleased with everything. On our second visit, our room was upgraded and we were treated to a surprise bottle of sparkling wine.The entire staff is helpful and friendly. They go out of their way to make you feel welcome.

This hotel was fab! My husband and I are just back from Waikiki after staying for 5 nights here at the Princess Kaiulani. It is centrally located opp Waikiki beach and the staff were very helpul. The hotel was quiet, clean and spacious. We didn't eat in the hotel as it was rather expensive but the food looked gorgeous - we had to pass through the buffet area to get to the lift and the food was diff each night! The hotel had its own travel agent and tours for example to Pearl Harbour could be booked just the day before. The hotel's famous Polynesian Show was brill too. I just can't wait to go back.....

I stayed 4 nights in this hotel for a wedding. Nice hotel, in a great location. Hotel service is pretty responsive. There are better hotels in the same price level if you're looking for a beach view, i.e. the waikiki outrigger. Hotels on this stretch of the island has nicer smoother sand. Sandy down by the hilton, for instance can get pretty grainy. I would not recommend the breakfast buffet here. Go to Duke's across the street in the outrigger.Only con is that there's no wireless, if you need it.

First of all, this was my 7th stay at the PK. The rooms and service have certainly improved. This is a tourist class hotel. Don't be mislead by any website's star rating. It is a solid three at times and a meager two at others, but not a bit more or less. The people who posted the worst pictures paid the least. In an ideal word this shouldn't be, but in the world where we exchange money for services it really is. Even SPG rates it a cat 3 out of highest 7(not five).Don't expect to book the cheapest room on the block in a tourist class hotel in this area of waikiki and expect luxury. If you pay for a standard, expect one. They will usually move you to a better room if they have space to improve your experience. Sign up to be an SPG member beforehand and book through their site, their price guarantee is good. It is a large hotel, something like 1100 rooms, and has varying levels of comfort. There is the tower, 29 floors, sweet sleepers, flat screen tvs. The ocean view odd number rooms don't get much sun, but the even numbered ones do. There are very comfortable suites on the top two floors called 'series 71' and 'series 82'. But there can be housekeeping issues in the suites as well-once, we actually looked up at the ceiling lights over the bed, suite, 2871, and there were giant balls of dust around the lights, The a/c vents were nasty, and mold in the bathroom tile grout. But, in general, basic housekeeping is efficient. I don't think the maids climb up on beds to dust the 10' ceilings. Almost all rooms in this building have some sort of ocean view above the 12th floor. Four elevators generally very quick.There is the middle building, I think 12 floors, which has sweet sleepers, but I don't think flat screens yet. On the highest floors of this building are various suites of varying quality. Here you are directly across from the pool, with a good view of the Westin Moana and an ocean view if you are far enough up. On the backside you are out of luck. You are low to the street and the noise can be brutal, and quite frankly the view stinks. On the city side there are no lanais.And there is the wing on the right of check-in, usually reserved as 'crew' rooms for flight crews and 'bulk group tourist getting the cheapest rate' types. These are your two star rooms which have no sweet sleeper, 12 inch tvs, and even the sinks are on two aluminum stands(you can actually lift the sink up). The housekeeping is generally good because they need the aircrew business. The rooms are old but amazingly efficient with fantastic use of spaces. But this building is really your last choice.I've also heard of something called the annex, with extra cheap rooms, but I've never risked it.Contrary to what some other reviewer posted, there is room service. There just isn't any past 2130. A small pot of coffee adds up to about $9.53 by the time the service fee (17%) and deliver fee ($3) get added on. And the breakfast is a bit expensive by the time you add on coffee and juice. But people order room service for a reason so if you want to splurge-splurge, and don't complain.The prime rib buffet is always good downstairs, but I think it gets a bit expensive for everyday. There is always as much snow crab as one can eat. They always offer a seafood, poultry, and pork option in the buffet. There is always a pasta choice. And it's a good opportunity to try some japanese style salads, sushi(very limited), and tofu's. There is always a good selection of breads. There is a very good selection of fresh locally made deserts. The usual ice cream bar and melon and pineapple choices round out the dinner buffet. There are also a-la-carte options to choose from. There is also the requisite Waikiki hula show, every night.The breakfast buffet is interesting. You can have anything made to order by just asking-they don't tell you this, but I've done it several times. One can also treat oneself to the japanese style breakfast. Most people are the usual bacon and egg type so they pay for the buffet and complain there are no choices and it's not worth the 22 bucks per person. But there aren't many places where one can get 'all you can eat' salmon for breakfast or fermented soy beans with mustard. Momoya can be great, just be prepared for smaller portions. The service is good, it seems to me the same staff have been there for a few years. The prices are reasonable.The pikake lounge. Well, what can I say? Land of leisure suit Larry's and lounge lizards. Kidding. The staff are obviously union and not worried about being fired for customer complaints. They understandably don't remember all their clients, but as a returning client I certainly remember them all. They can be downright rude. I've waited 25 minutes for a server to even acknowledge my presence. And I've had to put up with several of them giving me attitude or just plain non-chalance. The drink qualities are inconsistent, invariably. But then again there have been times where they have been downright fantastic.Hint, if you want to have a few drinks at one of the partner hotels, compare prices for drinks and apps with those at the PK. The menus are the same, but the prices about 20% lower at PK.The front desk staff is there to help. There are times when they can be short, but, in general, they are friendly. They always seem to have a way to help me with my issues. There was a time when the front desk supervisor and a few of the clerks were miserable sods, but they seem to have all moved on to greener pastures. I tend to remember people by name. Good job Sherri, James, June, Shauna. Not so good job new guy working nights(forgetful) and day-girl whose name sounds like the Indian word for tea but slightly different(very short). Always, Always, Always, check your bill before you leave. I had the experience, three years ago, of having them (their accounting department) contact me 7 months after my stay to say they hadn't charged me fully!!! Stick up for yourself, but don't be rude to them, ie realize that although this is your vacation it's their job(tourist class hotel, not five star)The pool is there, always clean, lifeguard on duy, and always colder than the ocean. The towel and chair attendants are always great except the female whose name begins with Y. Never had luck with her. Sign in and out for towels with your room key. Really cool new thing is the ability to sign out beach chairs for the day. These have to be back by 1730 or kept till the next day, but they stop taking them back at 1730 no matter what.The Hotel location is fantastic. The public beaches are right across the street. The Westin, Royal Hawaiian(currently closed for renovation), and Sheraton Waikiki beaches are also available for PK customer use.There is a fee for internet, around $14 and change per day. Tough to find wireless, but if you are on the oceanside of the tower you can pick up the new Apple store's wireless. Or you can sign up with the skywave and have wireless everywhere, it's much cheaper than hotel internet. Forget about using the phones.Overall the hotel is dated and nowhere near the quality of her sisters along the beach. But it is a family friendly hotel. We stay here because we're platinum SPG - thus we can book a low-medium priced room and expect the upgrade, although that's also no guarantee.

I stayed at this hotel for 9 nights and I can't say anything but nice things about it. The hotel is right in the heart of Waikiki, the beach, restaurants and shopping are all walkable. The pool is nice, cleaned every morning, entertainment at the pool every night. I ate at the dinner buffet one night, and it was very good. There are so many restaurants in the area, you can make your choice of just about anything. There is even a Burger King and KFC right across the street for those on a budget or just want something quick. There are also the ABC stores on just about every block that have premade sandwiches or salads, soda and beer, or there is a small grocer one block away. If you have a car, there is a Safeway grocery store not too far.My room was large, I had a regular sized dresser, large closet, large bathroom counter, and a great ocean view (upper floor). Small refrigerator to put your groceries or soda in, and a safe that is an extra charge if you use it. Internet service was high, 14.95/day but you can use one of their stations in the lobby for free, with a 15 minute limit. Just be prepared to wait for one to open. I tried my laptop in the lobby and was only able to get online once and it was very slow, every other time I tried it I couldn't find a free wifi signal.Staff was very friendly and extremely helpful. Dukes in another hotel across the street is the happening place to go day or night, they have a great restaurant too! The International MarketPlace is right next door where there is a small food court, and plenty of shops. I was there for Halloween, I had to work that night and couldn't participate, but the main street was crowded with people in costume until at least 2am. It looked like a good time, but driving was horrible that night, it took me 1.25 hours to get back from somewhere that was 10 minutes away.I travel every week, this was my first time in Hawaii and being a female, alone, I felt very safe in the hotel, parking structure and in the neighborhood walking and driving.

Stayed for three nights and loved every minute.We actually booked a standard room with 2 double beds and was not expecting much at all. When checking in we were advised that we'd been upgraded to a pool view room with king bed.We had room 712 and it was fabulous - great view of the pool, the Moana Surfrider across the street and also some ocean view. The room was tastefully decorated and updated - had the most comfortable (king) bed I've ever slept in. Was like sleeping on a cloud. The room also had a small 2 seater couch, desk, wardrobe with iron and safe (at a charge!), TV and large mini fridge.The bathroom was smallish but lots of towels and shower over bath. The shower had good pressure but when filling the bath the water didn't seem to get hot enough.The lanai had two chairs and a table, which was great to sit out on at night and listen to the music playing from the pool side.We were actually staying as part of our honeymoon, and returning to our room on the second day we had a lovely bottle of sparkling wine waiting for us, which was really nice and thoughtful.The pool is a good size and there are lots of lounge chairs to sit on. The strange thing is that the pool is incredibly deep - starts at a meter and then goes to almost 2 meters deep. the water was over my head after leaving one end of the pool by a meter or so. In otherwords, watch your kids - there is no kids pool either.Lobby was huge and lots of internet stations. The concierge can give you a great little bus route map and the travel desk always seemed busy and not very helpful.Front desk people were always really nice. Checking out was very quick.One thing I would fault is that the in room safe is charged at $3.25 per day! The location is superb - walking distance to anywhere and the bus stop to either the USS Arizona memorial or Hanauma Bay (or anywhere for that matter) is just around the corner.I really liked this hotel - i've stayed at the Moana Surfrider before, and also the Ohana West around the corner. For the room price and location, I was really impressed and would definetly stay again!

For all of you out there curious about the Sheraton Princess Kaiulani here's the scoop.1st: The hotel is in a great location. Beach access is right across the street and everything and anything you could possibly want is within walking distance.2nd: The hotel rooms and elevators are definitely dated. We had to ask to switch rooms because it was so old. And when we opened the "cover" that hid the a/c - ewwww. Can you say dust bunnies? People with allergies would've probably had issues.3rd: The hotel is located right next to the International Marketplace. Which we thought was great (our room was right above it) until nightfall and the stores started playing their music. Some stores blare their music until 12 midnight. The room is definitely not equipped with sound blocking sliding glass doors.4th: This hotel isn't plush. Meaning no spa or room service.All in all the hotel isn't the worst hotel at which one could stay. The staff was friendly and helpful. This hotel would be great for high schoolers on their graduation trip. Not for a couple looking for a romantic vacation.

Just one night here, using my hotel reward points. Pleasantly surprised to get room upgrade to tower block, with good ocean view from balcony. As a hotel though it isn’t anything at all remarkable. Apart from the view it could be almost anywhere, though it is conveniently located a very short walk from the beach. Fridge in room was empty but there are vending machines (with limited choice of soft drinks), though tea and coffee were supplied in room. Breakfast wasn’t all that impressive for the price - continental breakfast didn’t include the usual cold meats and cheese (just some cottage cheese with salad stuff) and choice of pastries and fruit wasn’t that great either. There’s nothing wrong with the hotel, if you want somewhere large and relatively anonymous in a reasonable location and staff were efficient (in my limited dealings with them), but if you’re looking for character maybe look elsewhere.

have just returned from a 12 night stay at the sheraton and cannot agree with the bad comments that are written about this hotel.ROOMSwe had a room on the 10th floor which was a good size and clean. there wasnt any mould in the bathroom clean towels everyday. yes the furniture is dated but it is clean and not falling apart.iron and board ,hair dryer, coffee maker are also in the room. the swimming pool is a nice area to sit round with enough sunbeds to go round. towels are provided.there is nice seating area for lunch and a beer but it is a bit expensive compared to a lot of places in waikiki. the breakfast buffet is very expensive and so is the dinner menu. but you are on holiday plenty of places to go and eat with various priced menus. cheese cake factory is superbthe location of this hotel is superb, right in the middle of waikiki with the beach just across the road. loads of excellant shops with a big shopping centre 15mins away on the bus.you do get a lot of cabin crew including captains staying at the hotel which i see as a good sign when booking a hotel. so if u want a 5 star hotel,go and book the outrigger across the road at twice the price. but if u want a reasonable priced hotel right smack in the middle of everything which is clean and tidy this is the place to stay.

I paid $149 for a ocean view room in the high rise building. location is excellent, convenent to everything. Only a block from Waikiki beach and right next to International market. Room is small, bathroom facility is old, but clean. Buffet is expensive, 39 for dinner and 28 for breakfast. Self parking is $20 per day. Make sure you unload everything before you park your car, because no elevator in the parking construction, the first 3 or 4 levels are always full. Free internet access with computers in the lobby area. Overall speaking, good value in Waikiki area, but don't expect a lot.

Ended up in Oahu at the last minute due to a tropical storm in Cabo. We booked the Sheraton Princess because the location is good and it was a cheap last minute option and we had some starwoods points to go towards the cost of our stay. Let me assure you there is nothing princess about this place. I noticed a lot of older people at the property (60's and 70's) and lots of flight crew. The hotel gave me what they call an upgraded ocean view room in the nicer tower which starts with an A. I would hate to see what the other regular rooms looked like, because the room I was in on the 23rd floor was pretty bad. I will attach some photos. The balcony was good and the bed was decent. There was lots of mold on the bathroom floor under the sink area. I rate the room a 2 and the lobby a 3. They charge $10 per hour for every hour one stays after the check out time. Do not pay more than $129 per night for this hotel. Do not get suckered into the $36.50 breakfast buffet or the $39.50 dinner buffet. You can eat for a third of the price right across the street on the ocean at Dukes. Hamburgers at the pool were $18 each. I don’t mind paying $18 for a good hamburger at the Ritz or a JW Marriott, but at the ghetto Sheraton Princess, give me a break. I think the hotel capitalizes on the older folks who don’t have the ability to leave the property.We did have a pretty good time. The staff was nice. The weather was great. You must get a rental car to do your travels around the island - if not you will start to feel claustrophobic in the city after awhile. 3 nights in Waikki is enough. Stay a few nights in the city and a few nights on north shore. This hotel is fine for college kids or families trying to save money, but don't go to the Sheraton Princess for a romantic trip away.

My heart sank when I stepped into my room at the Princess Kaiulani hotel. My first impression was that I had stepped into one of the deeply discounted hotels I sometimes stay at when backpacking in Asia. The room was small, the furniture somewhat beat up, the cheapo chair under the desk would be perfectly at home in a typical massive conference hall. But after the first negative impression, I found the positives: there was the Sweet Sleeper bed and nice comforter & linens. And the air conditioning unit was nice and loud, which drowned out the music from the bar only a few floors below. And after the sun came up the next day, everything looked different (and a little better). The courtyard was a nice lush green, and the room they had given me (562) actually had the largest lanai (balcony) in the hotel. When I left, I noticed that a little bit of the "International Market" seemed to be spilling into the lobby. Right across from the front desk, there was a long table with ladies and sewing machines sewing pillowcases. And other tables nearby selling various little knickknacks and collectible junk. good:The location of the hotel is great, right in the middle of Waikiki. My room on the 5th floor had biggest lanai (balcony) in the new towerNo fridge in my particular room, but there was a room safe and coffee maker.good & bad:airport shuttle bus can be convenient and cheap (for $9 one way per person), but the hotel is positioned near the end of the Waikiki strip (right before the beach). 3/4ths of the bus can exit before you reach the Kaiulani and by then it's been between an hour & 90 minutes of weaving around Waikiki streets. Taxi ride from the hotel to the airport came out to just under $40. Internet is accessible via wired connections in the room. I saw a sign posted downstairs that stated if you paid for an upgrade, internet would be free. In my non-upgraded case, the rates were: $4.14 for 2 hours, $13.56 for 24 hours, and $67.80 for a full week's access.Half the amenities in our 5th floor room bathroom were of the upgraded "Shine" variety, the other half were of a standard generic variety. The bathroom tiles were stained and the linens were tired (not fluffy). Hair dryer in room (yay!)Hotel appears to be in dire need of a renovation. Posters around the hotel tout shows that might be better suited at a Polynesian themed venue in Vegas, with photos of performers with bad 80's hairstyles. If Vegas style entertainment is your thing, then this is good; if the 80's are a pleasant memory best left as a memory, this may not be so desirable. If you want to watch TV, the one in our non-renovated room seemed tiny (15 inches or less). Perhaps the televisions in rooms on higher floors are larger?badThe beat up furniture in our room wasn't a good balance to the nice bed. I suspect all the rooms in the tower are of the smaller size like the one I was in. I don't think it would be a very comfortable stay for more than 2 people per room (a single room probably couldn't comfortably hold a 3+ person family).A few days prior to our stay, I received an e-mailed offer to pay $75 (per day) for an upgrade to a better class of room. Since we were only staying one night, I declined. The room we ended up being placed into was on the 5th floor of the 29 story Ainahau tower. There are four guest elevators for the Ainahau tower, but the cabs are surprisingly small for the height of the building. If you're put on a lower floor, you might have to wait for a few full elevators to go by before you can step into them with your luggage. Because I was staying on a cheapo rate and because I hadn't paid for an upgrade, it looks like my usually magic SPG Gold card had next-to-no influence here. No SPG guest floor with upgraded amenities, no bottles of water in the room, no robes, etc. I did get two newspapers in front of my door while other occupied rooms got none (so that might've been a SPG benefit). The rate I paid was $129 (before taxes) for my one night stay. Would I stay here again? Maybe for another one night crash pad, but for a longer stay, only if this property invested in a significant renovation.

This was my third stay at this place. In the past, I always though the rooms and the halls could use some massive update/renovations. However, I was able to find a $130/night on Expecia, so I thought "ok, one more time".Upon my checkin, they put me on the 5th floor on the old building (right of the checkin and they claimed it was an upgrade). So instead of a "standard room" they gave me a "city view". Granted, they gave me a king bed, but I heard the traffic every morning around 6am. The hallway carpet and the room were very dilipated. Very old. I had to turn the shower head to massage mode to stop the high-pitch sound.Having said this, this hotel is very centrally located. In the heart of Waikiki Beach and close to hip bars and resturants. Yes, the hooker corner exits. It cracks me up but I coud see older folks being offended.So if you're looking for an ordinary, old hotel that has great value then this could be it. However, if you're looking for a fancier hotel with the frills, this isn't it.

The 1st room we stayed in (5th floor) appeared dated(old) yet clean but the air conditioning didnt work properly. After 2 complaints (including talking to the manager), they upgraded us to the 12th floor with a/c that worked & had a better view. The outside (lobby area) was nicely upkept & the hotel was in a good location. Because of the nightly shows, it did get a bit noisy outside, but it didnt go on all night. The service of the employees was great, but I expected nicer rooms from a Sheraton hotel

Stayed here as part of a honeymoon trip. In a good location but the room was flilthy upon arrival. We requested house keeping to clean which was done. However, there were still alot of mysterious stains on the walls and floor. The furniture was dated (1980's) and the bathroom was small.The location was excellent, we didn't eat from the hotel buffett as it was very overpriced. Try local restuarant The Cheesecake Factory. Lots of shops and the beach in walking distance. Staff were helpful and polite.

Wonderful hotel, plenty of action down in the lobby to keep you entertained. There's live music every night down at the bar by the pool. The hotel also offers free internet lounge in the lobby. We stayed there just before Xmas and they had this whole nativity scene set up from cookies and chocolates alone. Location is conveniently in the centre of Waikiki which is the main hub in Hawaii. Directly opposite famous Waikiki beach which is excellent. Staff is very helpful and cheerful all round.

I've stayed at this hotel several times. It's an older hotel, but is a great value with it's location and clean, decent sized rooms. A new gym has been added on the second floor. It's located on the floor where the meeting rooms are. I think 8 treadmills, 3 ellipticals and 2 bikes. No free weights, but a bunch of machines. The pool scene is unusually crowded since Waikiki Beach is across the beach, but I guess, the crowds on the beach can be daunting. Staff is quite engaging and friendly. Live entertainment nightly. Close to zoo and aquarium. With so many options nearby, I've never eaten here, but people seem to like it and the buffet selection seems quite large. The breakfast seems to cater mostly to the Japanese packaged tourist crowd.

We spent a week of our honeymoon at this hotel and there were good things and bad things!Room:The room was fantastic! We had an high ocean view room with a king bed. It was on the 19th floor and had a fantastic view of the ocean! Room service and maid service were both great!Pool:The pool was gorgeous. There were shady areas as well as sunny areas to relax and the water was a perfect temperature. No complaints here!Beach:Waikiki beach is waikiki beach. If you're looking for a secluded paradise...keep looking! It was crowded! But we would go to the beach in the early morning before the crowds and have a wonderful time. It was basically across the street from the hotel and around a corner. 5 minute walk - max!Service:The hotel staff was great! The concierge gave us tips and advice to get all around the island. The excursions desk booked tours for us. **Many of the tours don't pick up at every hotel...however, PK is right next to one of the big bus stops! For instance if you go to Germaine's Luau, the buses only pick up behind the Hyatt which is next door to the PK. Convenient!Food:We didn't actually eat at the hotel at all. The food was priced similarly to other hotels in the area. There are a lot of good restaurants walking distance from the hotel.Noise:Here is where things go downhill. There was a band that would play by the pool. Great if you're looking for entertainment by the pool. However, our hotel room faced the pool area and it sounded like the band was in the room with us. AND we were on the 19th floor. I ended up buying earplugs. The music would stop around 11pm, but we were early to bed/early to risers. Not very romantic on your honeymoon. The walls were also paper thin. Our neighbours could be heard at all hours of the night.Location:Well...the location is excellent for the most part. Close to the beach, shopping, food, the Zoo, aquarium, etc. However...the locals call the corner next to the hotel "hooker corner". We had a few different tour operators and shuttle drivers tell us this. I didn't notice at first, but once they mentioned it, we did see these girls on the corner. They did not approach my husband, but I did see them approach several men who were either alone or with other males. If you have children, this might be a draw back...but they probably won't even notice!I would go again! I would stay in the exact same room again and not worry about the noise. It is just something to consider if it is a concern for you. Gorgeous hotel! Wonderful time!

We stayed on the 8th floor, Princess Tower. Comparing to the newer building, the room is bigger but the lanai is smaller. It works better for us since we have two kids. If you want a view, definitely ask for 8th floor or above. I'd suggest room x36 or x38 to look out to Waikiki from your room.Although the hotel is outdated, the price and location can't be beat. It's so closed to International Market and Waikiki, we and our kids were able to move idependently. We did not need to drive very often on this vacatoin. Love it!

We just returned from the Sheraton Princess Kaiulani 2 days ago. The room we stayed in was a partial ocean view room. The room was a nice size, 2 full size beds and all the amenities. The local newspaper and Wall Street Journal was delivered daily at our door for our reading pleasure. It is basically a very good family hotel. My 13 year old daughter enjoyed the activities available in the lobby for the children, pineapple tasting, vendors, etc. The beach is directly across the street, the police station is across the street, the International Market place is next door. Me and my daughter enjoyed the bar b que that is held on Saturday evenings, which is open to the public and hotel guest. The plates were $7 a soft drink /bottled water was $1, the bar b que consisted of (2 large pieces of teriyaki chicken, traditional hawaiian pork on top of steamed cabbage, a salad and white rice. In the outdoor pool area there is free entertainment. Its a clean and family oriented hotel. I would definitely recommend it to others singles, families, couples, etc.

The hotel is situated perfectly across the street from Waikiki right on the main road, Kalakua. Although it is right off the main drag, you cannot hear the street noise. Live entertainment every night is great. You can relax by the pool, the bar, or in the restuarant and listen to the music and watch the hula dancing. Everything is very close by, within walking distance from the hotel. The staff at the hotel were all extremely friendly and helpful. The concierge especailly went out of their way to help with directions, bus routes, and taxi cabs. The food in the Pikake Terrace was very good (don't go the buffet, order off the a la carte menu). Room was a good size, clean, and the lanai was perfect to relaxing after a long day of sight- seeing. Only wish that the pool were open later! Do your own research before you go for booking tours to attractions. The travel desk is helpful but their resources are limited to tours that they make comission on selling to you. There are many other tour companies that are cheaper that you can book online on your own. Overall great hotel and would go back in a heart beat!!

The hotel is bad! Do not let the pictures on the website fool you. The view from the "rich peoples" tower is nice, but if you are staying in the main part of the hotel the rooms are ok size, the bathrooms are disgusting, the lobby is classy, but is all mainly outdoors, the pool is good, the elevator is ALWAYS crowded, there are no stairs unless you want the fire alarm to go off. I would recomend it for people who want to stay away from downtown, that is about it.

We were in the princess block - nice room if a little tired but we liked where it was 4th floor. Excellent location for all Waikikis attractions. Very small swimming pool and we could see from our balcony it was not always very clean but you are 2 minutes from the sea so its not important. Very busy hotel but staff very friendly. Like everyone else we filled the fridge from the ABC. Waikiki is a bit like Rodeo Drive meets Benidorm. We used the local bus to visit Pearl Harbour- other tours were expensive but its a holiday! Sheraton travel desk staff were courteous and helpful.Do go over into the Hyatt next door if only to look at the shops! We rented a car- easy and not expensive but the traffic around Honolulu is horrendous. Lovely once you get outside and other drivers are forgiving and polite.

This hotel was decent. It does have a great location for the price. The openess of the hotel lobby area was very nice, and the pool and bar area seemed rather secluded despite being on a main road. The property is definitely "old" looking and in need of some updating, but it was still quaint. The rooms on the courtyard side were a bit noisy in the evening when the band was playing. Overall, I might stay there again, but I would look into other hotels first.

I was staying for one night at this property in their "deluxe ocean view room" on 8F. When I walked into the property, I was pretty much "shocked" how ancient this property is. Its just like one of the hotel from 80s. Everything looks very "tired". From front desk, corridors, rooms, bathrooms... oh mine~ its a very old fashion hotel. I have to agree with other reviewers said, this hotel is nice in its name only. I heard that they are not going to renovation anytime soon thats why the rate is this low for the location. The only thing that I like about this property is their Sheraton Bed. Asides from that, my room is old. (bathroom seems dirty too). Small CRT TV from 90s, Loud AC with crappy controls, no internets in room (not even plug in), u have to paid to use in the lobby's public terminal. The buffet is way overpriced for the price, I recommend to eat in the street behind the hotel or international market place for better value. Would I return to this hotel? maybe, if I am really on a tight budget and I really want to stay in waikiki while earning my stay credit for SPG..otherwise..not really.

We just returned from a wonderful week long vacation in Honolulu and Waikiki beach. We stayed 7 nights at the Princess and had a great experience. All of the desk staff, concierge, bell men, and even tour representatives were friendly and helpful. The room we had was a partial ocean view and was comfortable and convenient. Great restaurants, shopping, and the beach were all within walking distance. We book a number of tours for the days we were and the transportation to these events were literally met across the street at the Hyatt hotel. We would stay at the Princess again if we go to Honolulu again

We just returned from staying at this wonderful hotel. We were there for 4 nights. The Hotel was very clean, the staff very friendly and helpful. I liked that you could do your laundry on site. We sat on the balcony every night and listened to the nightly show that was put on at poolside. By11:30 every night the music stopped. The international market place next door to this Hotel was great. You could get all your gifts bought at this place and you can haggle a bit on the prices.The 15 min. free internet service was nice as well. You can also print your airport boarding passes out at the hotel to make airport check in easier. Everything was in walking distance and loved the hotel pick up to all the tours we took. Airport shuttle was very useful too. You just don't need a car they do it all for you. So this hotel was a good fit for all our needs. And the beach was just across the street. Couldn't ask for more. Very pleased with out stay.

This hotel is in a great location and is a very good value! Great service, friendly staff, nice rooms, nice pool, and very comfortable. This hotel is 2 blocks from the beach and is on the main strip where there is a lot of restaurants and shopping. The only down side is that the hotel restaurant was very expensive. There are plenty of other options nearby (e.g. The Cheesecake Factory, California Pizza Kitchen, etc.).

My wife an I spent a 6 nights at this lovely hotel. After reading some of the prior reviews we were not expecting to be awed by the hotel. We were pleasantly surprised!! The hotel itself was pleasant and well maintained. The hotel room was exactly what we expected too, nothing too fancy but a very reasonably priced place to rest( and a very pretty view from the balcony).The hotel staff was very insightful and helpful. We took advantage of the on site travel/activity coordinator. We obtained wonderful info from this person regarding rental car, luau's, snorkeling.Having gone to this hotel during prime time summer vacation, we were expecting to not find any lounge chairs at the pool. We were again pleasantly surprised, not once did we have any problems finding two seats next to each other. Although it was extremely busy/crowded in town, we did not feel the hotel was overbooked or crowded. Some MAJOR points to note: The hotel offers a hospitality guest room. Basically if your airline happens to fly out late on the day you check out, the hotel offers a complimentary room for you to shower/rest before you head off to the airport. We found this to be invaluable! And all you have to do is ask!If you happen to go to this hotel and are looking for more than just a convenience store(ABC store). There is a "Food Pantry" grocery store located one major street east of the hotel (2370 Kuhio Ave). We happened to stumble upon it after our 3rd day. The prices are much better at this store for things like snacks, bottled water beer, soda, candy, ice cream. It is a full functioning grocery store. Overall we would return to this hotel. The hotel was in great shape, the staff was wonderful, it is right across the street from the beach(3 minute walk). What more could you ask for.

Stayed at the Sheraton PK for 7 nights from 18 June 2008. We were in the high tower initially on the 8th floor but upgraded to a higher floor to get a better ocean view. Room was spacious and had a shower and bath in the bathroom.Didn't eat at the hotel as there are lots of options within walking distance. There is a Denny's if you turn left out of the hotel main entrance and then turn left at the next major street and walk around 200 yards it is on your left. Also there is a cafe if you turn left out of the hotel (on the way to Denny’s) as your approach the man street which does a simple breakfast for $3.95.For dinner we highly recommend the Cheesecake Factory (we ate there twice). The portions are huge and the prices low, especially when you consider you are in Hawaii. Also doing great food is Dukes. We also ate at Nobu as it was our first wedding anniversary. This was pricey (total $240) but worth it for that special meal. Also worth mentioning is PF Changs which is a chain of Chinese restaurants. This was good food and was very cheap too. In terms of tours we did the royal circle island tour which is a full day visiting various sites on ohau including the north shore, pineapple plantation (BTW! the pineapple in Hawaii is the best you will ever taste), look out point from where you can see a large part of the island and a fantastic coconut shrimp place for lunch. Well worth the time and money.We also went to Paradise Cove Luau which was $75 each which sounds a lot for dinner, show and a couple of drinks coupons but it was worth it. If you want to do a luau and get better value you could go to the Polynesian Cultural Centre which also has a series of seven villages that you can see shows and make crafts. The Luau is in the evening. I think the cost of this was $125 but we were put off by the length of the tour 10am and back at 10pm.Waikiki is a really good place and the beach was only a couple of minutes from the hotel. We chose to go to the beach to the left of the hotel and walk about five minutes down the road. It is much less crowded. There is also a Subway, Burger King, McDonalds and an ABC convenience store right across from the beach where we spent our time so it was easy to get something to eat for lunch. The sea was lovely and warm too.To sum up, the Sheraton PK is a mid range hotel in the middle of Waikiki, we were very happy with it and knew it wasn't a five star hotel. We found the staff very helpful and friendly and would stay there again.

The staff did everything I could have asked for, We wanted a non-smoking room, and at check-in, the man put us on the 7th floor of the smaller building (facing the pool)- the whole floor was non-smoking. It was very clean and fit our needs well for 8 nights. Almost everyday, there were activities in the lobby such as making flower leis,quilting,pineapple cutting, that gave it a sense it was a family atmosphere. Its not a glamorous hotel, but it allows families to experience Hawaii that may not be able to stay in more expensive hotels. The location is great to the beach, and is central to the area activities. The food is expensive-we did not eat there. The one thing I didnt care for was the pool closes at 6:30 pm for the outdoor entertainment but heard many hotel pools close early. There was no fitness center but it looked like they were remodeling one. Aside from these minor issues, I was completely satisfied with the lodging this hotel provided. Would not hesitate to stay there again.

My just husband stayed at the PK for a business trip for 2 weeks. I came out to join him for the last week of his trip. I had 3 days to explore by myself because he was at work. I loved the hotel, we were on the 26th floor facing Diamond Head. Our view was spectacular. I had plenty to do and to go see. There a tons of places to eat all around the hotel. I usually got coffee in the morning and walked along the beach and came back to the hotel to hang out by the pool. The staff by the pool were so nice, especially Angie. You can just lay by the pool and have lunch and cocktails brought right to your lounge chair. The hotel and grounds were immaculate. Our room was so clean, the maids really took care of cleaning every corner of the room and balcony. They have fresh plumeria flowers for your hair at the hotel desk every morning. A chef cut fresh pineapple each afternoon for the guests in the lobby. You can get anything your heart desires within walking distance to the hotel. I walked to the Honolulu Zoo and the Aquarium, which isn't to far down the beach. You can rent surf boards across the road at the beach or an go on an outrigger ride. The pool has chairs you can borrow to take to the beach too, that was great! I just loved it there and recommend this hotel to anyone who is out to have a great vacation.

We didn't want to spend too much on a hotel room because we were only there for 1.5 days (2 nights). The hotel "upgraded" us to a partial ocean view room. The Westin across the street completely blocked any chance of our view of the ocean. There was a lot of outside noise (band playing in the courtyard of the hotel) that was directly outside our room. Great location...very close to the beach, shopping/dining is walking distance. The little contact we had with the hotel staff was average.

We stayed here for our first 2 nights in Hawaii after a long flight from New York. The tower is a great location - not on the beach, but if you're only here for a short stay, you probably won't spend too much time on crowded Waikiki Beach anyway. And if the beach is your thing, it's only a block away. We stayed on the 27th floor - get a high floor if you can. The views are spectacular from the balcony. The staff is friendly - easy check in and check out, and the concierge was very helpful in getting dinner reservations at local restaurants for us. This hotel met all expectations, and even exceeded others with how good the breakfest buffet was. I don't think I'd ever spend a significant amount of time in Honolulu - the north side of Oahu and the other islands are really what Hawaii is all about. But for a short stay after a long flight, this hotel is awesome.

The location of the Sheraton was the reason we chose to stay here. I have never stayed in a room that was so loud in my life. Our room was in the newer tower that faced the International Market. Not only could we hear loud music until late into the night, it sounded like we were in the middle of a construction site with dump and delivery trucks showing up at the crack of dawn. Not to mention that we could hear everything going o in the rooms next to us. After the 4th day of no sleep, I went to tell the manager who wouldn't even come out to speak to me and told the front desk clerk that if I wanted to move, I would have to pay more money. I ended up calling their corporate office to complain and the manager called me on my cell phone and told me I could move at no charge. You could still hear noises on the other side of the hotel, but not as loud and the music broke up much earlier at night. There is nothing special about the rooms at all, from what the staff themselves told us, the food was nothing to rave about, so we never did eat there. We did enjoy meeting for drinks by the pool in the evening. They have live entertainment nightly, however, you'll spend plenty of time waiting for cocktail service out there. One night we made the huge mistake of taking in the hotel's comedy show. It was horrific and sooooo not worth the money. I don't know where they dug these people up from, but it was a huge rip off. If you want to use their hotel gym, you have to go to a different Sheraton and pay money. Also, I felt that the $20 a day to park was outrageous, but in all honostly I'm not sure how that compares to other hotels. The conceirge only wanted to make reservations at restaurants where he would benefit from making the call himself. For the almost $1400 we paid for 7 nights...I'd definitely keep looking around. If you feel you'll need sleep at all, you'd be better off staying somewhere else.

The four of us stayed at this Hotel for seven days. The Hotel is upscale, clean and in a great location.. The desk cleak was very kind and helpful. The room was a good size for the four of us, we also enjoyed the pool and spa. The maid service was respectful and charming. We had the best stay.

We had a corporate rate which was $109/night for a double-occupancy non-smoking room facing the pool (room 710). This building is the shorter tower which runs parallel to the ocean.We stayed there for six nights and found the room to be clean and comfortable, but, as many mentioned, there are some issues which may make me decide to stay somewhere else in the future.PROS- Beds very comfortable- Rooms kept very clean- balconies- Very short walk to Waikiki Beach (2 minutes) and the Waikiki 'strip'- Pool area looked nice- Nice Hawaiian music poolside nightlyCONS- NO valet! upon check-in we pulled up to the curb and a tour bus pulled in behind us, the single 'bell boy' rushed to the tour bus and didn't even look at us - we had to unload our bags ourselves and I had to go park my car in a multi-storey parking garage next door which was ALWAYS packed with cars and had no elevator! Plus - i had to pay $20 a day!- Understaffed - not only the lack of valet, but the front-desk staff seemed overworked, the concierge was almost never there or was inundated with Japanese tourists. I was even told on two occasions, "we're short on staff right now"- THIN WALLS - we could hear our neighbors conversations through the vents.- Noisy at times - Waikiki Blvd. gets noisy on any day of the week, especially at peak tourist times. if you are an early sleeper (before 9:30pm) the live music down by the pool is very audible every night!All-in-all, i think we got a great rate, but I would probably pay an extra $20-30/night and stay at the Kaimana Beach hotel which is right on the beach and has very friendly and personable staff and a proper valet!

We were here for 4 nights. Had orginally contacted hotel to ask questions and ended up joining their Starwood Program. Got the room for a decent rate. We upgraded to an Ocean View room. Let me tell you, the view was incredible!!! We were on the top floor, 29, and view was of Waikiki Beach and north and also some city/mountain view. Awesome!Check-in had some problems, though. We arrived early and left bags with bell hop in front of hotel. Went and checked-in in case we could get in early. She went ahead and did all the computer work and told us to come back at 3:00, two hours later. That was fine, we went to Dukes and had lunch. We came back at 3:00 and was told that one of our rooms was ready, but someone must have taken the other room because it now showed as filled. Okay, give us another room......She finally found one,we had requested ajoining room, on the top floor, but the second room would'nt be ready for another 2 hours; it had had a late checkout. We asked that all of our luggage be brought up to the room that was ready. We got half of it. Okay, that's alright, we'll just wait until the other room was ready. She called and said that she had accidentally reset our room key and would need to come down and get a new key. I went down there and asked if the other room was ready. She said it wasn't and offered us drink coupons for their lounge. I went ahead and took them and we all went and sat in the lounge for an hour. Room was finally ready and we went back up to make sure our luggage was there and get ready for the evening. Our room key didn't work! So back downstairs and they reset it again. Worked this time!The rooms were a little "tired", but clean. The beds were incredibly comfortable and pillows nice. We were in the "Ainahou" Tower. Much nicer than the other, older tower.We got 2 papers every morning at our door, complimentary. Because we were Starwood enrolled and stayed 4 nights, the 4th night was free and we got a $100 food coupon for each room. We decided to use that for the Mother's Day Brunch at $40 a person! It was good, but not worth the $40 ,so glad it was free.They had a great show, Creation, A Polynesian Adventure. We would definitely stay here again, but only in the high "A" tower.

We picked the PK as part of our vacation package and the price was reasonable. We stayed in the north tower and could see the Royal Hawaiian hotel from our lanai and a bit of an ocean view. The room was very basic - two queen beds, one chair and a desk with the TV. We were a bit crowded because we also had my 19 month old son's travel playpen with us that was set up between the slider to the lanai and the bed. The furniture itself is old, outdated and in need of replacing. The beds, however, were very nice. Upgraded linens and very comfortable.We did not eat at any of the hotel restaurants because it was kind of pricey. We did sit out and listen to the entertainment by the pool one night and have a few drinks. Nice atmosphere. Can't beat the weather in May.The tower we stayed in only offered dial-up internet connection and it was spotty. The in-room safes did say there was a daily charge for use, but we called the front desk to ask because literature in the room said the safes were available free of charge. The front desk said they don't charge anymore, it's an old sign, but we double checked at the end of our stay and there wasn't a charge, so we were pleased.Other than that, the hotel was perfect for our stay and met our expectations. The location, of course, is beautiful and exactly how mentioned in many of the reviews here. We had no problems here and would stay again!

A friend and I stayed at the PK on our first trip to Oahu in Feb 2008. We were originally booked for a city view room but arrived late on our check-in date and were bumped up to an ocean view room. The view from the balcony on one of the highest floors made this a much better hotel experience! Otherwise, we would not have had a view overlooking the gorgeous Waikiki beach! The hotel has a great location a block off the beach. It is walking distance to many great restaurants (try Duke's!!!), shops, and the bus stops. We did not rent a car here and did not need one. The hotel has a small outdoor pool but we didn't mind as the beach is almost right across the street! The front desk staff were extremely courteous and helpful. The hotel has a delicious buffet breakfast which we loved, especially with the outdoor patio tables, but we weren't as crazy about the dinner even thought it was much more expensive. The hotel grounds were beautiful. Overall, a very nice, clean hotel-- if you can get a room on a higher-up floor, I would definitely recommend! The view is more than worth it :)

My wife was attending a conference at the Honolulu convention center, and we booked at this Sheraton basically due to the price and reasonable location. (It is not close to the convention center, but this conference was running a shuttle between the hotels. It would be about a 20 minute walk to the convention center.)I don't have anything really bad to say about it, but I don't have anything really good to say either. The location is very convenient to Waikiki Beach, shopping and dining. The hotel itself is a pretty basic business type hotel. It is across the street from the beach. From our balcony, we could see a sliver of ocean between the other hotels closer to the beach. The rooms were clean and the staff was polite. The main negative I'd say is that they really seem to nickel and dime you for everything. For a business oriented hotel that was about $175 a night, charging for WiFi seemed stingy to me. There were some public internet terminals in the lobby, but they were usually occupied, and it's just not the same as being able to use your laptop.What seemed even more ridiculous was the $3/day charge to use THE ROOM SAFE. There's just no excuse for that. I have stayed in hotels before where you had to pay for internet access, but never for the safe. That just strikes me as gouging, and I socked away my valuables in the sock drawer instead of playing along. I would not stay here again unless I had Sheraton points to cash in, or all other affordable hotels were booked up. We attended a couple of functions at the Hilton Hawaiian Village and it was much nicer for only slightly more per night. Based on talks with other people from the convention, if we did it again, we would stay at the Hilton Hawaiian Village, Ala Moana, or Westin Moana Surfrider (although the Westin would likely have been out of our price range)It's not bad... but there are better choices. If you get a good deal on it, it's a decent home base to do things around Hawaii, but you will not find yourself spending time on the hotel grounds like you might at the Hilton or Westin which have their own beach areas.(Parking was $20/day which did not seem unreasonable for the middle of Honolulu.)

My Family and I stayed here for 15 nights without any problem what so ever and 15 nights is quite a long time!!... I chose the cheapest website with the cheapest rate, upon arrival we were upgraded several times to a room with a pool view (nice in the evening with every night a hula band by the pool) The hotel is a little tired looking in parts but not the communal areas...i get the feeling if your not happy about something, they will attempt to do something about it like moving you're room. The pool area is immaculate and will give you towels to take to the beach... Which is just a 2/3 minute walk away, Its also close to bus stops, shops, car rentals in fact anything you could really need... I had one lunch time snack around the pool which was ok, didn't eat much there though.The room was cleaned very well every day and all the staff seemed fine... I dont know how anyone can hate this place, for the money some places charge in waikiki, this is a bargain... In simple terms, this is a better hotel than the price suggests... I would stay here again no problem... In fact i probably will...

The hotel offers very basic rooms but quite comfortable. It is located quite central. You can easily reach the beach and shopping area. The staff in the hotel polite but give wrong information. You have to pay 20$ per night for car park. The staff suggested us free parking area, which later on cost us 180$ because of the tow-away area. He didn't informed us about that and the singes are quite small. Beware!

I found a great rate for this hotel ($129/night) and decided to take a chance. I was considering this or the Ohana and ended up choosing this one because of the pool area and the fact that I could tell that it was directly across the street from the Moana Surfrider. Although the hotel is not one of the new luxury hotels it ended up being a great choice. The location is excellent. We were given room 718 which overlooks the pool and even offers a small view of the ocean. (nonsmoking and king bed as requested) While the room decor itself was fairly old fashioned and basic, it did have a small balcony overlooking the pool and the nightly entertainment. There is a small stage and local bands provide music nightly until 9:30. The weather was perfect for sitting on our balcony and listening to the music. Very pleasant. The room comes with a small tv but we never even turned it on. There is a small fridge, a inroom coffee maker, an iron and ironing board, and a hair dryer. The bed was comfortable and when we called and asked for a lighter blanket and foam pillows they arrived in less than 30 minutes. If you like granite countertops and brand new furniture you might not be happy with the room but we were fine it. We brought our own laptop and verizon internet connections but did think it odd that the hotel doesn't offer free wi-fi. They also charge for the inroom safe which we didn't use. One of the best things about the place is the location. It is right in the middle of the best part of Waikiki (IMHO) Plus we were extremely happy with our view of the pool. The hotel was reasonably quiet and everyone was very friendly and helpful. We would stay here again if we could get the same room and the same price.

I love this place. This is my third stay. Room 918 in the main tower is my favorite!! While compared to other hotels, some will say it is 'older' in appearance, but it includes all the amenities I needed. Only complaint is no wireless in the main tower. Although I was able to get it from the Hyatt T-mobile signal though while sitting on my lanai. Location, location. Awesome pool. Fresh pineapple in the afternoons, chair rentals, towels. Great sister properties. I used the gym down at the Sheraton Waikiki and also the beach chairs/area over at the Moana Surfrider. It is a short walk to EVERYTHING!I can't say much more great things about this place. For those that complain, I think they might be expecting more for the $140/night price tag. Unfortunately you have to pay a LOT more in Hawaii for those luxuries, but I can say as an avid traveler I am quite pleased with all this hotel has to offer.

Frankly I am shocked to read ANY positive reviews of this hotel on trip advisor. Unfortunately, we read them and booked at the PK partly due to these reviews, and we were extremely disappointed. Maybe our expectations were just too high, having stayed at nicer hotels in the past.To say that the PK is old and run down is understating the truth. If you want a hotel that is clean, new, nice, modern; Then this is not your place. Our arrival in their drive up area was greeted by a mob of people also arriving, but not a single solitary valet, and not a single, solitary bellman. I was finally told that they don't valet, and told to pull around back to their self-parking garage. For the privilege of parking my own car in their dilapidated, crowded garage that has NO ELEVATOR in it, I was CHARGED AN ADDITIONAL $20 A DAY. So if you plan to have a rental car, factor that into your costs.Our "ocean view" room on the 19th floor (also paid $50 more a night for the ocean view) was a view of buildings, but if you walked out on the crumbling deck and looked 90 degrees to the right, you had a ocean view, so I guess that counts. The elevators to get to the 19th floor were always crowded and slow, and stopped on the 12th floor (with no passengers waiting) every single time you went down.The lobby and pool area were a constant area of activity, and the free pineapple was a nice touch, especially when waiting in the lengthy lines to check in and check out. The TV checkout system doesn't work, and the business center computers are nice in that they are complimentary, but not nice in that they are not connected to any printers, so you can't print boarding passes or anything like that.The hallways, corridors, carpet, EVERYTHING, has a musty 1960's, run down feel to it. Sheraton/Westin have 3 other properties within walking distance and all of them, especially the Sheraton Waikiki just down the way, are nicer and classier. The PK is obviously the poor stepchild of the rest and they have not put a dime into the place in 30 years, I guarantee that. The room was a joke. Standard size, old furniture. I didn't know they still made color TV's as small as the one in this room, it was like 10 inches, in a terrible old cabinet. The bed was actually fairly new it seemed and comfortable, but the A/C worked very poorly. I called maintenance about it after the first night and was told they would look at it. Not sure if they did, but it did not improve. The bathroom was dingy and the tile and counters were old, old, old. The whole place is badly in need of a makeover, or the wrecking ball.We also booked on a package where we were offered $100 "dining credit" for any of the restaurants in this hotel or the sister properties. We had 2 great meals at Rum Fire, at the OTHER Sheraton, only to find out when we checked out, that the $100 was for "food only". No drinks, none of the tax, nothing but purely food was covered, so we didn't even make it to $100 on our stay. What a scam! This was nowhere in the fine print, but what can you do at this point?

We stayed a week from Apr. 11 - 18th and enjoyed the hotel because:1) Great location - heart of Waikiki and close to shops, eateries and car rentals and tour pick-ups. The beach is a few minutes away and just across the street. Also close to bus services.2) Rooms were clean and a good size. We stayed in a high ocean view room (on the side which does not face the pool where there is nightly entertainment and hence may be noisier). Our ocean view was limited however, as there were so many high rises on the beach front which stood in the way. 3) Free pineapple between 2 and 3 pm and if your plane is late, there is a hospital room which you can use for an hour (after you've checked out). Allows you to shower and clean up before hopping on the plane.4) There are free computers (about 4 working stations). The key is to go really late at night or in the middle of the day when most people are out. I think you could also hook up your own laptop if you decide to bring one along.We would stay there again for sure.

Just got back from a short stay at the PK. It was great. We loved how close to everything it was never a shortage of things to do. The staff was friendly and helpfull in recomend places to eat and helping with reservations. The beverage service was slow by the pool but everything is a little slower in hawaii. Overall great experience.

I had a group booked to stay at the Sheraton Princess Kaiulani in March 2008. I was a little concerned after reading some of the comments on tripadvisor. There were negative comments about the rooms and staff. I decided to go there with an open mind. ( Last year when I escorted a group to a hotel in the Dominican Republic there were terrible comments and I was pleasantly suprised when I arrived. ) I was also suprised this time. Upon arrival, I went to the front desk to get the room keys for the group. All the rooms were ready and were assigned with the requests that I had asked for. All the rooms were clean and had balconies. The restaurant and bar staff were friendly. The pool was open and easily accesible. The location is great. Right in the heart of Waikiki Beach. The group department was also very helpful and friently. I would not hesitate to book this hotel again for myself or another group.

We originally were booked in a small room that had a water view, nice room but too small with 3 teenagers. The front desk moved us to a suite on the 11th floor for a small upgrade. Weird shaped room but big, excellent water view and huge lanai. Very quiet. A few problems getting extra towels promptly but no complaints. Fantastic sitting room on that floor. We had a great time, the location was so convenient to everything. Only complaint, the pool was so cold! Too refreshing, even for the kids. We would definitely stay again.

Aloha! My first stay with PK was back in 2005 and its a hotel that we keep going back to. (I'm returning again in a few weeks time for my fourth time. Once you've been to hawaii its very easy to keep going back time and time again). Waikiki Beach is one of my favourite places in the world. The food, the beach, the people, Diamond Head the massive volcano crater at the end of the beach... theres nothing like it. ME:To set the scene Im what you could call a "value" traveller... certainly not a budget traveller but I like to see my money go a long way. My first stay at the PK was arranged by my partner but the subsequent few stays by me. I'm 28 and my other half is 36 we're from Sydney. BOOKING:Tip One: After paying a travel agent a nice commission the first time around, we now always book online direct with the hotel . You'll find some of the best rates rather than having to search and AAA members can sometimes get better rates. I've only stayed partial and ocean view in the past - good to escape any street level noise. ARRIVAL:Tip Two: outside the airport the HNL airport you can get a shuttle to the hotels in waikiki.
