The shuttle comes regularly and is about 12 bucks or so. During our last trip we got stuck in traffic for a while so may be a better alternative than having the meter in a taxi clicking over. My first experience with PK was like a few other reviewers arriving on an morning flight from Sydney. Being excited about going on holiday didnt sleep much during the over night flight and really wanted to have a rest but our room wasnt ready. Check-in is around 3. So you dont have to go rummaging through your luggage in the reception take some summer/beach clothes (and sunblock) in your hand luggage. Dont worry if you've forgotten anything though... Honolulu is covered with ABC stores - (A Hawaiian institution that sell everything you need for a hawaiian holiday - its easy to become a fan! I guarantee you'll be visiting just about everyday for one thing or another) There are a couple across the road from the hotel. They also sell Washing Powder and fabric softener if you want to use the coin operated laundry in the hotel. ROOM:When our room was finally ready on our first stay, we received a complimentary upgrade to a higher room (very happy about that! ) Staying in Sheraton before I had reasonable expectations about the room but can say was a bit shocked when I stepped in. More fool me for not reading up first. The decor is "Classic Hawaiian" (classic as in hasn't been updated in a long time).The rooms are clean and tidy. If you come with this expectation it wont be a shock! Quite frankly it really didn't matter once I saw the view. PK is one hotel back from the beach (behind the Moana Surfrider) but towers over it. The views were stunning. I'll try and attach a pic or twoAfter familiarising yourself with Honolulu you realise the location of the PK is what makes it and is one of the biggest reasons we keep going back, its so central that you dont have to spend all of your time walking long distances and it comes at a reasonable price. The last time we stayed they had added complimentary internet access in the lobby. Accessing online banking and flight info was so much easier than having to use in-room internet or having to go looking for an internet cafe. STAFFThe staff at PK are very helpful the concierge can certainly give you all the tips on things to do.EATING:There are plenty of places around where you can get food if you dont want to eat the buffet in the hotel. If breakfast isnt included in your room rate it is much cheaper to eat out. We discovered a place called 'The Cheesecake Factory' nearby. This place is heaven for food lovers. Australia has nothing like it but they have a few other restaurants throughout the states. You cannot go to honolulu and not eat here, the menu and the food is amazing I cannot recommend it highly enough. But be prepared to wait during peak times it is tremendously busy. Appetizer or Entree size is the same size as an Australian Main so dont over order. POOL SCENEIn the afternoon when you are tired of the beach, the hotel has a great pool area. The tiles are hot so remember your flip flops (they are thongs if you are an Aussie) A great place to relax in hte afternoon.. make some friends over a couple of Mai Tai's (the delicious local cocktail - yum). THINGS TO DO: We had an amazing experience a couple of days into our first stay. For a couple of dollars we bought inflatable Lilo mattresses from the ABC store and were floating around in the surf at the beach across the road (getting a hawaiian tan) when a woman on a nearby shrieked ... it took a couple of seconds before I realised that she wasnt getting eaten by a shark... it was a half a dozen giant sea turtles were feeding around us.. and this is at one of the busiest parts of the beach, directly across the road from the hotel. Relaxing in the sun in the aqua blue warm hawaiian waters. You cant get better.. Tip Three: you can have your mattress inflated at the ABC store or to save the hassle there is a guy who sells them already inflated in the beach access lane next to the Royal Hawaiian.)CAR: If you have a hire car there is a parking station attached to the hotel. If you hire a car you can go to:The Arizona memorial - Pearl HarbourNorth Shore - be mindful that there are a ridiculous amount of rental car break-ins on the north shore. The Waikele Outlets - Diamond Head- You can walk to the top of the massive crater at the end of waikiki beach, amazing views, not for the faint hearted some of the stairs on the trail are almost vertical!SHOPPINGThe Ala Moana shopping centre .. not far from the hotel you can jump on the Pink Trolley (open air bus) which will take to you to the Ala Moana Shopping Centre. Its 2 bucks a ride. I think I could live here... shoppers heaven. Waikele outlets - best to get there by hire car, that way you can leave when you've had enough, if you book a tour you have to return at a certain time. Print down a voucher online and pick up a book from the info desk for some great discounts. Stay at PK for the location, the hotel itself is a bit dated but with so much to do in you wont be spending a lot of time there anyhow!

Thank-you to Sheraton Princess Kauilani for giving us a find end to our 10th year anniversary celebration. We spent seven days on a cruise through Hawaii and were happy to settle down for three nights. Only one sore spot, when we arrived there was a long lineup at the Check-in-Counter and were told the rooms would not be available until later in the afternoon. After approximately thirty minute wait, I found out this information and asked to be upgraded. They were able to accomodate our request for a little extra. They should have informed everyone earlier due to the fact there was a number of older people in the lineup. We were happy with our room and spent our time enjoying the pool. We explored the sites of Oahu and were satisfied with our surroundings. Our room faced the pool and each night we were treated to music from the poolside. My wife and I enjoyed this sitting back enjoying a cocktail while listening to the sweet sounds of Hawaii. We would return to this hotel - due to the proximity of the hotel to dining and shopping in the area. Thanks for everything - we'll be back one day!!!!

I guess I might of had higher expectations than I should have to begin with. The hotel is in a fine location (although not right on the beach, it is walking distance to a lot of shopping and eating), the lobby was nice...but that was it. I got there pretty late, so I was tired and hungry - sorry room service ends at 9pm. Mini-bar with snacks? Nope. Vending machine? Nope. Try the ABC market across the street. It was a little irritating that one HAS to leave to hotel for a snack after 9pm. Okay - I get off the elevator and the first thing I see is the "Starwood Preferred Guest Floor" sign, I immediately think that this actually means something...wrong again. The floor was filthy as were the walls in the hall way. I got to my room and it had a balcony - staring at 4 other buildings/hotels. I do realize that I didn't book an ocean view room - but I guess I expected that the city view room would have a view of the city - and not be 25 feet away from the hotel next door. After getting in bed - I think I realized that the best part of this short three day business trip to Honolulu would be the comfy bed. Although I didn't hear it the first night, on the second and third nights, the faucet in the bath tub dripped all night long. The last morning I decided to go down stairs to try the breakfast buffet. I was okay - nothing spectacular - but acceptable. I ate and proceeded to the check out counter - because I was tired of waiting around for the waitress to take my check - what a mistake that was. The cashier was sooo mean. Everyone that approached her got their heads bitten off...you are better off waiting for the waitress.To wrap up - The PK Hotel wasn't the worst hotel I have stayed at, but I definitely left feeling dissapointed after so many wonderful experiences at Starwood hotels.Side note: I think that was my first and last time to Honolulu. Not because of the Sheraton PK - but because Honolulu has got to be the worst place in Hawaii. I have been to Maui and the Big Island several times each, and I guess I was just spoiled by their natural beauty and lack of sooooo many people and traffic.

Generally a good experience with helpful staff. The room was a bit tired with the wallpaper starting to peel.Situated only 1 block away from the beach and the side entrance leading directly to the main shopping street.Breakfast was a buffet with seating in the open air under sunshades. The food was good and plentiful with a chef available for Omelettes etc.Main problem was that when people had finished their breakfast and left the table if any food scraps had been left on their plates then pigeons would descend.The employment of a bird of prey handler would do wonders.

From beginning to end our stay was perfect. Don't believe all the terrible reviews. We were immediately upgraded to a Deluxe Oceanview room, Champagne on ice when we arrived, greeted by Leis from Ben the front desk agent at 11pm. Service was phenomenal, location was perfect, food was fantastic, pool was large and immaculately kept. The rooms are a bit dated, but they are extremely clean and comfortable. They offer beach chairs, towels and beach mats and the beach is less than 100 feet across the street. The best vacation we have ever had!!!

We stayed in this hotel last September for a few nights and surprised to read the poor reports .Unfortunately arrived early in morning from a flight from Australia and found we had to wait for a room as was not available till 3pm the reception desk was most helpful and eventually we got settled in .The room was pleasant and clean an added bonus a balcony with a good view .The beds were a luxury .Ok I agree the rooms are outdated but more than adequate .The lobby was spacious with atmosphere also booked a trip there which was very good .The staff all friendly and helpful. For the price and a good location I still don’t understand seeing so many negative reports.

This hotel is in the perfect location in Waikiki, close to shopping and the beach, and lots of restaurants with in walking distance. I guess we lucked out because our stay was extremely pleasant. You have numerous restaurants in walking distance if you wanted something more reasonably priced than the hotel restaurants. Lots of variety, at all levels of price. We stayed here during Pro Bowl and lots of pro bowl activities right around this location, lots of fun! Our rooms were great, super ocean and pool view, comfortable beds! Others said that noise was an issue in the evening but we were so tired that it did not bother us, 2 Adults, 3 children and it did not go on too late anyway 930-10PM. Pineapple in the afternoon was a nice touch in the lobby. Only things negative that I can think of is Hotel parking was a little expensive, but hey what isn't in Hawaii? Bathrooms in rooms were definately out dated but clean and I didn't go to Hawaii for the bathrooms! All staff were nice to us and very helpful! You really could get away without a car here if you wanted, so close to everything. We did have a vehicle as one of us has mobility challenges. We would definately stay here again!

I stayed at the Sheraton Princess Kaiulani from 2/7-2/12/08 to attend a family member's wedding and I was very disappointed with the overall experience. We basically received a room that was not as described in the original reservation and the only accommodation the hotel had available was for an upgrade which we had to pay for. The only explanation the front desk could give us was that all basic rooms are described as a "Cityview room with balcony etc." and that a "Cityside room" which is much smaller with no balcony can also be described as such. I feel this is very deceptive and we would not have stayed there if given that option. We actually had reservations at another hotel but cancelled because we thought we were getting a certain level of accommodations. In addition we had no problems corresponding with the group reservations agent Keri Shiramizu prior to our arrival but after we arrived she did not respond to a voicemail or email regarding the room situation. Overall we had a terrible experience with this hotel and will never stay here again.

In 2003, 2004 and 2006 we stayed at the ohana waikiki west and in 2007 across the street at the miramar, so we have seen different hotels. This yr was our 40th anniversary so thought we would stay in a little swankier place. What a disappointment. Like all the bad things the other reviewers wrote Id have to double it. First we are smokers, ya I know, and had requested a smoking room, which we got if we would have arrived on Sunday as planned but due to flooding on the big island we went to waikiki on Friday and conviently they had no smoking rooms but we sure could upgrade and get one. ( other hotel reviews on here people write all the time about a free upgrade) for a price. Thought maybe since it was our 40th they would give us one HUH they sure did for $25 a night (5 nights) so we took it. Got to the room and as one reviewer on here said what a disappointment that isnt the word. For what you are paying the room wasnt as nice as the ohana west and for twice the price. The wallpaper was coming loose from the wall in many places, if you looked where the floor met the walls, there was dirt and waste and the bathroom tile floor was a mess, grout was all dirty and corners dirty, the toliet was sitting on the floor at a angle and when you sat on it you thought that you had to hold on so you didnt fall off, There are no dressers just a small set of drawers not enough for one person in the closet, also in the closet was 2 bottles of water with the ice bucket the bottles had a sign on them only $4.25 each comeon high priced room and you have to pay $4.25 for a dollar bottle of water?? Your morning coffee isnt free either in the room, our coffee maker was screwed up open the lid to pour the water in and the hinges were broke so you had the lid in your hand, after the coffee was made there was no way you could remove the pot without opening the filter basket and the same trying to put the pot away. The mattresses have seen there better day and thought that I was going to fall out of bed several times the center is higher then the sides,. Unfriendly very unfriendly staff EXCEPT for the maids and bells very nice people, we went back to the room one day to put some purchases away and the maid was in the room. We told her what we wanted to do and she stopped her work moved the vacuum out in the hallway asked for our room key and shut the door and then used our key to open it, you dont find that at many hotels!!!!! Maid was very security minded. Now the good parts Location Location Location and when we upgraded it was called a ocean view room which it kind of was, you could see the ocean if you stood at the lanai railing but not if you sat in the chairs and the sun set between two hotels and it was very nice. Every day between 2 and 3 they give away free slices of pineapple in the lobby and they have 5 computers with internet that you can use for free. Have to wait your turn and sometimes that was 30 or 40 minutes. So for our 6th trip you can bet we wont be staying at the SPK I could write more but dont want to take up your time as I think you get the point, IT'S NOT WORTH THE MONEY!!!!!!!!

We just returned home from staying 10 nights at the Sheraton Princess and have to admit, although it was an amazing location, we would never stay there again!!!!!!!! After our early morning flight there coming from the winter cold, we were expecting warm greetings when we arrived........ I mean, you would think the guest services could at least have a smile on their face when they say "Aloha"!? Instead, it almost seemed like we were just a complete hassle when we asked any form of question at all, nice, really nice:) So, we went about checking in and went up to our rooms to see how they were, and quite honestly it was a disappointment when we opened the door and realized we were paying a ridiculous amount for a VERY AVERAGE room:) Now, one thing I do have to admit, besides the awesome location, we did have an amazing view:) The next morning we thought it would be nice to attend the breakfast buffet in the Pikake Lounge, considering we had a bunch of family fly in to meet for a special occasion. After finding out it was $21.95 EACH, we decided to sit down anyways and enjoy the beautiful atmospshere (so we thought!) Not only were the servers painfully slow, they were among the RUDEST, CONDESCENDING INDIVIDUALS I have come across!!!!!!!!!!! After this experience left a bad taste in our mouth we almost didn 't want to return:) However, we thought we would give it another chance, once again, disappointment!!!!!!!! The only employees we want to give thanks to are the Bell Boys and the Housekeepers for actually smiling and acknowledging us on a daily basis:) We will return to Waikiki, just not to the Sheraton Princess:)

My husband and I and 2 kids 6 and 8 stayed here Jan. 2008. We were scared considering some of the reviews, but we really enjoyed our stay. The rooms were dated, and a little rough around the edges, but overall our room was very pleasent and clean. The room had a late 1980s feel. The staff was genuinely friendly and helpful. I can see how where you are located can affect your stay. We were in the Princess tower and our room overlooked the pool and the Westin Moana across the street. It was nice. There is pool entertainment noise at night, but we were so exhausted at night, it didn't bother us. Try to avoid street rooms at the lower levels due to bus noise. This is not a hotel for you if you if you are finicky about your room, or you like to spend a lot of time at your hotel, lounging at the pool, lingering over room service meals, and relaxing. This is not the place for honeymooners. The hotel has a small pool and a busy atmosphere and the rooms are for showering and sleeping. I personally found the atmosphere festive with a "I'm on vacation!" feel. We are active travelers, who are gone all day, and the room was perfect for us. The beds are comfortable. I like the small Hawaiian touches the hotel provides. Flowers for you hair at the desk, which my daughter loved, pineapple slices and juice in the afternoon, lei making and hula lessons and craft sellers in the lobby and Hawaiian entertainment at night. Though sometimes the night entertainment was very lounge lizardy. We had a discount for the morning buffet that we used. It was very good, with a wide variety of breakfast foods. Our price with the discount made it reasonable, but if your on a budget I would skip it. Avoid the waxy doughnuts, not worth the calories. Yes the name says Sheraton, but with a room rate of about $150 - 200 in expensive Waikiki, you should know that you are not going to get a top notch room and you won't. When they do rehab it, prices will go up accordingly. I felt our room rate was fair for what we got, a clean, comfortable room in a great location.  A hint for those parking with luggage, go to the top part of the parking garage that is labeled "additional parking." There is an elevator there that can take you to the lobby. The lower levels do not have an elevator and you have to lug your luggage down stairs. We had a great time in Waikiki, which I usually avoid for the North Shore, and I would definitely stay here again.

My partner and I went to Hawaii to visit his son who is stationed at Kaneohe Bay, and stayed at the Sheraton for our visit.The bellmen were among the best I've ever encountered - very friendly, very knowledgeable, and quite helpful in getting us oriented. The check in was quick and professional, so no complaints about that part of the process.We stayed in room 236, a king room at the end of the hall with a lanai overlooking the pool, and just immediately over the reception area. While the lanai sliding doors did a pretty credible job of blocking out the noise, if they were open to allow in the lovely breeze, it was VERY noisy. It seemed that there was a tour bus loading up every morning and it was a constant cacophony. The hotel is one block off Kalakaua Blvd, the main drag in Waikiki, so lots of road noise, and at night, lots of noise coming from the street performers as well as the nightly poolside show. In retrospect, I probably should've asked to stay on a higher floor, and perhaps some of it might have been filtered out.The bed was comfortable, the bathroom pretty standardly sized with a pocket door for privacy. We were pretty exhausted the day we arrived from the long flight there, so I didn't notice it immediately, but when I went out onto the lanai the next morning to enjoy some fresh pineapple juice, I noticed a large crack in one of the sliding glass doors, and several bloodstains on the curtains. Now, to their credit, once I pointed it out to the housekeeper, they immediately got to work on it and the front desk called up and offered to move us to a different room, but my partner was ill and uninterested in repacking just to unpack again, so we declined. But it did make me wonder how long it had been there and how often they inspected such things.It seems to be a global trend for hotels to nickel and dime you to death for amenities that should come with the room, which annoys the ever-loving daylights out of me. You have to mount an exploration to find the free channels ( I was looking for CNN) on TV; the menu button on the remote leads you directly to all the pay services. Wireless internet access is expensive, and the signal wasn't that great; you could take advantage of the free desktop computers downstairs, but be prepared to wait, as there was always a queue. There was an in-room safe, which has been free everywhere else I've stayed, but I believe they were charging something like $4.95 a day to use it. There is a free computer solely devoted to checking in for flights and printing boarding passes - but it closes at 9:00 pm when the concierge leaves, and if you want to check in for a flight back to the mainland which leaves at say, 10:45 pm the next night, you can forget about doing anything about it until the concierge returns at 7:30.The breakfast buffet, while tasty, was a ridiculous $21.95 per person. We did it once, and for the rest of our stay opted to go across the street to the ABC store and get fresh fruit salads and sodas there for $5.00 per person, which we could eat in our room, free of the annoying gulls who set up shop in the open-air dining area. As soon as a diner would get up from the table, the birds (who had long since lost any fear of humans!) would swoop in to devour any leftovers on the plate. That was just too creepy for me to deal with, personally. The wait staff tried to shoo the birds constantly, but were overwhelmed by their number and their tenacity.Waikiki Beach is across the street. There are two public beach access points convenient to the hotel; go left (towards the "Duke" statue and the Police Station), and there's a little snack bar, restrooms, surfboard rentals, etc; there is another if you cross the street at the Moana Surfrider and head up the street towards the Cheesecake Factory. You can check out beach towels poolside with your room key and take them to the beach and then sign them back in when you return.There are several shuttles that pick up across the street - the "pink line" will take you to Ala Moana Mall for $2 each way; there's also a free Hilo Hattie's shuttle which will take you to their flagship store on Nimitz Blvd. After you've dropped some bucks for the quintessential touristy souvenirs, the shuttle driver will, on request, drop you off at Ala Moana Mall, the Aloha Tower, or the Ward shopping center.The one thing I really liked about the hotel was at 2:15 every day, you could taste fresh pineapple or drink a cup (or two!) of fresh pineapple juice. It was wonderful, and can't recommend it highly enough.

This was my second time to Waikiki in 2007.The first time I stayed at the Waikiki Marriott where I had my honeymoon. We had a great room but it was pretty expensive.This time I took my mother and decided to stay at the Sheraton Princess K or as I remembered it "the Sheraton with the hookers out the front" as it was more centrally located (so easier for an older person with mobility issues), much cheaper (USD $185 per night) and was pretty well reviewed on this site. As it was apart of the Sheraton chain I figured it would have to be pretty decent too. This hotel is good value for money especially when you compare it to a lot of the other hotels that are pretty much in exactly the location. We stayed around Thanksgiving and I was surprised at how cheap it was considering it was a peak holiday time in the USA and there were plenty of guests. It is a short stroll to the beach and surrounded by good shops, restaurants and close to the Food Pantry supermarket on Kuhio Avenue.The lobby and pool area is great and I was pleasantly surprised with our room on the 29th floor. It wasn't the Marriott and as others have commented, the hotel could do with a refurbishment soon. The beds and bedding were wonderfully comfortable and the room was clean and in good condition with a good size lanai. That said the bathroom reminded me of the shower scene in Psycho (very 1950's) and after a few days there seemed to be a bit of mould near the top of the shower rail that was mysteriously never cleaned by housekeeping. The room faced the International Marketplace (not the ocean like it was supposed to but you could technically see the ocean) so it was pretty noisy until midnight and I had to sleep with earplugs a couple of nights. We didn't eat at the hotel as it was expensive and there were so many great restaurants within a short walking distance. The free Overall it was good and I would stay here again and recommend it as a mid range accommodation. I have stayed in much worse places than this!!!! Some of the hotels off Kuhio Avenue looked pretty rubbish in comparison so I think the Princess K is pretty good considering that hotels tend to be pretty expensive in Waikiki. Most importantly, the whole point of going on holiday is not to stay in your room! Get out and experience what you came to Hawaii for!

Just for the location, the Sheraton Princess should be highly considered as a hotel for Waikiki. The Sheraton is in an L configuration with the patio, pool and performance area in the open space to form a rectangle on Kalakaua Avenue, the main street of Waikiki. The best part of Waikiki Beach is just across the street and east or directly through the Moana Surfrider, about 25 yards. The International Marketplace is just west of the hotel and other major shopping centers are within a few blocks.While advertised as a three-star property, this hotel should definitely should be rated higher. The lobby is open-aired, well-staffed and the room was in excellent condition. We were upgraded from the lowest priced room to a front location overlooking the pool, Kalakaua Avenue and over the palm trees, the ocean. The room contained a king bed, sofa and dresser/desk. The balcony was small but both sliding doors could be opened to make it part of the room.The evening buffet was expensive but we ordered ala carte at the bar at a more reasonable price. Entertainment is provided each night from 6:30-9:30 in the form of a trio with dancers. As a promo for a Legends show, performers like Elvis, Chuck Berry and Whitney Houston also drop in to sing. There is a parking fee of $15 a night but the parking attendant issued a pass after the first night. Free internet is provided at stations in the lobby, however, wireless can be found on the balcony.The price, quality, location and ambiance make for an excellent value in Waikiki. The Sheraton Princess should be highly considered when visiting Honolulu.

I would like to begin by saying that this hotel is not the bad hotel that a lot of reviewers have been saying on the negative side of things.Yes the hotel is older and is due for some updating but it is clean and very close to Waikiki beach.To stay at a newer hotel you would be paying triple the room rate. The concierge was always helpful and there was free use of computers in the lobby for internet access.You can check out towels and beach mats from the pool to take to the beach with you. You don't have to use you own towels which is great.There is many stores for shopping nearby as well.We would definitely stay here again in the future.

We enjoyed our short stay very much. Our expectations were somewhat low based on some of the earlier reviews, but in fact this hotel was clean, extremely well located (across he street from Waikiki beach and some of the best shopping on the island), and very well priced. Prepare to pay $15 for parking. Really, we would stay here again in a heartbeat.

This property is great! We stayed in Oahu from 12/22-12/24 and 12/28-12/30. The first part we stayed at another hotel, and the second half we stayed at the Sheraton. I would recommend it to ANYONE! We had a reservation at another hotel but called a few days before to see if they had a cancellation. They did, so we booked and cancelled our other reservation. Just a tip: If you are going to stay, join the Starwood Preferred Guest program. The rate was originally $330 and with AAA it was a bit cheaper (I forget the rate exactly) but with SPG it was $215. *This was around the holidays when the prices are rasied*The front desk agent who checked us in, Chie, was very friendly and also gave us recommendations on places to go nearby.Our room was spacious, clean and attractively decorated. There are also nice balconies. Our room overlooked the pool and there as nightly entertainment that we could watch from our room (or downstairs by the pool if you choose!).The hotel is located right in the center of things and there are many restaurants nearby.The ONE thing I didn't like about the hotel was that the pool closed so early (at 6pm!) It would have been nice to be able to have a night swim. Other than than it is GREAT! I really recommend that you stay at this property. We certainly will be staying here next time we are in Waikiki!!

We stayed at the PK (as the locals call it) from December 10-15th and were generally happy with this hotel. Was it a five star experience? No. But the price was right and the location was great - right accross the street from the beach front hotels (which cost way more). We payed a bit extra to get a room with a "high ocean view" and were pleased with the view from our lanai. Waikiki is an urban area: there are homeless people, street performers and prostitutes. That's part of the deal. If you want to avoid this, go to Maui. Yes, the hotel buffet was expensive, but this is Hawaii people; everything is expensive! The nice thing about Waikiki compared to some of the quieter islands is that there are so many food options within walking distance you don't have to limit yourself to expensive hotel food. Overall, I would say this hotel was a good value and very well situated.

Sheraton Princess Kaiulani needs major overhaul. Room amenities - dilapidated bedding & furniture, musty odor, stained carpet, tacky lighting, broken bathroom tiling & poor drainage, dusty 1950s decor - were very old and outdated. Lack of wall plug-ins. Bathroom very dirty, even after housekeeping. For the price, the room was a rip-off. Location - close to shopping and crowded area of the beach. Also a prime location for obvious prostitution after 10 pm. Hotel staff was more amused with these persons than they were with asking them to relocate themselves. Free, public internet computers, available for 15 minutes at a time, contain viruses, are very slow, and most were out of order. Hotel dining - overpriced buffet - approx. $20 per person breakfast, $40+ per person dinner. Waitresses available by the pool at designated tables if you are willing to wait at least 30 minutes to be acknowledged. Hotel housekeeping lacks nor uses skill or care in cleaning your room around your belongings. If your personal property is accidentally removed from your room by hotel housekeeping, a complete investigation will result in waiting 30 days or more after you have returned home to hear that your items will not be replaced, "because the housekeeper said she didn't take it." So after a thorough search of your hotel room and remaining personal property by hotel security, filing reports and collecting affidavits, and making numerous contacts by phone, email, and letter - the hotel does not hold their staff accountable for criminal or accidental loss of your property. By the way, the police department is right across the street for your convenience. Unbelievable! Stay at your own risk.

This hotel was wonderful. The hotel staff was very helpful and more than willing to go the next mile to help us. They even provide a hospitality suite to allow travelers who have a late departure flight to "freshen up" before going to the airport. The lobby was very clean and openly bright, with nightly entertainment. The parking garage charges $15 a day and you can get a parking pass upon sign in and take out the car as many times as you like just paying once. Location, this hotel is ideal, literally a block away from Waikiki beach. ABC store across the street very convenient to pick up any extras you'll need throughout your stay. Also, the International market is right next door. Great staff, great service, we had a fantastic time, would definitely stay there again.

This hotel is in desperate need of refurbishment. The first room we were allocated overlooked a car park and was extremely noisy due to a motor located outside. It was also very filthy. We requested another room but were asked to pay £180 to do so. The policy here is clearly not to provide customer satisfaction. The second room we were allocated overlooked the pool and was a nicer room. However it was still dirty and old. I was shocked and disappointed by this hotel. Staying here ruined my holiday. I wouldn't recommend it to anyone.

Surprised about some of the negative reviews. The room #2956 could do with some updating, but its decent enough - I've definitely had better 3* rooms in new hotels, but the Kaiulani easily possesses a 3-4* feel in the lobby.Great view from the room (top floor, facing Diamond Head).Good location, and at $185 I'd say it was very good value. Check in was nice - drop the baggage off from the car, park (in their car park), obtain keys within 2 mins, nip to the bar for a cold pint while the missus arrives and the bags get taken to the room.We stayed Thanksgiving night. I'm British, so don't care and didn't even know it was Thanksgiving until 2 days before, but was grateful for the accommodation. We were tired after a long day and needed to eat dinner. I was tempted to order dinner using room service, but there was a disclaimer that said 17-18% service charge would be added to the price. What's that about?? In the end we ate at the Thanksgiving buffet around the pool as we couldn't find anything we fancied nearby. Reasonable food $38 each though, not including any drinks.

This hotel does not deserve 1 star. It felt like a 1940 soviet era hospital. It has not been renovated since at least that long. The rooms are full of black mold. The service is hostile and rude and disinterested. The place is generally filthy.

Overall, for the price, this was a good place to stay. The central location was great with the beach just across the street. Lots of restaurants and shops were adjacent and the short blocks made walking around town quite easy. The public bus and paid trolley stops were nearby. Bus/organized tours picked up right outside the hotel.The pool was only open from 9am-6pm and there was no hot tub to warm up in after swimming at the beach. The hotel itself didn't have a gym, though the sister Sheraton hotel had facilities where you could pay to get in, if you wished. There were some restaurants at the hotel which we did not visit (there are so many around that were less expensive). At 2pm, the hotel offered "pineapple carving" where you could help yourself to fresh pineapple juice and pineapple slices (delicious) <even if you're not a guest, you could stroll in and induldge!>. During the day, there were a few vendors selling crafts by the pool.The rooms were small, but very clean. I loved the pillows though I found the mattress a little firm. Our view towards the west wasn't much. Unfortunately, we were located on the 3rd floor which TOTALLY SUCKED BECAUSE IT WAS REALLY NOISY FROM 4AM unti 11PM. The people traffic wasn't bad - the problem was that shuttle buses and tour buses would idle outside on the street picking up passengers. Very annoying. We did ask for a room overlooking the poolside when we checked in, but apparently, they didn't have anything available. Because we wanted two adjacent rooms, we elected to stay where we were. Although some rooms had connecting doors, ours didn't so I guess that we should have requested new rooms on the second day. Oh bother!Hotel summary: good location, clean rooms, nice staff, and good price BUT request rooms towards the poolside and remember that this is not a resort hotel - there's so much to see in Oahu - don't plan to spend much time at the hotel. Go experience Hawaii!Recommended outings: Germaine's luau, Giovanni's shrimp truck, Duck tour - Pearl Harbor, Hanauma Bay, Kailua kayaking, Diamond Head, Happy Trails horseback riding, Waimea Audobon Center (waterfall!), Waikiki Aquarium, Makani Catamaran

Well, I am not sure I can really add much to what has been already said about the hotel. I was alittle surprised by how small the room was. One of the cabinets is taken up for the frig and the safe, so you were left with very little space to unpack. There are drawers in the closet, but they are quite small. I guess it just was hard to keep the room very tighty with so little storage space. We did have to deal with the noise, but I was so worn out each night, I really did not have any trouble sleeping. What I would really want you to know is, if you are looking for a resort type enviroment, this is not the place for you. It is a hotel and no more. They try by having bands by the pool and bring in vendors to sell hats, jewelry, etc. They also have a few classes such as lei making, but they are in the middle of the day and most people are already out and about. The location is great if you are looking for shopping and yes there does seem to be an ABC Store on every block! The beach is not far and the hotel is great about letting you take their towels from the pool area to the beach. As a Starwood Preferred guest we are suppose to get late check out, when I went to the front desk the day before we left, I was told they were totalled booked and would not get late check out. I called the next morning and was told "no problem". This really helped as our flight did not leave until late that night so we were able to visit the beach one last time and really enjoy our last day in Hawaii. I visited with one of the clerks at the "Thor" store and she told me that Honolulu is not what Hawaii is about, you really need to visit the other islands to get the true "aloha spirit". We did take a one day trip to Maui and really enjoyed it. The only down side is the hurry up and wait at the airport. We had to wait over an hour and a half each way at the airport. So, if you are going to shopping, spend alittle time at the beach and site see this hotel will work for you. If you are looking for a laid back, romantic holiday, keeping looking!

This hotel is below what I'd consider 3 stars for a US hotel. I've been in 3 star hotels in Mexico that were nicer and better equipped than the Princess Kaiulani. The staff are all very nice, but the room was fairly cruddy - all the bathrooms were very old with floors that had very questionable, moldy looking stains in the grout and it was very cramped - if one person is standing up in the room, you'd get claustraphobic just looking in from the doorway. I had to sleep in a room where water dripped from the ceiling onto my head for 2 nights before they felt it was appropriate to move me. The hotel is very conveniently located right across the street from the beach, next to the International Marketplace, but I was almost embarrassed to tell people where I was staying. Bottom line - good location explains the rates, but overall, it's a rundown hotel that you wouldn't expect to find in the hotel zone right along Kalakaua Avenue next to all the expensive, high end retail shops.

we have just returned from 15 nights at sheraton princess .we arrived on monday eve travelling from ireland 24hrs..well it was worth every minute to arrive at this beautiful destinitation..the poolside woz torch lit and a local band playing hawaiin music as people dined..very impressed..friendly staff greeted us with ALOHA .a regular occurance. every night music starts at six ,another musician starting at9 till 11.30..the room woz standard size with a small balconey with views of the sea and diamond head .it woz perfect for our requirements as we were out sightseeing during the day or catching the waves on the beautifull Waikiki beach which was literally 2mins walk from hotel.The pool area wos clean and staffed at all times .any amount of towels and beach mats availeable at no charge..they also provided cold face towels to cool down wich i thought was a nice touch.lovly bar menu and reasonably priced.thought breakfast and dinner were a little pricey but there are plenty of other gorgeous restaurants to choose from.I would highly recommend Dukes restaurant, and Shorebird both outrigger hotels.my favourite,beachfront restaurant all you can eat salad bar and steaks ,kebabs chicken and fish entrees that you cook yourself on huge indoor bbq..very fun idea ,with good music .very romantic ..the Big Khauna another good bar food menu,good music and late night bar...the Sheraton had daily lei making, hula dance lessons and pineapple tasting during day also ..room service of linen and towels daily..v.good overall a truely wonderfull experience aand would definitely stay at sheraton again..P.s a sunset cruise is a must...for the true romantics out there.....ALOHA

Used points to get this hotel so couldn't complain about the price. Good location for a place that is not on the beach. Open lobby around the pool with very friendly staff. But overall, this place is a little old. Elevators are musty. Bed was good. We were placed in the main building without a view. There was a taller building that may have been better. Overall, I would recommend this to people looking to save some money who don't want a newer facility. Services were very good however so and it's Waikiki, so don't stay too much in your hotel room anyway...

Booked this hotel through the SPG site. We got a "high ocean view room with a king bed" in the Ainahua tower. We were on the 25th floor with what' I'd call a partial ocean view, since the hotel is a block from the beach and you can see the ocean only between two beachfront hotels. On the other hand, you can also see the hills and have a nice city view. The room and bathroom was clean and comfortable. Central location with stores and restaurants steps away. Concierge was knowledgeable and helpful. Yes, there was 'noise' but it was hawaiian music from street performers not horns or sirens or drunken screaming. It quieted down around 11pm, and was completely acceptable to us.

I was recently on business in Hawaii and stayed at the Sheraton Princess Kaiulani. I was extremely disappointed with the hotel. The room was small, overlooking the International Market on the 19th floor. The noise from the street level kept me up all night, and to my suprise prostitutes gathered outside the hotel enterance each evening. The hotel staff was unwilling to relocate me to a room with less noise, and when I addressed to prostitute issue, I was told "we are a full service hotel". Boy, what a image of the Sheraton hotel chain. I'm just glad I didn't have my children with me for this trip.

My husband and I travelled to Hawaii to celebrate our first wedding anniversary. We travelled from the U.K. and stayed in Vegas for 3 nights before going to Oahu. We were worried after making the booking and reading the reviews. So many people made negative comments. My husband even tried to change the hotel. We had been spoilt by the gllitz and glamour of the hotels Vegas had to offer. I thought our hotel in Hawaii was going to ruin our vacation. However, when we arrived at the Princess we were pleasantly surprised. The front desk were helpful. The rooms were cleaned well. Our room had a pool view. Every evening we would listen to the live Hawaiian music playing downstairs as we got ready to go out. Beautiful !. My husband loved the pineapples that were served to eat or as a juice. This took place daily at 2pm in the lobby. I loved chatting to the local Hawaiian people who came to sell souveniors. The Princess Kaiulani is in a fantastic location. Close to the shops, beach, restuarants. I see what people mean when they compare it to other Sheratons. However, it's good value for money and would suit those who would rather spend their money exploring the island that on a glitzy hotel. Hire a car, go on a submarine trip, climb diamond head. It's a paradise island, and for us was a trip of a lifetime.

My husband and I stayed at this Sheraton in the beginning of August. We did stay in the oldest wing. It was in need of updating.When I saw the AC unit I was a little afraid of leaving it on all night. It was that old. But, I must say, the room was large and imaculate. Maybe we just got lucky with housekeeping for the time we were there. I am very particular with cleanliness of rooms! I usually always call the front desk on my first entering a room. The room was very reasonable compared to other hotels in the area. We just came off a 7 day cruise, and wanted to see Oahu because the ship really did not stay any amount of time there. I could not afford to spend a great deal. The location is great . The beach is a block away, and all the good restaraunts are in the area. We went to the Luau at The Royal Hotel. Not to be missed. The staff was great at this hotel. We did not have to leave for the airport until 6:00., 7 hours after check out. We stayed at the hotel, used the pool, had a light supper and then was given the key to the "Hospitality Suite" where we were able to shower and change. . My experience there was very favorable.

Just returned from our vacation in Paradise...!!! After reading the reviews, I was afraid that we had booked the wrong hotel. I am very picky but for the price you cannot go wrong. We were on the 10th floor in the Ainahua tower. Room overlooked the pool and ocean. Beautiful view morning and night, I never heard the street noise or music and I am a very light sleeper. Besides, the music is beautiful and you are in Hawaii!!! The room was clean but small but that was okay. The bathroom was small as well and could have been a little cleaner. The bathtub took a little while to drain. Beds/pillows were very comfortable and usually I cannot sleep except in my own bed with my own pillows. There is a refrigerator and a safe. (they did not charge $3.25 a day for safe) No it is not a 5 star but for the price, it is a steal!!!! Everything you needed!!!Hotel staff was helpful and courteous...except for the parking garage staff, they got a little irritated with us,,,we lost our parking pass once and forgot it once,,,not happy with us at all. Oh, well!!Could use a little upgrade but for us PK was excellent choice for the price!! Would stay here again!!Aloha!!!

I stayed at the Sheraton Princess Kaiulani with a friend who booked the room using SPG points, so I don't know how much it would have cost, but it seemed to me like a Sheraton would have larger and/or nicer rooms. The bathroom was pretty cramped and I think the beds were doubles rather than queens. The balcony was nice but overlooked the pool so we heard a lot of music which could be good or bad. We didn't mind too much. The location was convenient to Waikiki Beach and to the shopping on Kalakaua Avenue.

The SPK actually was a nice hotel. I had low expectations based on the prior reviews and the cheap price I paid.I booked the cheapest room on the Sheraton website and was upgraded to a partial oceanview on the 23rd floor overlooking the international market. Once the drummers stopped playing around 11pm, the room became very quiet.Check-in was fast, friendly and efficient. All of the staff were very friendly and helpful. The lobby nicer than I expected, very open with a nice breeze. Elevators were a little slow and always packed.We asked the concierge about a nice simple seafood restaurant that wasn't overly expensive and she gave us a few recommendations, none of which were in any of the local Starwood hotels. I'm glad she can give out recommendations that don't include their hotels. We ate at Ocean House and it was great.The pool was nice and not overly crowded. Plenty of towels too.The pool bar wasn't overly exciting, so I went over to the Westin for drinks which was the best place go for happy hour.The breakfast buffet was overpriced at $22. We ate at Duke's instead for $15 and got an ocean view.The location was perfect. The beach was across the street. Tons of restaurants and bars very close the hotel. Hertz car rental was across the street too.The only problem we had with the hotel, was that I was supposed to have champagne and a cheese plate in my room when I arrived and it wasn't there. They delivered it much later, which ruined the whole point of having it.Overall, I would definitely stay there again for $125 a night.

The hotel is right across from the Moana Surfrider and Waikiki beach. You can't check in until after 3pm and there is no valet parking. You have to park your car around the corner at the parking garage located behind the hotel, cost is $15 per day. Make sure you get your parking validation ticket as soon as you check in! We didn't know about that and had to pay $9 for parking our car in the garage for 3 hours and it was the lady at the parking garage who told us about the valdiation slip. We had asked for a Deluxe Ocean View and got a room at the top floor (11th) with an awesome view of the ocean. They have live entertainment around the pool area from about 7pm to 9:30pm and if you stay in the wing facing Waikiki beach and Kalakua road, you could enjoy the entertainment from your balcony with some snacks. Our room was very spacious with two ceilign fans to keep you cool and the Air conditioner on low to save energy. The bathroom was a little small and on our first night there was a littel trouble with the hot water, some yellowish water was coming out. But I think that was because we were in the old wing and it took the pipes a while to work. The next morning all was well and the hot water was spewing out clear water. The water pressure on the shower was good.There are plenty of ABC stores around you. International Market is like a two minute walk from the pool area and the Royal Hawaiian center was right across the street. This hotel has a great location and is not as heavily priced as the other Sheraton hotels around Waikiki.

They were very nice and perfect customer service.I can not say it better wayI will stayy in this hotel again.clean and perfect location.Mr. Dennis was fantastic. he is very nice man, helped us every way he can to make sure we are happy.Takim family

I stayed with my family over July 4th. We needed 3 rooms all with double beds. Our reservations were accurate. Check in was fast, friendly, and efficient. The rooms were clean and well maintained. They were not fancy. The furniture showed some signs of wear. The TV s were small but worked and had many channels to chose from. We were in the tower with an ocean view.The location is great, right across the street from the beach. Guests are allowed to use all the facilities at the Sheraton Waikiki, the Westin Moana Surfrider, and the Royal Hawaiian including the pools.The best part. The price is usually less than half the price of the other 3 hotels. There are many off property reasonably priced restaurants within a block or two. There are many shopping opportunities ranging from designer to market stalls.When traveling with a group or family, we would stay here again. If we wanted to splurge, we would stay across the street at one of the other properties.

Booked a high ocean view room on the 22nd floor which was very quiet, clean, comfortable and with an absolutely stunning view of the beachfront, the hills and beyond. This was our first trip to Hawaii and I would strongly recommend the SPK as a great value place to stay. Our room also overlooked the pool area and strip. Although it can get a little noisy with the floorshow and street performers (we were seranaded by some idiot with a set of bongo drums for two night!), things quieten down before it gets late. Indeed, the breathtaking views from your balcony more than compensate and we spent many hours just drinking the atmosphere in.The check-in and lobby staff are very courteous and helpful and the whole ground floor and pool area have a very cool, relaxed and luxurious feel about it, even though it does get VERY busy!Didn't eat in at the hotel, mainly bacuse there's so many great places to eat right outside the hotel door.Would I stay there agin? Absolutely! Hopefully before too long aswell.
Really nice hotel, great service and great views. Also great perk that you are allowed to use the pool in the other Sheraton Hotel which is located accross the road, on the beach.

The price was excellent but the rooms were dirty and in need of renovations. The cleaning person must have cut themselves and didn't notice the blood that was left in the bathroom and on the sheets it took quite a ong time to get someone upto the room to address the situation. THey just handed us sheets and told us to change them ourselves. After a 20 hour trip I was not happy would not stay here again.

We have stayed 5 nights in middle of May. Hotel was nicer than my expectation. We got high ocean view 20 some floor and we could see diamond head, and ocean.Hotel room looked new and bathroom was good size. ( not like other people were saying )Location was perfect. We paid $127/night through expedia, and for the money could not do any better. I will stay here again, and recommend to others.

Just returned from a memorial weekend trip to Ohau. We had a five night stay and overall had no major complaints. The lower floors can get street noise if you are facing the street, which we were. We were on the fourth floor Kaiulani Wing. This faces the King Shops. The pool as are all the pools that we saw along the hotels in Waikiki is rather small for the size of this hotel but when you have such a great beach right across the street who wants a pool?We used the safe on a few occassions and were not charged for it at check-out. It's says on the safe that they charge $3.50/day. The large lanai was nice. There was an empty fridge in the room, which we filled with water/drinks from the ABC store. Our room was right above the parking area for the tour buses so we were awoken each morning to the sound of diesel bus enigines. The hotel is showing its age. The elevators in our wing broke one day while we were there and I had a steel tube from the sink drop on to my foot, causing a large cut that bled profusely. The hotel staff is friendly and overall the value and location of this hotel makes it a good deal for people looking for a decent and clean place to stay on Waikiki with out paying the higher prices for the location. We'd stay hear again.

Arrived in HNL, picked up rental car from airport, and headed to Pricess about 3:30 p.m. on a Friday afternoon. Traffic was horrendous!!!! This was the only time during our entire trip that we experienced this. It took us almost an hour to get to the hotel. It is an easy drive to the hotel. Hotel will be on the left of the one way street and is across from the Moana Surfrider. You must turn left at the light for the front entrance. Great input from others such that we knew to pull up to the hotel and drop off our luggage with the bellcap BEFORE parking the car. We then parked next door on the 5th level. Make note -No elevators in parking deck!!!You enter the hotel from the first floor over the parking deck. You enter into an open-air area. To your left is check-in and lobby, directly in front is the pool, to the right is a lobby area and dining. We took our parking tkt to the front desk with us. We were given some kind of receipt so that we would have in-and-out access to the parking lot. Cost is $15 daily.We booked our room for one night via Expedia for $98 and used Starwood points for the other night. Check-in was quick. There were yellow plumeria leis and flowers for your hair on the counter. We were assigned room #1471 in the tower. It was at the end of the hallway facing Moana Surfrider. Based on past reviews, I was a littleconcerned. However, the hotel was great. It is not luxury, but it is nowhere near the worse I've stayed in. While it is not new, and neither are many of the hotels in Honolulu, it was clean and the staff was great. The room is avg size with a lanai. It was extremely clean (see pictures) with a Hawaiian theme. We are happy with our decision to stay here. Originally, we were going to splurge and stay somewhere else. We spent so little time in the room, staying here wasthe best decision that we could have possibly made.There is high-speed access, coffee maker, and a safe in the room. Not sure of the cost for high-speed, but there is a cost for the safe. The safe sits on the closet floor and takes up half the space. If you have more than one large suitcase, you will have to put it up against a wall or something. Our room had one King bed (looked like a queen). Double rooms maybe different.Now, about the location...it was absolutely FABULOUS! We parked the car early each evening and hit the sidewalk. We walked to dinner at Nick's and stopped at shoppes/stores everywhere we could. International Marketplace, Duke's, and anywhere else you might want to go.A funny note, whether you walk out of the hotel by the lobby, left of the pool, or past the shops to the right of the pool...you will find an ABC STORE!

We had a high ocean view room. We booked with a web special of 65% off. We were on the 19th floor, excellent view over the top of the hotel across the street on the beach. Our balcony overlooked the pool area, straight out was Waikiki beach and the ocean. The hotel could use some updating, it is showing it's age. Overall, it was a very good deal for the price.

We chose to stay here for one night on the first night of our honeymoon before heading off to another island. I usually would book on priceline or similar, but wanted to guarentee a king bed in a non-smoking room for our honeymoon so booked directly through the website. Unfortunately, when we arrived they had said they were upgrading us, but it was to a room with 2 double beds... We called and requested the non-smoking king and they only had one room that was lower than that which we booked and could only find it when I told them we would not stay there... Once checked into the lowest class room (not even avail online) it was okay - but there was hair on the bathroom sink and the hallway smelled of mildew.

Now before choosing this hotel I started looking into its review here on TA.To be honest Ive read a lot of complaints regarding the noise, dirt, condition of the room etc etc.I didn't really want to stay at this hotel, but for the price of $99 a night for a standard room, to me it was a no brainer since the location of the hotel is a big deciding factor.When we arrived on April 19 for our 4 night stay, they immediately upgraded us to a partial ocean view room (See attached Pictures). We where definitely happy about that. We where given a room on the 7th floor.The room was clean, and the furniture and the carpets didn't seem worn out. The bathroom was clean too, and not worn out. The air conditioning worked perfectly and was very quiet. The room had a nice partial view indeed and the noise from the street and the nightly show was not a factor at all. The only complaint I have was that the hall way smelled like smoke.Overall I have little to no complaints. We got fresh towels everyday from the cleaning lady. We borrowed hotel towels everyday for the beach (Don't know if that was allowed but we did return them). We enjoyed the free computer access in the lobby.Now the little complaint I have is the lack of recommendation by the concierge on a great place to eat. We asked them to recommend a great Japanese Restaurant, and they suggested the ones in the Hotel. Each time I asked for another suggestion they keep reminding us on how great the Hotels Japanese restaurant was. That was the disapointing part, but after a bit of searching on the internet we found a gem. If your ever in the mood of GREAT Japanese food head to Sushi Sasabune.My experience at this hotel was pretty good, and would definitely stay here again. Hopefully the next time we stay at this hotel it would have been renovated.Thank you for reading my review, and hopefully it helped you decide whether this is a good choice for you.

If your idea of a hotel in paradise is a business, group/convention oriented, fast-paced hotel that is tired, run down and in great need of renovations, stay here. Otherwise, do the right thing and choose another Starwood property. The only reason to stay here is because you can't afford the rates or the points for a better property (i.e. Royal Hawaiian, Moana, Sheraton Waikiki or W). My partner described the noise level of this hotel as 'metropolis.' I have stayed in much quieter hotels in downtown Manhattan. All night we heard trash trucks and sirens and traffic and harleys. I think the issue is that the hotel has no sound insulation at all. Many street performers gather in front of the hotel area at night, and they can bang on drums until late into the evening which will keep the entire hotel awake. The elevators are painfully slow and small. The rooms are old and tired. They don't have Sheraton sweet sleaper beds here, and they do very little in my opinion to cater to Starwood Platinum members here, including a marginal upgrade and not allowing a late checkout. Every other hotel we went to made this place seem like a Best Western. When you call to complain (i.e., the maid never brought more towels an hour after calling the service promise desk), they really don't seem to care much. The hotel lobby itself always seems to smell like raw fish and moldy carpet. I was embarrassed I booked this hotel and encourage you to look elsewhere unless you are OK with 3-star standards and a lot of noise. This is not the Hawaii you see on the postcards...

I stayed for one night in a room at the back on a low floor, and was reasonably impressed. Check in was smooth. The room was clean, quiet and well airconditioned, with two double beds and a very functional bathroom. The lobby and pool area are great, and the evening show is pleasant. The cooking smells could be better, at least the evening I was there - but I cannot comment on the food as I ate on the plane. Being a big hotel, everything is fairly busy - but the crowd seemed well behaved. Outside on the street in the evening they should ask the Waikiki police (just opposite) to move the ladies of the night away. Waikiki has families strolling by in the evening and could do without this problem.

I need to caveat this by explaining that I live in a hotel 300 days per year, and I am kind of a hotel snob. This Sheraton was ok - definitely not the type of Sheraton I am used to - i.e. no sweet sleeper bed (bed was uncomfortable, pillows were lumpy and the comforter was a scratchy, thin spread popular with motels), no soft towels, not renovated - but it was clean, simple and a good value. I actually stayed there on Starwood Points and it was only 7,000 points per night - not bad since the other Sheratons nearby were 12,000 per night and up. The staff was friendly, the location was good (right next to a ABC store, a few restaurants, and the International Marketplace) and I rented a car so I could escape Waikiki when the tourists got overwhelming. There were a lot of tour groups and school trips there, which got a little tiresome (MUST you scream to your friends down the hallway at 3am??) but overall - good value for the price, and it doesn't promise a 5 star experience, so I knew what I was in for.

Disappointed is probably the best word for this particular Sheraton. When you think Sheraton you expect a classy and luxurious hotel. Bad News:The lobby is nice but the hallways are dingy. Not really dirty but just old and in need of new paint and lighting.The rooms are pretty much the same. Dingy. The bathroom tile was fading and chipping. The hot water and air conditioning did not seem to work that well either. The view was nice. We had a particial ocean view and we could see the Sheraton Moana Surfrider which is across the street and magnificent.The location of the hotel is great since it is in the heart of Waikiki. I think with so many hotel options in Oahu, I would not pay more that $120 a night to stay here.The only real grip I have with the Princess are the elevators. There are only four elevators for the tower wing. The day we were checking out we waited 25 minutes before we able to get onto an elevator with our luggage. The elevators are slow and small and usually crowded. If you do stay at the princess plan a little extra elevator wait time.Good News:I read in the paper that the Princess is slated for renovations but probably will not happen anytime soon.

We were very pleased with our hotel stay here. The location can't be beat. Waikiki is the best place within Oahu to stay in. Everything is so close and convenient. Buses run everywhere.First off the location of this hotel was great because: we were among the first people to get off the shuttle from the airport and last people to be picked up. Nothing worst than taking a shuttle and be last to be dropped off or first to be picked up. If you have a car rental or can take a taxi then great for you but I'm sure most people would like to save where they can. Bad thing about car rental is that you have to pay for parking which can be expensive!Check in and out was quick. Wasn't a long line at all. People weren't bubbly but friendly. They had free internet access downstairs and 3 different FREE newspapers! SWEET!!Our room was on the eighth floor. Room was fairly small, not that much longer than the bed but they did have a full size mirror which made it longer and a nice balcony. AC was a bit noisy, not horrible but definitely not one of your quiet newer models. We didn't lose any sleep due to that though.Room was clean and fairly well kept. Our tub's drainage was a bit slow though. I find that's an issue in quite a few hotels.The concierge were helpful. The buffet they offered was a bit expensive. I wouldn't recommend unless it's a Friday when they offer lobster and steak for $3 more than normal. That would be a great value but we didn't stay there long enough for that.Beach, shopping, food all nearby. Don't try the local food places. They are either small in size or lacking in quality. If you see a small price, know what you're getting. I would stay with the more established and well known. We love Denny's for breakfast. You can take the bus to almost everywhere but make sure you know when they start running for certain lines.

Dissapointed Very!!! Having just spent 6 nights at bellagio vegas did,nt help but ,felt the hotel was old in bad need of refurbish,dining well you ate with the birds don't leave your table unatendedhave had better hotels for less money!! really its a case of what you want luxury or just a place to sleep,at least you got a tea & coffee Maker thats one good point for them.But Bathroom well its not a bath a shower and bath for diddy people!!!Won't Stay there again. But Hawaii is a wonderful place weather is great thats why wakkiki is so popular. plenty of trips to go on culture centre is a must a well spent day.Pearl Harbour is another must you have to go we went on the early trip 3 hours all in all.Restaurant you have to go to atlantas food is excellent so is the service prices very reasonable.The revolving restaurant few doors down from atlantas well al a Carte food not impressed the restaurant is okey but service & food expensive,those into shopping go to the outlet cheap!! and macy's anywhere in america great!!!!!!!!!

We stayed in Honolulu for one night in February. Since it was just a one night stay before heading back home, we weren't looking for an expensive hotel. Most of the hotels in Honolulu seemed to be older so we weren't expecting too much. The hotel is situated at a great location - just across from the beach (but not on the beach itself). But it does have a very nice swimming pool and is relatively less crowded than Wikiki beach on a nice day. From the airport, you can take a shuttle to the hotel for US$9 per person (contact the hotel to arrange a pick up time) or a taxi wlll cost about US$40 depending on traffic. There are lots of restauants and shops just along the strip so you won't have a problem finding places to go. The only negative about the hotel is that they have a live band who plays at night till about 9:30 or 10pm, which can be heard on the floors above (we were on the 22nd floor), but you can request a room on the other side of building if you wanted a quieter room. A great price (US$144) for the location if you're not looking for anything fancy.

Wonderful place to stay! Got an upgraded room with an ocean view that looked down at pool and stage where they played nightly music. VERY RELAXING to sit on our lanai and listen to music each evening. Location was wonderful. Couldn't wait to get up and open our lanai doors each morning so we could hear and smell the ocean. Close to beach and shopping. Short walk to everything. Don't let other reviews scare you like they did me. Our travel agent recommended after our trip I thanked her. This is not the fanciest but I thought it was a nice place to stay and wonderful for the price.

We were scared off by the reviews, but wanted to try it because of its value. Surprisingly the hotel is very nice, 3-star hotel. Obviously there were some room for improvements (the carpet was old, the hallways were old as well), but the room was manageable (it was a little small, but since we weren't there much except to sleep, it made no difference to us). The location is extremely convenient. It's across the street from the ABC store, as well as the King Street Shopping. There were plenty of things to keep you entertained at the hotel (live band nightly by the pool, and music going on 'til 11 pm most weekends). It's about a block and a half from Waikiki Beach, so the location is just top notch, without having to pay too much for it. We were located on the 4th floor, with views of the street (no pool view, no ocean view), and it was fine. I think there were other reviews complaining of the noise/music, but when you're in Hawaii, nothing less should be expected than some occasional street performers, and people walking late at night. Besides, the shops are open late (usually 11pm or later), so it's expected to hear the cabs, cars, and pedestrians mingling about.All in all, if on a budget (~$150 or less per night), this is the perfect choice.

Booked 2 rooms via online special. Arrived on-time for check-in to be told (rudely) that even though we pre-paid they had only 1 room for us and were refunding us for the other room. After complaining and arguing, the manager "fixed" the problem and we got our 2 rooms (not together like we had requested). The rooms are average at best, not well maintained and very dated (at least in our wing). We were specifically told by the concierge to visit a snorkeling beach on a day when the beach was closed. We wasted 3 hours of our trip getting ready for the snorkeling beach and waiting for a bus. Despite being given bad information, we were only given our $5 busfare back. We used their computers in the lobby area only to be rudely requested to get off the computers after 5-10 minutes when we were simply checking in for our flights home. We refused to let someone else use the computer until we were finished and were requested by the concierge to get up from them (they have a voluntary -- please limit use to 15 minutes as a courtesy to other guests policy). We felt we were treated rudely as paying guests. We would not stay at the hotel again. Its location is nice, but there are several other hotels in similar locations -- pick one of them before the Sheraton Princess... Housekeeping was friendly. The rate we got was decent. The level of unneeded stress and waste during our vacation was not worth any amount of savings, however.

We booked our package thru Costco. The rep my husband spoke with recommended this hotel. Friendly staff, nice lobby, clean rooms and comfy beds. Our kids loved it too. One of the few hotels in Waikiki that has a pool. Very close to the beach, International Market and restaurants. Would definitely stay at the Sheraton Princess Kaiulani again!

Great location in the heart of Waikiki Beach! The main busy stretch of the beach is directly across the street. The hotel was clean and very well maintained for its age. It looks like a throw back from the 50's. They have a stage by the pool for lounge acts which perform nightly (some better than others). Our deck overlooked the pool and the ocean which was nice once the sun went down. We went to the ABC store (located on every block) and bought a bottle of wine to enjoy during the sunset on our deck alone (away from the throngs of people everywhere but still watching all the action). There isn't anything fancy about the hotel but the location and price were perfect ($126/night for an ocean view). The breakfast buffet was reasonable ($19) for the convenience of not leaving the hotel.

The view of the ocean & the Royal Hawaiian from the 22nd floor were great.Being next to the international market place is a draw back... the street drummers played non-stop until 1AM & the hotel could not (would not??) do anything about it.Will not stay here again. oversixtynrh

“The Princess K” was the perfect place for us to spend two pre-cruise days in Honolulu. We initially were hesitant when we decided to make our reservation at The Princess Kaiulani. Even after reading all the reviews of this and other hotels posted on Trip Advisor we weren’t sure how to weigh each. We finally figured, for two nights we could handle anything.There was no need for hesitation or concern. From the moment our airport shuttle pulled up to the hotel we were embraced by what we considered to be the Aloha feeling of old Hawaii. The beautiful garden and tropical causal elegance of the lobby made it the ideal place to people watch. The room was a standard American style three star hotel room, clean, comfortable and practical. It was the ideal place to use as a base of operations for avid sightseers as we were who weren’t planning on spending a lot of time in the room. Located on the 5th floor we had a view of the pool, and a sliver of the ocean and in the evenings with the doors open to sitting out on the small balcony balcony you could hear the gentle strains of the Hawaiian music played by the small combo in the cortyard below until about 9:30 in the evening. In our exploration of the area we discovered some of the other three star hotel options we had considered, and were glad we made the choice we did. We will definitely stay here again, hopefully for a longer next time.

This was our first time to Hawaii - so it would take a lot to have really made it a bad experience. The hotel lobby and hotel was very nice - however the rooms were probably a bit dated and small. The cool thing is that we spent most of your time on the beach or walking around - driving around... so that didn't bother us at all.Overall - I think the hotel was awesome as far as location - just across the street from Waikiki Beach. The cool thing is that you do not have to pay the price of the beachside hotels - yet you get almost the same exact thing - location wise.I would not hesitate booking this hotel again.

We liked the Sheraton "Princess". It's not a bad distance to the beach and it's a lot more cost effective than the beachfront properties. They have evening entertainment. The only drawback is that the parking lot is kind of hard to find your way around and they let people attending the entertainment park there, so there's not much room for the guests. But, at least it doesn't cost an arm and a leg like the valet parking across the street. The elevators are a little slow.I would definately stay there again!!

The location of this hotel is PRIME in Waikiki, well ok for not being beachfront!The rooms were clean and the staff were friendly. The maids and the concierge desk was most helpful.Don't eat there... too many great places just down the street that are more reasonably priced. Had one breakfast there, and it was ok, but real pricey.The location was the great part, right on the main drag, with lots of shops and restaraunts in walking distance.Stayed in the tower that faces the pool (and the nightly music). It was nice to sit on the blacony and watch. It was loud if you wanted to sleep by 9pm. But it ended early enough that it was more of a bonus than a hinderance.The internet access in the lobby (free) was great.I would stay here again if I went back to Waikiki - and couldn't get a beachfront property!

Checked in and asked for non-smoking; rude desk clerk said all floors were non smoking now. Next day smelled smoke, called front desk, they said I was put on a Smoking floor, guests can smoke in rooms! This is not a real Sheraton (no nice beds), in fact, bed is as old as the Hotel; room smelled of mildew; old and noisy A/C.My room had stopped up tub/shower, was not fixed in 4 days. Had to repeatedly ask for coffee service to be replenished.For this price, stay elsewhere!

I stayed here with a group of 36 people for 3 nights in Mid January. As other reviewers has stated, the hotel is somewhat dated, and it shows here and there. However, our room was clean and certainly large enough for 2 adults. The sheets were clean, the mini-fridge was nice, and our balcony was overlooking the pool area. The music is loud at night, however its Hawaiian music and your in Waikiki. Unless you go to bed before 10:30 every night, it shouldn't be a problem.The great thing about this hotel is the location. The hotel is adjacent to Kings Village and the International Marketplace, is across the street and half a block from the beach, and there are lots of restaurants nearby. You can also walk about 4 minutes to Kuhio and be at all the major buses. This hotel is really in quite a safe area, with the police right across the street next the the Surfrider. That being said, you still get the occasional hooker walking around. They won't hurt you, they are just working. If you aren't interested, they aren't interested in you.I found the staff at this hotel to be excellent. They were all friendly and happy, and the consierge was very helpful.
