So if you go to this hotel, you go for the location. If you expect 5 star state-of-the-art rooms, you'll be disappointed.

As a Starwood Gold Member, I received a 35% off offer in the mail from SPG. I made a reservation for 9 days at the Princess Kaiulani at a rate of $153 per night. I requested an upgrade to the Ainahua tower via email and phone calls directly to the hotel. Upon arrival, I was upgraded to the Princess Tower - which is NOT your typical Sheraton room (old furniture, carpet and small bathroom & tub with old fixtures). The only positive comment about Room 536 was that it was a corner room with a nice lanai facing the beach. Unfortunately, the room did NOT offer the Sheraton Sweet Sleeper bed, even though the website references same. I learned the lesser of all towers is the Kaiulani Tower - I would NEVER have stayed in that old tower. Apparently, I was upgraded from the Kaiulani tower to the Princess tower (2 upgrades) as a SPG gold member; however, I was not impressed. After the third day, I was finally upgraded to the Ainahua Tower (as originally requested) to Room 2856 - with an awesome view of Waikiki Beach. This tower and room is more like the Sheraton you are accustomed. Definitely avoid the other two towers. Unfortunately, the front desk will not inform you as to which tower until check in; or you may call late the morning of arrival to determine same. Otherwise, the entire staff was friendly and accommodating. The negative reviews about this hotel are apparently comments from guests who had rooms in the older two towers. Again, not your typical Sheraton. Also, the pool is adjacent to the lobby, restaurant/bar area with live nightly entertainment and lots of tourists - thus, no privacy or quiet pool area. Aloha!

We were so glad we stayed here as we almost stayed at the Outrigger Reef on the Beach but as they had renovation going on and my husband is in a wheelchair the sheraton princess kailaniwas situated in the best position its central to everything we went down for a look at the outrigger and it looked lovely but it was too far away from everything and when you have to push a wheelchair you will know why. our two sons came 12/ and 17 and they had a great time. We stayed in the newer part of the hotel, two D beds, .( has a barthroom with disable seat in shower and no hobb to get over) the rooms are small but we were only in there to sleep so it was no big deal Very clean and the house maids were very lovely (we had trouble with the toilet as their flush hole is not very big and if you are heavy on the loo paper (one son were sorry to say but we needed a plumber and they came straight away ,tipped them all very well) moral USE ABOUT 5 LITTLE SQUARES OR YOU WILL FIND YOURSELF IN THE SAME SITUATION.-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------we had breakfast at the buffet down stairs 1 time, very dear for breakfast but have to say it was worth it, you name it they had it its worth going to just once, we went to a shop around the corner and brought cereal/ juice/ fruit /plastic plates etc. the dinner buffet we didnt try as we heard it was not very nice it looked ok but too pricey. We went to the cheese cake factory for dinner about 4 times ( go early as it gets very busy around 6.30 on 1/2 hour wait) as the meals were just wonderful if not a little big but they do doggie bags( dont be shy to ask as they are very happy to do) not cheep but you could get any of the meals and share if you wanted to as the meals are very big., went to Danny around the corner its good for hamburgers etcAs for tours we went through the tour desk , lovely lady helped us with all of the tours we did and she also foud out informatiom about Wheelchair access for us she was very helpful all in all we had a wonderful time. cant complain

Stay: 5N, Jan 15 to 20, 2007Room: Small but clean and well maintained. Our terrace had little peeks of the ocean and mountains but primarily overlooked other high rises. They consider this a partial ocean view room.Property: Pleasant open air lobby. Comfortable pool area with small swimming pool located in palm treed court with access main street and Waikiki Beach (short one block walk to newly restored public beach or use the Sheraton Moana Surfrider directly across the street). Service: Excellent. Room service was quite prompt in bringing extra towels to our room. Front desk staff were friendly and courteous. No problems at all. Restaurants: No need to eat at the hotel and pay expensive hotel prices. (Breakfast buffet $19.95 per person, ugh! There's a Denny's around the corner on Kuhio Av.) There are plenty of restaurants in the area just begging for your business.

I'm not going to tell you the room was small because it was fine.We were in a partial ocean view room in the tallest tower. The view was more than one would expect for a partial view.The cleaning staff was wonderful and kept our room fully stocked and clean.I had to deal with 4 different people at the front desk for various reasons, 2 of them were wonderful, 1 was indifferent and 1 needed an"inclusion" intervention.I also spoke to the manager on duty about an ugly incident with another hotel guest (who threw papers at me) and his handling of the situation was not satisfactory!The biggest negative about this hotel and I guess the location of our room was #1 garbage pickup across the street at the Outrigger an Surfrider.5AM for almost 2 and sometimes 3 HOURS come on now!!! EverydayBEP BEEP BEEP CRUNCH CRUNCH CRUNCH!!!#2 Street entertainment, great, but Drummers not 1, but 3 different drummers doing there own thing until 11pm. Every night!I understand that neither of these issues can be controlled by the Hotel, but need to be known by those thinking of booking this Hotel. I think I'll return to "The Reef" .

I stayed at the Sheraton Princess Kaiulani for a family vacation and my entire family and I ate at their dinner buffet (Pikake Terrace) the first night. I don’t recommend going there at all. At $32.50/person, it’s not only the variety was very limited and the only expensive item - sashimi was always out. Also, the parking structure was terrible. There’s a lot of one ways but you couldn’t really see those signs so I ended up having to back up several times in the tight garage. The rooms, too, are horrible. The Kaiulani Wing is extremely old (STAY AWAY FROM THIS WING AT ANY COST) and the Princess Wing is loud until 10:30 PM due to the nightly performances.

First stay was in October of 2005 for two nights. Liked it enough to try it again. Had no reservation this time. My wife did the walk-in thing the day before check-in and was quoted a rate of $139 plus tax for each night of a three night stay beginning December 28, 2006. Orbitz was the only web travel site I found that could match that rate. Others, such as Travelocity and Expedia were higher or showed no availability.For that price, we couldn't ask for much consideration at this time of year, although I requested something high or away from street noise. No luck in that regard due to a very full house, I was told. And, as I feared, the third floor room (372) faced the street, so we did get some noise. A loud, heated verbal exchange among a small group of young men did awaken me the first night; it was short-lived, however. Foam earplugs served well. One of the aspects that brought us back to the Princess Kaiulani was the atmosphere and general lively ambiance of the open, spacious lobby area. Great for people watching. Several airline crews stay there. A number of tours leave from the Hyatt Regency, only a half block distant.Free copies of USA today and the local Honolulu newspaper were available. Three computers in lobby's soft-seating area are set up for free internet access. Signs indicate to limit your time to 15 minutes if others are waiting. Didn't experience any problems getting online; users were considerate.The pool area was roomy, clean and well maintained. Plenty of reclining lounge chairs were set up all around the pool. Nightly entertainment included local, professional-quality, small combos on the stage set to one side of the pool. The restaurant's Friday night seafood buffet had an ample variety; quality was just average in my view. Cost: around $80 (tax included) for two without alcohol.Less than a five minute walk to the active, crowded beach. Lots of shops -- low to medium end -- on the street adjacent. Burger King, Subway, KFC within one block. Cheesecake Factory a few short blocks away. Airport shuttle - $9.00 per person each way or $15 round trip. Friendly, helpful staff.We requested and were granted a two-hour late check-out for 1 p.m. at a cost of $20. The bell desk held our luggage until our 7 p.m. airport shuttle. We didn't make use of the hospitality room, but were told it could have been used for us to clean up if needed.Overall, a very pleasant experience. I've stayed at many other three star hotels that don't measure up to the PK standard.

I definitely think that there are much better places to stay at the same price level on Waikiki Beach. It is a very nice hotel, but the food is less than impressive and the pool area was very small. Service was decent and rooms were clean, but I disagree with the three star rating.

Ok, I visited this hotel when one of colleagues attended a business trip in April '06. Considering this was a business trip, I didn’t contribute to the price. So here are my thoughts on everything else. LOBBY: Beautiful, inviting, nice set-up. Pool area was right next door. You can sit in the lobby and enjoy the breeze from the outside pool area. You have to pay for internet access and it can only be accessed from the lobby. They do hourly rates and/or daily rates. I was there for ten days and paid around $68. ROOM: Well, the room looked petty dull with it’s green color. I was afraid to walk on the carpet barefoot, our toilet leaked and the air condition was broken the first two days. LOCATION: Great….right across from ABC store (there’s one on every corner) a Subway, Burger King and KFC. Waikiki Beach is also across the street.PARKING: Garage parking is $10 a day. So I paid $100. I also would like I rented a Pontiac SUV and paid $287 for 10 days (great deal).

This hotel is in a great location, just off the main shopping street in Waikiki and just a few minutes away from the beach. The hotel is huge and has 3 separate towers. I had a partial ocean view room on the 9th floor of the high tower. The room was an adequate size with two double beds. The bathroom was clean, but the bath was unfortunately very slow to drain. You couldn't take too long of a shower, or the bath would fill up too much. But it didn't bother me too much to complain about it. The bed was comfortable and I had no problems with noisy neighbors. There was some street noise as there seemed to be some kind of drumming going on outside every night, but it never lasted until late. I didn't try to pool or eat at any of the restaurants. For $125, I think it was a good place to stay at.

I have traveled to honolulu for the past 22 years sometimes two and three times a year, i have afforded many hotels on the island fromt the south shore to the north shore. and have had the pleasure to experience the sheraton princess kaiulani on more than 10 occassions,I love this place because it invites you to share their hospitality very similar to what we all refer to as home i enjoy lying out by the pool for hours at a time so that i could return back to los angeles with that yearly tropical tan. i also enjoy the nightly entertainment, i personally find their mai-tai to be the best in oahu, and trust me iv'e looked for the best in the last 22 years. i also enjoy their buffetts, they offer a bit more than the usual. the staff are exceptionally welcoming and are always ready to accomadate you.i most love the flowers and jewlery they are known to sell in the lobby, i met the nicest man there one year named brownie, i remember him because when we met even after i told him my name was teresa he insisted on calling me "sis" i felt like family.i will be staying at the princess in january 12 2007-19 2007, i have chosen this place to celebrate my 44th birthday with my new love. i'm looking forward to it. sincerly, teresa lindsey.

Location, location, location. That about sums up the true strong point of this hotel. Magnificently located just steps from the beach this hotel offers a "center of everything" location in Waikiki. Travelling with a friend, we were fortunate to get a room in the newer, tallest building in the 3 tower hotel complex. Our room, on the 29th floor, had a spectacular view of the ocean. The room itself was fair-sized and well kept with a terrific balcony overlooking the beach. The hotel itself looks a bit tired and we have since learned that the other 2 towers are scheduled to be torn down and replaced with condos, while the building we stayed in will be closed, renovated, and reopened as a more luxurious property.Even though this in not the Ritz, I heartily recommend staying here while you can, since at the rate we paid (less than 50% of the rate for a similar room at the nearby, bigger Sheraton hotel) is, all things considered, an absolute bargain. GO while you can and enjoy Waikiki while there is still an affordable quality hotel there. Soon they'll all be replaced by much more expensive luxury properties.

We have stayed in Waikiki several times but this is the 1st time at the Sheraton Princess Kaiulani, we arrived at 10.30am & were greeted by friendly staff & also given a room upgrade to a Ocean View Room on the 24th floor which was ready at this early check in time. My husband & I were in Hawaii celebrating our 10 yr anniversary & was very pleased with the all round appearance of the hotel, very central to all areas of waikiki. We enjoyed the free nightly entertainment. I have read previous reviews about the noise of the area, to those who want peace & quiet go to another Island. The cost of the Buffet was a bit pricey, you can go around the corner to Smorgy for $20 less, or across the road to Dukes Buffet which is directly on the beach, Don't call direct to another Country from your Hotel Room or it will cost you $$. We will be staying here again next year.

This hotel is terrific value offering all of the advantages of its more expensive sister Sheraton Hotels across the street, without thehigher costs. The hotel room was nicely furnished with 2 double beds and a sitting area with a balcony. If you can, get a roomon the 8th or 9th floor directly overlooking the Sheraton MoanaSurfrider across the street, which also affords a gorgeous oceanview and lovely scene at night with the torch lights illuminatingthe pool area and the hotel across the street. Very clean, first class hotel has delicious food, reasonably priced at the poolside lounge restaurant. Friendly, efficient staff are eager to meet your needs.It was easy to walk across the street and visit the Royal Hawaiian Hotel and the Moana Surfrider and the Sheraton Waikiki, and to charge any drink or beverage bill to the room at the Princess Kaiulani. Hint: the room's hair dryer is in the drawer of the TV armoire. All in all, an excellent first class hotel option in the heart of Waikiki within a few steps to Waikiki beach and the excellent shopping of Kalakuai Avenue.

We stayed in the newest tower (Ainhau) in a corner High Ocean View, 12th floor. Of course having a corner room & even number (1262) probably made a difference. We are well-traveled, have been to several all-inclusive resorts & many cruises. We were in Oahu for my nephews wedding, our sister & brother-in-law (Nashville, TN.) & cousins(Paris, France) also stayed here. We were all pleased! The Lobby areas & Pool area were very nice, always a lounge chair at the pool. Pool bar frozen drinks were close to $8.00, but hey your on VACATION. We did not do the breakfast or evening buffets $20-$30 per person, though the presentations were very nice & food smelled delicious. We walked across the street to the Outrigger Hotel & had breakfast at Hula Grill ($7 & up) gorgeous ocean view. Dukes at Outrigger had a buffet brkfst. for $12 0r $13 . These are both good & reasonable for all 3 meals. Our room was fine, you could hear the traffic noise below & nightly entertainment, but keep in mind your in downtown Honolulu in the center of Waikiki Beach. The noise didn't interfere with our naps or nightly rest. Our room was a fair size, bathroom clean & functional, a/c kept us cool. This hotel was built in the 50's & 60's, so everything isn't perfect, but then our home is only 6yrs. old & it's not PERFECT anymore either. If your a perfectionist, maybe you'd rather pay $100 -$200 or more a night & stay at the Hilton Hawaiin Village where we stayed previously . The Sheraton Princess is in a great location for walking everywhere!! Beach just across the street, International Market Place for South Pacific Jewelry, if you go later at night they will give you better deals, just keep talking them down. We also walked in the other wings of the hotel, out of curiosity after reading all the horrible reviews, they looked fine from what we saw, balconies may have been somewhat smaller. You can't beat this hotel for the price. PLEASED GUESTS from Atlanta, GA.

My best friend and I spent 4 nights here. The hotel was nice. In an amazing location, right across from Waikiki beach, and right next door to the International Market Place. They had free entertainment each night and the rooms were decent. Nothing fancy by any means, but the view from the 28th floor was amazing!We both felt that for what we had paid, we got what we paid for. The price was moderate and the room was moderate. Have to pay for internet access and the buffets (at least I thought) were pricey. I just would think that as hotel guests, at least a discount would be offered for a buffet with eggs and the usual nonsense. The staff however, was always friendly and very helpful.Overall an ok place to stay, and would do so again if the circumstances required it.

My husband and I stayed at the Princess Kaiulani for 2 nights and it was too long for me. When we checked in, after an 8 hour flight, I was welcomed to our "upgraded" room with urine on the toilet seat. Oh yes, it was upgraded apparently because we were able to see the upper deck of the parking garage. After my husband called the front desk to notify them of the situation, we were promptly relocated to another room (that hadn't been used since the 70's because it was outdated and icky)! When I finally got to use the restroom, as there was no urine on this toilet seat this time, I noticed there was a used bar of soap on the sink and a wadded up wash cloth on the side of the sink (obviously the room had been used since the 70's, but maybe for just 7 minutes). We called again and not only demanded a new room, but a better room this time. We were told they were completely full and would not be able to move us until other guests began checking out the next day. Well, they finally moved us to a king-size, ocean view room the following day and it was a little better (still very outdated). I just couldn't believe it took that much feedback from us to finally get them to do something. After our experience at the Princess Kaiulani, we will never stay at a Sheraton again and I wouldn't recommend this hotel to anyone!

We arrived at the hotel, were well taken care of by the Hotel staff. The room faced the pool, and the music at night. We also used the facilities at the other Sheratons. (Beach.) The room was adquate, had all the amenities. The room was nice and clean. We also liked the fact that the hotel had one of the best shows on the beach. We would go back to the hotel again and again.

We spent 4 days here in August 2006, and wished we had gone elsewhere. Please when booking this hotel don't buy a room that states high escape ocean view. This is just a con by the tour operators. I found 1 room that had a view of the sea and all the other hotels in front. The rooms were nothing special, which dissapointed me as we had paid a lot of money for this hotel. Upon arrival we joined the masses! and queued. I was given a room with a balcony , but no sea view , you had to lean over the balcony and looked into everyone elses balcony if you were that lucky. I complained and was relocated to another room which had a sea view.( You can see a few palm trees and a bit of the sea)The room rate did not include breakfast which did annoy me. Everything at this hotel seems to be 'EXTRA', if you want to use the gym it costs, the safe in the room costs, parking costs $15 day. But the main factor was the noise. Every night there was karoke or another form of entertainment going on near the hotel and the noise travelled. We were awake until 2 am most nights and as a result got up later the next day. When checking out we were able to leave our bags and use the hotel pool, there was also a room to have a shower in before the flight. I would not stay here again and i would definately not recommend this hotel, there are other hotels which offer a better choice. Do not go for the brand name sheraton as i feel this is not a sheraton hotel with the standards i would expect. i prefered Aqual Palms with a 15 min walk to wakiki centre.

there were a couple of complaints. Yes, the walls are paper-thin and the baby next door was cranky. The sound from the nightly music by the pool floating up into the room was a treat at first, but when you're tired, you get out the ear plugs. The internet availability was limited to the lobby area, I couldn't send my pictures home easily. Workers were re-vamping some of the rooms on my floor, so no nap before the luau evening.The hotel was beautiful and the personnel very helpful, especially the concierge desk. The porters were extra nice. So, overall, my experience at this hotel gave me a good vacation.

this is my third year staying at the princess kaiulani. its a very nice place, they have a nice buffet every night, theres free entertainment every night, many positives with this hotel. the reason im writing this review is to advise that the sheraton advertising point of "stay at one, play at all" is false advertising. i heard it from the sheraton reservationist, the hotel tv channel, and its on the back of the sand chairs the princess kauilani gives out. nevertheless, when my wife and i attempted to sit on two lounge chairs at the sheraton moana surfrider, we were told we had get up by a very agressive cabana girl. and this when there many empty chairs. i did call the sheraton customer service # and they said the manager would call me, but of course no call was forthcoming.  so, enjoy the princess kauilani, but dont expect anything from the other sheratons across the street.

Stayed here for four nights following NCL cruise on Pride of Aloha. Hotel is in a good situation and was very friendly. We were on 7th floor in Princess Tower overlooking pool. Room was clean and tidy and the complimentary bottle of champagne to celebrate our 25th wedding anniversary was a lovely touch.The food was excellent. We are not well travelled people but I can honestly say I have no complaints about the hotel at all.

We stayed here for two nights on our way to the big island. The property has a great location, next door to the International Marketplace, just down the street from main area of Waikiki beach. My main complaint is that the cost of the room is far too high for the benefits. The room is what you'd expect at any family motel or hotel for under $80 a night, nothing special. For what I paid I should have been in the hotel across the street. The lobby and pool area are the only nice areas in the hotel. The foodservice at the hotel is average but the price is very high, as are the bar prices. The pool area is nice and we appreciated the live music and dancing while we were there. On the down side, the service from the two waitresses looking after the pool was incredibly bad. We waited to place an order, waited to get the order, waited to get the bill. It was laughable. The first time I tried to order from the bartender I was told I had to order from the waitress. It seemed to depend on the bar tender as later I was able to just pick up my drinks. No valet parking which wasn't a big problem but a bit time consuming. I wouldn't go back. There are better places to stay for the money.

We booked this through United Vacations and from the photos on the internet, we thought the rooms looked fine. We arrived on 22nd July and the room they allocated overlooked the car park and delivery area (very noisy). The room itself was like something from the 70s. The shelving and wardrobe area looked as if someone had built it themselves from white formica and the carpet was very worn. We complained and asked to pay for an upgraded room but had to stay one night in this horrible room. The room we were moved to was overlooking the pool and was a lot nicer but still very shabby for a Sheraton hotel. This hotel is screaming out for a refurbishment and although we did not let it spoil our holiday, I would not recommend this hotel to anyone.I would like to add that the staff were very friendly and helpful (apart from the bar tender who was not very friendly at all).

Stayed 2 nights early July, in the tower, 11th floor. We had 5 people in the room (ugh!) so it was tight with two double beds and a cot. Thank goodness we didn't spend much time in the room, except to sleep. Small bathroom and had to ask for extra towels each evening.Overlooked the International Market, but were high enough above it to not "hear" everything that went on there. Fellow on our floor had the drums beating into the night outside his window!! Even 11 floors up it was bad!No neighbours, so didn't have to deal with thin walls.Front desk and poolside staff okay, but not overly friendly. Pool side bartender great and introduced us to the "Lava Flow" drink which was fabulous! Loved the evening entertainment after 6:30, we sat around the pool to watch.The pool was nice, with the shallow end roped off for young children, and plenty of lounge chairs.Did not eat on property.Parking okay, at least they have their own lot nearby.For the money we spent I would not stay here again.

The location is excellent. Across the street from Dukes and the beach and just down the block from the Int'l Market Place. Parking, the lobby with free internet, the front desk personnel, the maids, and Angie, our waitress and the drinks at the poolside bar were great. I was given a fruit basket in the room that we really enjoyed.BUT.....It is a Sheraton, but it is a very old Sheraton in desperate need of renovation. Rooms are very small, carpet in the room was filthy, the furniture looked like something from Home Depot, and my lovely lanai on the backside of the hotel overlooked Sheraton's lovely, smelly trash bins. The drain plug for the tub was inoperative. The hotel caters mostly to Japanese tour groups. The pool closes at 6:30 PM. The Outriggers along the beach, the Hale Koa, and Hilton are well worth the extra money. I will never stay there again and would encourage all to stay elsewhere.

Note - if you like eavesdropping you'll love this hotel - yes, in the tower wing you can hear most comments from room next door. We had an unhappy couple with strong accent next door and the swear words and fighting came through fairly clearly. That and that the air conditioner barely cooled made this hotel not too hospitable. Maybe at least you'll have a more interesting roommate next door. Am sorry that loyalty to Starwood and modest price hooked on this hotel. Other guests have covered the hotel well, but the noise and lack of decent air conditioning need greater mention.

Luckily we only had to stay here for one night! The hotel is one of the older ones in Waikiki, which we didn't mind at all, BUT after we stepped out of the elevator on our floor (the 11th in the tower) we really were shocked at how old and worn everything was. Rugs, wall paper, signage...all really shabby. Our room was just as shabby, but even more unpleasant was the bathroom. Mildew was clearly evident on the ceiling above the tub (no fan in the bathroom!), the hand-held shower head was so grungy and probably 15 years old, the grout on the tile floor was really dingy, and the counter top looked slightly mildewed to where the top veneer seemed worn down. I really wished I had shower shoes to wear in there! and to make matters worse, our tub was clogged and didn't drain so the hotel plumber was sent up and spent an hour getting the clog half cleared for us! The rest of the room was okay, shabby like I said, but not as attrocious as the bathroom. the one grosser thing, however, about the bed was that our bed was short-sheeted! so there was 2 inches of exposed mattress and mattress pad (again, very old and gross looking). I slept with my feet on top of the top sheet! And of course removed the bed spread completely.At least we had a view, and it was only one night, but I would recommend you avoid this hotel unless you're a group of college kids looking for a lower priced room. Oh, and the location IS great, but I'd have gladly walked further to be able to enjoy a clean bathroom.

If you are looking for the basics this is for you. If you want any luxury you will be disappointed.Negatives - Very weak air conditioning. We had to change rooms 2 times. Then ordered an extra fan to boost power. I am a native Texan and can handle the heat. Bad sign. No elevator in the garage. So after parking we had to walk our luggage down the ramp 3 stories. Small rooms. Building is old and so is the decorPositives - clean, staff is friendly and responsive, great location.

Notes were taken from my disappointing stay here in late May, though I thought I'd let it go - here are some observations still recalled. Do you think hotels act on these reviews? When I filled out a computer survey of my visit expressing disappointment, I never rec'd follow up. Does that reveal anything?Am platinum level Starwood member, and room was not available for check in until 3 pm. Then at 3 pm, the special line for Platinum and Gold Starwood members was closed and there was an 8 minute wait in line to check in - you'd think loyal clients would get rooms prepared first.So during the wait I paid for internet wi-fi access about $13 - then discovered it's only good (at best) in the busy, noisy lobby area - not in the room!! That's not clear when you sign up and pay the fee. There is no high speed internet access in the rooms.The management doesn't care about the guests very much - the clientele is largely Japanese groups. "Turn em and burn em" is a hospitality industry term. Room door had smudges, air conditioner didn't work properly and when reported someone came up, tried fixing it and nothing could be done until next day, so instead of sleeping with the patio door open to the noisy sounds of Waikiki, the sleep was in 74 degree heat. Room was changed next day. No accommodation for the discomfort - nor did I ask - if they don't have the courtesy to offer, am not going to request it. Yes, parking is inconvenient - I wondered what elderly banquet clients do - no valet parking and access to elevators and hotel takes more effort than many are capable of. This is not hospitable.The smell of the foods in the buffet get strong - and one has to cross this area to get to the tower rooms - it's not welcoming. The smell of fish on the seafood buffet is unpleasant.  The doormen and bellmen are helpful, seasoned, really nice. Some of the front desk staff are terrific and probably embarrassed by the level of service. Haircut at the hotel was pleasant experience. $3 for use of in room safe - ??? Come on.This is a huge hotel - no room service after 9 pm?Yes, breakfast across the street and at Cheeseburger in Paradise are also good and with ocean views, but the breakfast buffet is good quality here. Breakfast buffet is good - Patty was especially accommodating waitperson - many of the employees of the hotel have been there 20- 30 years. That made quite an impression - one employee had his last day after 40 years the day we were there.There must be better values close by - this is not a hospitable, accommodating place of Aloha - it's a discredit to Sheraton Hotels - you might feel 'taken' with the service and blah rooms. Maybe with more feedback they'll upgrade this hotel.

We stayed at the Sheraton Princess Kaiulani June 26-July 3rd, 2006 and I wouldn't do it again. The place is worn down and tired with it's carpet from the 80's and small rooms with paper-thin walls. We stayed in the main part of the hotel on the 8th floor ... I guess the 'towers' are newer and a little nicer (or so they claim) but they didn't look much nicer to me. Our travel agent told us that free parking was included, which is typical at the nicer hotels, but we got there to a snooty receptionist that informed us that they charge their guests $10 a day to park in their POS parking garage with no elevators and then they reserve half of the first floor for their employees so ALL guests are walking and most are trekking up and down stairs. The restaurants are nice and you can use any of the neighboring (MUCH nicer) Sheraton hotel restaurants and charge it directly to your room. Sadly enough, they consider this perk one of the great benefits of staying in their hotel. If you get a chance to stay at any of the other three Sheratons on the same block, I highly recommend it. We could hear everything from our neighbor's room ... we heard their afternoon chats, their party and every TV show that they watched. Luckily, we didn't stay in the room much but with 3 different groups in that room while we were there, and none of them overly loud, we heard each one of them so it wasn't just a case of one loud neighbor. The one group that threw the party even invited us over because they knew that the walls were thin and they planned on making some noise ... we declined but appreciated the offer and took a midnight stroll on the beach instead. The best thing you can say about the hotel is that it is centrally located on Waikiki beach. If you get bored, or can't sleep because of all the noise, just step out the front door of the hotel and you are on the main drag and a great touristy-type surfing area with rental boards and all is located right across the street. Some websites, and our travel agent (Our ex-travel agent) rated this as a 4-Star hotel ... that's not even close to the truth. It's a 3-star at best. They claim to be cheaper than the other hotels in that area but that's like comparing apples to oranges. They ARE cheaper than their neighboring competition but that's because they're not as good as the hotels that they're comparing themselves to ... they compare their prices to 5-star hotels across the street ON the beach. If you think you found an awesome hotspot at a great price then keep looking because you'll only be disaapointed. I also found it interesting that the hotel's comment service on their TV didn't work and when I asked for a comment card at the front desk they couldn't seem to find one ... so I wrote my comments on a post-it note and gave it to them. Speaking of which, we voiced our concerns only about items that we felt management would be able to correct, in order to avoid sounding like a whining guest and in return we were treated like a whining guest complete with rolling eyes and deep sighs. Nothing was done ... not a shocker at all. Overall, we had one of the best vacations of our lives but that was no thanks to anything the folks at this hotel provided. We spent very little time in our room, which is a good thing while you're in Hawaii, and we enjoyed ourselves immensely. Go to Hawaii and have a good time, but if you're looking at the Sheraton Princess Kiaulani for a room you might as well save some money by booking a complete dive and avoid the let-down. This place was not very Sheraton-like at all.

On arrival, we were well catered for, we were given a room on the 27th Floor of the Tower and had a good view of the beach to the right of the balcony, we had booked a standard room but were upgraded due to my husbands 40th birthday, we stayed one night and then came back after our cruise, we were then placed in the standard room overlooking the carpark, this room was in need of refurbishment and was a bit of a let down but you get what you pay for, it was fine for our needs, we were not there to stay in our room all day. The seafood buffet looked great but pricey so we opted to eat outside. International marketplace and the cheesecake factory were nearby. Would stay again but probably try somewhere else next time.

My wife is from Hawaii so we visit at least two to three times a year. Normally we stay at the Outrigger on the beach (right accross the street from the Princeess Kaiulani) and have had absolutely great service.We booked a last minute trip for June 2006 at the Princess Kaiulani and found the experience dissappointing.The main problems:1. Parking has no valet, and the first side of the paring structure has no elevators, so you could end up climbing 5 flights of stairs to get to your car. It wasn't until our second day there that another guest told us to drive to the top of this parking structure and then drive to an adjacent lot that provided access to elevators. It would have been nice if the hotel could have communicated this in the beginning.2. Any item billed to your room is sent for a credit authorization of the original dollar amount times the amount of days you are staying. For example, our parking was $70 so the cc authorization was $70 x 7 days or $490. We had room service the first night for $108, so that authorized $108 x 7 or $ 756. They had tied up over $1200 of our money in two transactions. This is obviously not something they tell you at check-in so be aware.3. The pool was shut down two days due to contamination.4. Small room, small tv, small fridge.5. They charge extra for items we received free at the Outrigger on the Beach i.e. $3 for the safe, bottled water (complamentary at the Outrigger).On the plus side:1. The hotel did make an effort to resolve the credit authorization problem.2. The staff was polite.3. This hotel is centrally located4. The rooms are ok -definately not as nice as the review pictures.We are scheduled to go back to Hawaii in October and had originally booked this Princess Kaiulani hotel. When we had problems I called our travel agent and switched hotels back to the Outrigger on the Beach. I sure we will enjoy our stay much better at the Outrigger.

We stayed here for 2 nights on the 6th floor in a room overlooking a carpark at the back of the hotel. I guess the only positive side to this was there was little noise from the street.The room was tiny and had 2 small double beds crammed into it, with no room to store our suitcases. The decor was dated and in need of a mafor refit. We didn't bother with the $20 breakfast at the hotel- overpriced, but opted to buy fruit salads from the ABC stores- cheaper and healthier than all you can eat buffets!The hotel was in a good location and there were always plenty of people around at all times of the day and night. Be aware that the street along the side of the hotel is a prostitute pick up point at night.I would not stay here again.

We had a two night pre-cruise stay at the hotel. It was very clean and comfortable and the location is great! You are just steps away from Waikiki Beach, restaurants, shops, the International Market,etc. The bed had a beautiful red & white Hawaiian quilt on it. There is entertainment nightly by the pool. We really enjoyed it and I would stay here again.

We arrived to book in and where told our rooms where not ready at 1pm. We where asked to come back at 3pm which we did and they still were not ready. We where given a drinks voucher to thank us for being patient. That was a nice touch. We where given our room keys about 30 minutes later and made our way to the elevator. As soon as I stepped into the elevator I knew that this was not going to be good. There was a musty smell about it. We got onto our floor (9th) and it was apparent that this was the original part of the hotel. The carpets where old and worn, the walls where much the same and there was that musty smell. We gingerly opened the door to our room and it was just as I expected. It had a musty smell for starters, the room was tiny, it had 2 double beds and very little else. There was not enough room to store our suitcases on the floor, we had to double up so we could walk through the room without banging our shins on the furniture. Our view was overlooking part of the city. The bathroom was small and poorly decorated, there where cracks in the walls and the wallpaper was peeling off. The sliding door to the balcony kept coming off the runner and I could not open it or shut it without my husbands help. I was terribly disappointed and decided to let them know. The sheraton have a policy that states " if you are not happy, then just say so". I called the customer relations number and told the lady of my concerns. She asked if I wanted to put my complaint in writing. I said I would like something done about our room. She replied that I needed to speak to the room manager, so I was put on hold for about ten minutes and then was told that he was busy and he would call me back. I waited for half an hour and the call came. I explained how disappointed I was and with 3 people in the room it was very uncomfortable. He offered to send a maintenance person up to address my concerns but also said he could upgrade us to a pool view room that was a tiny bit bigger at a cost. This was not what I expected and we refused the costly upgrade. My son was also disappointed with his room. He found pubic hair in the bath. They sent someone to fix his problem. The location of this hotel was excellent but I would never stay here again.

This hotel was reasonably priced and in a great location. Our room was fairly spacious (we were travelling with a toddler and had a crib in the room). While it could have used some updating, it was clean and safe. We were upgraded to a partial ocean view on the 6th floor and had a lanai overlooking the pool. The music was loud with the door open, but with the door closed, the noise was not a problem at all. I would stay here again.

We stayed at the Princess Kaiulani last week (5/4-5/12). The hotel is very centrally located to Waikiki Beach. The area where Waikiki beach is unobstructed by all the oceanfront hotels is less than half a block away. Trust me, if you want to get to the beach and you aren't staying in one of the oceanfront hotels it can be a real chore. It's also centrally located to all kinds of shopping, Coach, Chanel, Dior, and other high end shops are right down the street. The hotel is also right next door to the International Marketplace. This was not so good. Don't be fooled by the name, it is a total tourist trap. It also happens to be the gathering place for a number of street performers, a couple of whom bang on drums until 12-1am in the morning every night. Even on the 16th floor the drums were rather loud and sometimes made it hard to get to sleep. The lobby area was open air and looked out over the pool which was very nice. There were plenty of chairs around the pool and there was also a nice lounge/restaurant area around the pool. The lounge served a $20 breakfast buffet every morning, overpriced for breakfast if you ask me. We went across the street to the Hula Grill for breakfast, it was less expensive, had great food, and a fantastic view of the ocean. They also served dinner buffet style or a la carte. Either way, at $33-35 for the buffet and $17+ for entrees it was also overpriced. If you intend on staying near the hotel for lunch/dinner, I suggest Duke's which is across the street a level below the Hula Grill. Now to the room, for $200/night I expected a little more, but based in comparison pricing for hotel rooms, $200/night doesn't get you much in Hawaii. At $200/night we've stayed in much, much nicer rooms/hotels than this. The room was a little small and the decorating was dated, but all in all it was acceptable. We had a partial ocean view room and the view was spectacular. We got lucky and had a room right on the corner of the hotel closest to the water so I can't guarantee all partial ocean vews are this good, but ours could just as well have been a full ocean view. The maid service wasn't great, they forgot to refill our coffee, replace towels, vaccuum, or take used dishes on different occasions. Other than that the staff was courteous and very helpful with directions, etc. Overall, the hotel was adequate. We got about what we expected and I would say at this price range it's a fairly safe choice.

I was shocked at the condition of this Sheraton location. It has not had any updating in a long-long time. All I could think of when I entered my room was the Brady Bunch scene with the tarantula in the room while they were in Hawaii. I didn't have any encounters with tarantulas but they have roaches. The bedspread was dirty and even on the 11th floor the room was extremely noisy. In addition, they only have dial up and if you need high speed; you'll need to truck it to the main lobby. Do not eat at this hotel - the food is not very good and is overpriced. Duke's across the street is great and they have a bar right on the beach. If you want breakfast (at breakfast prices) walk towards the back of the hotel from the main entrance and there is an Outrigger on the corner with a restaurant on the corner that has a nice Island breakfast for around $7.00 a far cry from the crummy buffet at the Kaiulani which is offered at $20. There are a couple of Hotels directly across the street which are much nicer. One of them is also a Sheraton - much more of what you would expect.

This was a great trip... I traveled with the Habersham Central Band of Blue from Georgia and I had the most fun ever. I have never experienced a trip like this one and the service at the Hotel was great... I will be visiting again real SOON!! Thanks so much, Tara

We went to Honolulu during the school spring break about two weeks ago. This was our first time visit Hawaii with three small children(7, 4 &1). We stayed in Sheraton Princess Kaiulani Hotel and we loved it. We had a one bedroom suite with two double beds on 10th floor with both ocean and city view. The hotel is clean and convenient. The room had a fridge and and sink area with coffee maker. It has cabinet above the sink area for storage and it's a big plus for famiy with infant or toddler to put the bottles, baby food for drinks. The bathroom is large enough to let our whole family staying inside to watch my little one bathing. There is a closet with sliding door which I have not seen before. It's very thoughtful. We tried the hotel's breakfast buffet and everything was fresh made. The kids ate free and you paid for adults only. The eating area is outdoor next to the pool. The only thing I would compliant was the birds would fly or around the eating area. It's little bit annoying but the lovely food and weather could make it up.The location of the hotel is great, you don't need a car at all. International Market Place and Waikiki beach are only few minutes walking away. You can get some less expensive but still delicious Japanese and Korean food in the food court at International Maket Place. We will definitely come back to this hotel next time. We had a good experience and fun time there.I

It was our first time in Hawaii and we wanted everything to be somewhat perfect. Our stay at the Sheraton PK was not only enjoyable but entertaining. We stayed from April 12 until April 20 and we were sad to go home. The staff were very friendly and helpful. We stayed on the 10th floor towards the parking area and it was very peaceful. We had a great view of the mountains and a balcony to look out on. Like everywhere else in Waikiki the prices on food are a bit expensive, but the food within the PK was very good and organized. It is right in the middle of the action, right next to the famed International Market and half a block away from the statue of the Big Kahuna and the beach. All in all we loved our stay in Waikiki and staying in a hospitable hotel makes it more delightful. We wil stay here again!

This was an excellent hotel. It had a great price considering what other hotels were charging and some of those were not on the beach either. I felt that the room was a good size. There was almost no noise. It was not on the beach but very close. Overall this is a great hotel to stay at.

The only reason I would not rate this as excellent is because it's not on the beach, but across the street is good enough. After reading some of the negative reviews, I was a little curious as to what we got ourselves into. Worry not, this place is great! We booked via Travelocity and were upgraded to city view upon arrival. A city view room is very roomy, gives you a small view of the ocean (lower floor) and a great view of the pool/entertainment stage. The entertainment stage is great in the evening when you want to relax on your balcony with a mai tai and listen to the band and hula dancers below, the show was great. Location can't be beat, restaurants everywhere, Duke's and Chuck's Steak House across the street and it has a food court next to the pool for early morning coffee and breakfast. Would not think twice about staying here, unless I desire a beach front hotel, which I doubt. Stay here.

I just returned from Waikiki in April 2006. We stayed at the Prince Kaiulani and had a great time. This is a very clean and reasonably priced hotel for waikiki. The best features are the price, people (very friendly) and the service. The only thing that was not that great was the food (breakfast buffet).Its overpriced and not worth your money. If your looking for a great breakfast at reasonable price, go to the Hula Grill right across the street above Dukes. They have excellent pancakes and the view is unbeatable. Another small downfall is the lack of internet access in your room. They do have a computer room with 4 computers, but you may have to wait a few minutes to use one. Other than that, I would certainly recommend this place for the money if you don't have $300 a night to blow on a room.

We stayed at the Kaiulani from March21-April 4th this year. Check in was a snap, and we were upgraded to a deluxe ocean view in the Princess wing , on the 9th floor. The room was a tad small, but clean and nicely furnished with two doubles and a sofa bed.We discovered that the pillows were feather,my husand is allergic. Housekeeping had replacement pillows sent up with 10 minutes!!! The staff, from front desk, to housekeeping to maintenance to pool desk were very friendly and helpful. Our housekeeper was wonderful as well. She kept the room immaculate, even washing and drying our personal drinking glasses we brought from home.I didn't like the prices at the restaurant. We never ate there. And the pool side drinks were a$tronomical!! The beds were very uncomfortable, I had to double up the bedspreads and put them under the bottom sheet to make things a little more softer. And I guess the first few days we had no neighbours, but on night 3 or 4 we heard a guy snoring, and a phone ringing that never got answered. Then we heard a baby cry for an extended amount of time too. They sounds were very clear. And the street noise is very loud. I agree with the other poster. There was a drummer outside that banged those $%$% drums every time somebody put money in his hat!! We were tempted to pay him $50 to move to another block!!! Like I said the staff are exceptional, but the noise was a little too much, and the beds too hard. I would probably not stay here again, unless of course, they replaced the mattresses, and worked on some sound proofing.

We just returned from a week in Hawaii. It had been over 30 years since my wife and I had been there so we decided to go to Waikiki. We chose the PK because of it's location - right across the road from the beach and in the centre of Waikiki.We can't blame the hotel for the weather (it rained every day). Our room was classified as a "high ocean view" room". When we first checked in our room was on the 23rd floor facing downtown with a view of the International Marketplace. I checked to see if we could see a couple of other rooms and the desk staff were only too helpful. We decided on a room on the 15th floor facing Diamond Head. It was right on the corner of the building overlooking Kalakaua Avenue. Please note if you have a room overlooking a main street there is noise 24 hours a day. Again this is no reflection on the hotel itself but just an observation. Garbage and delivery trucks operate all night on the strip and the buskers are out until at least 11pm. (a particularly annoying drummer took up residence right outside our window)We were disappointed in the restaurant and bar facilities at the hotel. The hotel only offered a buffet for both breakfast and dinner with table service for lunch. Neither my wife and I are fans of buffets so we found a great restaurant up the street that served a great breakfast at a reasonable price. For dinner we tried all sorts of different restaurants. The bar did not have the ambiance that I would expect from a hotel in Waikiki. Again we went to different restaurants on the strip for afternoon drinks and pupus.The hotel staff were great and the lady that cleaned our room every morning was fantastic. If she saw us going out for our walk in the morning she made sure the room was cleaned up before we got back. If we had any special requests she made sure we were looked after.The room itself was fine. We could hear a bit of noise from our next door neighbours but nothing outrageous.We had a great view in a fantastic location. Our next trip will probably take us to somewhere quieter but I think we got what we paid for on this trip.

I stayed at the PK with my 10 year old daughter. We were in room 518 on a non-smoking floor. (We moved from 602 where we could smell smoke from next door...so be sure to specify). The lanai had a table and 2 chairs and overlooked the pool. The room decor was white with a traditional Hawaiian quilt on the king bed, and a print of hibiscus. Clean and simple. Shower had good pressure, lots of hot water. Maid service excellent.I liked the casual welcome of this hotel. We set up by the pool in the morning, and then came and went all day long. Front desk, lounge and poolside staff were all very pleasant. The PK has an old world charm that I enjoyed, and is conveniently located.

We loved the location. Right in the heart of Waikiki. Our balcony overlooked the IMP. We could see the ocean to the left and the mountains to the right.A lot of this hotel is kinda dated, but great service, housekeeping, front desk. We would definitely stay again.

What a misery, old, ugly, dirty, so tiny,you don't want to go to the room! The name needs to change from Sheraton to Motel 6! No way I will ever stay in this hotel again. I would rather sleep out in the beach under the stars. No high speed internet, staff who didn't even care to ask how we liked the room. You will be making a big mistake staying in this hotel. The picture from the outside looks good and so does th pool area but wait until you go to your room! Shameful!

Good basic hotel. Great location and service for the price. It's just across the street from Waikiki and wallking distance to many restaurants and clubs. We paid $140 and were upgraded to a partial ocean view. I probably wouldn't pay much more than that. This is not a luxuary hotel, but pleasant and clean. This is not the type of place where you get mints on your pillow or a fancy waterfall in the pool. Room decor was not my taste, but most of the hotels in Waikiki are somewhat dated unless you're going for a luxury hotel. Room service was available only certain times of the day, but we prefer to go out most of the time. There was a slight musty smell in the hallways, but I wrote that off to the humidity. Rooms were clean and lobby areas are nice. Restaurants on the property are quite expensive, so never ate at any of them. All in all, we enjoyed our stay

We have just returned from staying at the Princess Kaiulani and would not hesitate to stay there again. The staff were most accomodating for us - the front desk, the restaurant staff, the pool staff and the concierge(s). The food was excellent - we had 2 breakfasts, a lunch on the terrace by the pool and enjoyed the seafood buffet on our last night there. The location is fantastic - yes it will be a bit noisy - you are in the middle of Waikiki after all. The nightly entertainment was lovely and we enjoyed hearing it in our room in the evening. Our room was a king and while it is not huge it was certainly functional for us. We had the pleasure of being on the 21st floor with ocean view - terrific! And I love the little touches they do such as changing the quilted wall hangings in the elevators from "Good Morning" to "Good Afternoon" to "Good Evening", each with the appropriate Hawaiian translation. Attention to detail is present everywhere.

We stayed three nights at this property as part of a conference. It is perfectly situated in the heart of Wakiki. The room was okay. Sheraton advertises a Sweet Sleeper Bed but ours was no better than what you would find at a Motel 6. The mattresses were yellowed and obviously very old. The Princess Food Court is a fairly inexpensive place to eat and a great place to people watch sitting on the corner of the street.Other reviews mention concerns about prostitutes in front of the hotel. That is totally true. If you are traveling with children or are sensitive to some of the seedier aspects of a big city, this may not necessarily be your best choice. Neither the HPD or staff at the hotel seem very concerned that these women are working their streets.Overall, we might stay here again because of the location and pricing, but not because of the property itself.

I stayed here seven nights while attending a conference at the convention center. The room was a bit smaller than the typical hotel room, but it was clean and looked well kept. The hallways smelled a little funky, but tolerable. The first floor (lobby, restaurant, shops) were all nicely decorated and clean. The staff was very welcoming and helpful. My view (20th floor) looked west to north and was pretty nice. Knowing the area, I knew I wasn't going to have too much of an ocean view. Location in downtown Waikiki can't be beat. You're right across the street from Duke's bar and the Mai Tai bar at the Royal Hawaiian! Easy walk to the beach and the aquarium (highly recommend!). The hike to the convention center is not horrible, but longer than I anticipated, especially in long pants at 2:00 in the afternoon. A nice place and I would probably stay there again.

We paid about $150 a night, which is very reasonable for a hotel just across the street from the Waikiki beachfront. So I was prepared to be disappointed by the room -- but I wasn't at all. True, we didn't have an ocean view, but it was nicely furnished and clean. The staff was pleasant and helpful, too.

I just spent 6 nights at the Sheraton Princess Kaiulani and we loved it! It's in a great location for walking in both directions and the staff was extremely friendly to us! They helped us out with all of our questions and were very knowledgable.Our room was very clean and we heard no noise at all! We were on the 7th floor and the room was fine for us. We didn't have a great view but that was okay because we weren't there to spend all of our time in a hotel room we were spending it outside enjoying the sights.We didn't see many people using the pool at all but the ocean is actually warmer than the pool.

For a Starwood/Sheraton hotel I was rather disappointed by this place.I spend plenty of time before going on vacations researching hotels because I never want to end up with a poor quality one. This hotel was the first one I missed the mark on. Based on location, cost, photographs, and previous reviews I was certain that this hotel would be a good one, but I wasn't that impressed.The staff is very friendly and courteous, which was a plus, but friendly staff doesn't make up for the rock hard mattresses and moldy washrooms. My room was on the 14th floor (Starwood Preferred Guest floor) but was noisy at all hours of the day and night. They have some kind of music playing from about 9:00 pm until some hour of the night (I always was able to somehow fall asleep while it was still blasting) and the sounds of traffic and people are very irritating.I never utilized the pool since it was always packed full of people, so instead of swimming shoulder to shoulder with all the other SPK guests, I opted to spend time elsewhere.The one good thing about this place is the access to all of Waikiki, which is very convienient. It is within walking distance to so many things (Zoo, Kapiolani park, aquarium, Waikiki beaches, restaurants, shops, Internation marketplace, etc.) which really cut back on the taxi fares that I broke my bank on when I stayed at the Hilton Hawaiian Village, which for $40/night more is far superior and recommended by me.I wouldn't return to the Sheraton Princess Kaiulani again if I were to go back to Waikiki, I would rather re-do my research and find another place to stay since I wouldn't think it would be that difficult to find something more satisfactory.

My wife and I stayed here for a surprise birthday trip that she arranged. When we checked in, we were immediately upgraded to a partial ocean view.. WOWThat afternoon when my wife stepped out of the shower the towel rack came out of the wall.. when i called the front desk to tell them what happened, they immediately upgraded us to the 29th Floor and a HUGE suite. By far the BEST customer service i have EVER had in a hotel. And I LOVE disney.. and this was better then disney.

Was a little nervous to stay here after reading some of the reviews, but was pleasantly surprised. This hotel is right in the middle of everything. Just a block from the beach, across from the Sheraton Moana, next to the Hyatt and 1/3 of the price! We walked across the street and went surfing; walked up the beach and had Mai Tais at the Royal Hawaiian, and had dinner at Dukes at the Outrigger. Our room was always clean, and the lobby and buffett areas were very nice. We spent New Years eve on Waikiki Beach, and it was so nice to walk away from the crowds and just sneak back to our hotel across the street. The pool was nice and clean and you just have to walk across the corner to the ABC store for shopping. Highly recommend!

I really enjoyed my time at the Princess. It had a great location and was very comfortable. My room was a bit on the small side but that was not a great concern of mine. Most of the trip we were on the beach and doing tours. But, when we went back to the room I found it clean, neat, and pleasant. The hotel, while not on the beach, was perfect for us. The beach was only a block down the street (if that) and we found the lobby and service to be top notch.

The hotel was excellent, wonderful service, very clean and well kept rooms. It deserves a 5 star rather than a 3 star rating. We were there during Christmas, the lobby and restuarant decor were wonderful. Of all the Honolulu hotels we have stayed during numerous trips this one has been the best.

stayed at the pk with my elderly mother the week of december 1-8, 2005 - it was with great trepidation that i booked this property based on the reviews, but my mother loves being in the heart of the action, and with the pk's location next to the international marketplace and across kalakaua from the moana surfrider, the pk seemed like the perfect choice for the money. we had a partial ocean view room in the ainahau tower - the rooms in this tower are newer and were clean and comfortable. all the employees were absolutely wonderful and went out of their way to be helpful, especially with the hospitality suite on our final day since we were returning on a redeye flight. would stay at the pk again anytime we're in honolulu. if you go to waikiki, be sure to catch the free hula halau nightly from 6-7 pm at kuhio beach park - a 3 minute walk down kalakaua ave. from the pk (towards diamond head.)

Have just spent 7 nights at the Sheraton PK. Not sure about all wings of accommodation, but we had rooms on 23 and 20 floors. Decor was a little dated, but King beds were so comfortable, rooms very clean, air conditioning units very effective, views amazing and the hotel location was awesome. Housekeeping staff were excellent and very friendly. Front desk staff okay, but the poolside restaurant and bar staff could do with a shake up! We never had problems having to wait on the lifts, the four in our wing worked very efficiently.We live at the beach in NZ and there are no ocean views at night, so really appreciated the views of the ocean during the day and the activity and lights after dark. We did not have any traffic noise at night on 23rd floor.We tried a couple of breakfast venues, but settled on Duke's and Shore Bird as value for money and catering to our tastes. Evening meal choice limitless, but our favourite was Diamond Head Grill in the W hotel, food excellent, service brilliant - good value.This was our 3rd trip to this Island and we will definitely be staying at the Sheraton PK again next time.

I stayed at the Sheraton PK with my wife and 1 year old daughter for a week in a Ocean View Room on the 24th floor. Being a Sheraton hotel I expected a little nicer place, but I guess a lot of hotels in Waikiki seem a little run down. Not exactly what I expected but the reviews I read had some truths and fallacies about them. I will begin by saying the staff is very friendly and try and accommodate every need. I read a lot of the reviews and decided for the price and location I would go with the PK, if I had to do it again I would stay at the Sheraton Waikiki instead. The hotel is a little dated and the rooms are really bland and the beds are the most uncomfortable beds I have ever experienced at a Sheraton. Clearly this Sheraton is not a part of the Heavenly sleep program. It is a good clean hotel and centrally located to everything, next to the International Market place, across the street from the beach, has a food court next to the pool and right in the middle of bars and restaurants. I visited the other 3 Sheratons and after accessing the amenities and cost I believe the Sheraton Waikiki is the best choice. The Surfrider is a beautiful hotel but not worth the price. The Royal Hawaiian seemed like a pink funhouse...couldn't wait to get out of there and the Sheraton Waikiki seemed it was the best all around for price, amenities and location.

I was in Hawaii for my best friend's wedding and stayed at the Sheraton Waikiki for 3 nights and had to move to the Kaiulani for the final night (the Waikiki one was sold out the final night). After spending 3 blissful days at a beautiful hotel with their signature heavenly bed (aahh), I ended up moving over to this dump of a hotel. The price difference was only about $35 a night but it felt like you dropped 3 stars in hotel class.Where to begin.. the hotel seems pretty old and not maintained well. After check in, the elevators are tiny and there's only a few, so the wait is long. My room had a standard foam mattress with the thin mattress cover/blankets you find at cheap motels. The bathroom was extremely tiny with a sliding door and the showerhead and tiles looked incredibly dirty. I really felt grossed out by them. The worst part is, there was a mosquito in my room and after spending 40 minutes (unsuccessfully) swatting at it, I gave up and had to endure this unwelcomed guest. After talking to some other friends that ended up there, I found out that I was actually "upgraded" due to my starwood status as my room had a small couch and a balcony overlooking the pool. I checked out the "standard" room and it's even worse. Never again... for the type of money you'll spend going to Hawaii, you want to feel relaxed and comfortable at the hotel. For $35 bucks more, go to the Sheraton Waikiki, I highly recommend that hotel!

My first time in Hawaii and I was sorely disapointed in the hotel Im afraid to say! The decor was extremely dated and the rooms, although sufficient, were really bland and grey. We overlooked a side street which was very noisy from 5.30am onwards (and Im not a light sleeper!) When asked could we move to a different part of the hotel after two days with very little sleep we were told the place was full up. Not very conducive to a good honeymoon!!! The pool area and bar were nice and the restaurant food was good value and very tasty. Location was great aside from the scary prostitutes in the evening. If returning to Waikiki will be looking at alternative accommodation.

We recently got married and had flown to Maui to honeymoon and planned on staying at the PK for the night before we flew back to the main land. When we got to Maui, we hated the location of the cottage we rented and said "Screw it" so we flew back to Oahu and extended our stay at the PK from 1 night to 5 nights. In hindsight, that was the second best decision we made right after our first decision to get married in Oahu. We totally loved our time at PK. We really, really loved the band that played at night. We would sit on our lanai and just listen to the great music the band played which ranged from Hawaiian to contemporary songs. We so enjoyed the music that we spent out last night at the hotel downstairs by the bar to actually see the band play (we would have sat in the lounge chairs by the pool like we did the night before, but it sprinkled that night). Along with the music, we had a great view from our room of the pool and the street. Although we were not on the beach, I thought that our location was perfect because we could just walk across the street to the beach and there were so many places to shop and eat around us that we didn't miss the beach that much. The hotel is also next to the International Marketplace and we practically went there everyday to shop and eat. We totally loved the little sushi place in the food court at the Marketplace. It was cheap and the quality of the fish was awesome. Although we didn't eat at PK, we totally enjoyed our stay and the friendliness of the staff and the excellent location. Overall, we could not have asked for a better place to stay. On our next trip, we would definitely stay at PK!!! Plus it's a Starwood hotel so we got lots of points that we will definitely use when we stay the PK again.

The location cannot be beat! You are steps from the beach, the International Market Place and only a short walk to the Honolulu Zoo. The staff is helpful. Being Starwood members , we were upgraded from standard parking lot view to pool and partial ocean view. The breakfast buffet was great and kick started our day. We were able to walk everywhere or hop on the Wakiki Trolley which was great. When we had drinks by the pool, it afforded us the ability to interact with the staff and get some great Oahu tips for our vacation. Listening to the music at the pool from our lanai was fabulous and NOT annoying. If you do not like Hawaiian music ...do not come to Hawaii. Being able to go to any of the Sheratons and sign was also helpful. We would cross the street and go to the Moana Surfrider and have drinks, listen to the music, and watch the ocean. We also went to the MaiTai Bar at the Royal Hawaiian which was awesome. If you can't be happy here..you probably aren't very happy anywhere.Aloha & we will be back

I stayed here for three nights whilst on my way to Canada from Australia. I found nearly everything pleasant and the location was practically on Waikiki Beach. I had booked a standard room but was upgraded on arrival to a part ocean view room/balconey. The hotel's buffet style breakfast was a bit too pricey for my budget so usually breakfasted at the Baskin Robbins icecream place come cafe, just down the road from the hotel. Prices for brekky (good sized portions) most reasonable at approx. $8 US, plus tax of course! The only gripe I had about the hotel was the lack of an electric jug to boil water for my early morning cuppa (being Aussie). A coffee percolator was provided which warmed the water but not hot enough for tea. I also noticed 4 hookers or 'ladies of the night' as we call them in Oz, just down from the hotel and was told that they 'hang out' there to attract Japanese businessmen who frequent the hotel. I found this curious considering that there was a police station just across the road on Waikiki Beach.

Great location short walk to the beach. Our room was musty. I asked for a new room and was told it was sold out. They sprayed some kind of fragrance to appease us but the smell came back within an hour. Would not stay there again.

I had a nice room on the 25th floor of the Ainahau tower, which is the tallest of the three towers. The room was very clean and I had a balcony. I noticed a chambermaid spraying disinfectant on the telephone and cleaning it with a small brush -- I was impressed and I wonder how many hotels do that as part of their regular routine. The decor was fine, and the view was unbelievable, of both the ocean and the rest of Waikiki. If you stay here, it might be worth paying more for a room with a great view. (Mine was described on the website as "1 king, ocean view, 282 sq ft.") Some cheaper rooms look onto a parking garage and nothing else, although those rooms probably get less exterior noise than mine.I thought the staff had a great attitude. I wish I could remember the guy who checked me in and checked me out, beause he seemed to genuinely enjoy interacting with customers. I wonder if some of the negative reviews here are because customers are reacting to the fact that the overwhelming majority of tourists are visitors from Japan and the people who live in Hawaii are overwhelmingly Asian-American. Deal with it or stay home.The location is very urban, which is what I wanted, with buildings packed together closely and the sidewalk at the front entrance. You cross the street to go to the beach. If you want a self-contained beachfront resort with more green space, try a place in western Waikiki such as the Sheraton Waikiki or the Hilton Village.Negatives: Some people might enjoy the free nightly show by the pool by a lounge singer, but it drove me up the wall! I hated the music. Even with my balcony door closed, the overamplified music reverberated through the room making it impossible to do things like watch TV, and this went on until 10 or 11. Noise from the adjoining room, filtering through a connecting door, was also a big headache even though my neighbor wasn't doing anything out of line. For some reason this particular block attracts prostitutes who are very aggressive toward solo male pedestrians after 10pm, even when in sight of police officers! My biggest gripe is that the room a/c was insufficient to cool down the room -- don't believe the nonsense about "cooling ocean breezes" (although I was there in August).

We booked this trip last minute and we scored a great deal with this hotel. We upgraded to the High Ocean View, which, if the Hyatt Regency Tower was removed, we would have had a great view of Diamond Head. Still it was a great room and we are pleased to report the Kaiulani did not disappoint.The staff was most courteous and acommodating, there was a minor mix up with our room but it was handled in an expedient manner.The room was clean and bright, the bed very comfortable. The hotel provided us with a coffee maker and a refrigerator. We had a walk out balcony where we spent several evenings listening to the music coming from the lounge (they stop the music by 10PM). The A/C is efficient, but we found we were able to shut it off at night and leave the sliding door open to let the trade winds blow through and cool the room.On June 11, 1955, the hotel opened it's doors. Built by the Matson Navigation Company on the grounds of the Princess Victoria Kaiulani's palace, Ainahau. Kaiulani was Hawaii's last and most loved princess, who died at an early age of 23.It is apparent that the spirit of Kaiulani still exists throughut the hotel. The lobby of the hotel was beautiful. Many artifacts from the Princess Victoria Kaiulani's life were all about the hotel. Many photographs and oil paintings deicting the Princess and her life.Every morning in the lobby, local artisans will come and display their wares: Local flowers woven into leis, a ukelele maker, and other various sorts of arts and crafts.The hotel is centrally located to many areas of interest and the neighborhood in which it sits is quite safe for those who may be traveling alone.The hotel also offers a "hospitality suite" for those who check out early but have a late departure time the Kaiulani provides a room for travelers to take a shower or just kick back unil your departure time. It is "First Come First Serve". There is also a computer center with free internet access. They ask when it is busy to please restrict your self to 15 minutes use.Prices:US$120-180

Stayed at the Princess Kaiulani again for this year's trip to Hawaii. Loved it as much as last year. This hotel has a beautiful lobby, nice pool area, rooms that go from small to large (some with a crappy view of the parking structure, some with a great view of Waikiki), and LOCATION, LOCATION, LOCATION at a GREAT price. If you're on a budget that allows for a mid-priced Waikiki hotel, choose the PK. If you want luxury, try one of the other Sheartons, the Halekalani or the Hyatt. Since you probably won't spend a lot of time in your room (which may be small but will be clean and have a parking structure that's close by and only 10 bucks a day for hotel guests), I'd recommend the PK! You can be on the sands of Waikiki beach in about 53 seconds after walking out the door of the PK, it's close to great shopping, an inexpensive food court is 50 feet from the pool, and, compared to other similar priced hotels in Waikiki, the Princess Kaiulani doesn't have that musty, old hotel smell.  I'll book another trip on Expedia NEXT summer and stay at the PK again!

I was very pleased with the everything at the Sheraton Princess Kaiulani. It is a beautiful hotel just across from the Waikiki Beach. An excellent value, pretty, spacious rooms with balconies, Hawaiian flare, lovely nightly entertainment, convenient restaurants. We had a reservation for a partial ocean view, and because we are Starwood preferred customers, we were upgraded to a full ocean view room. It is not as posh as the Royal Hawaiian Hotel but I felt uncomfortable just walking in the Royal Hawaiian. I felt very comfortable at the Princess Kaiulani. The staff is very friendly and helpful. WE HAD A GREAT TRIP AND WOULD STAY HERE AGAIN!

My husband and I recently celebrated our 15 year anniversary in February and celebrated with a trip to Hawaii. This was our trip of a lifetime and needless to say that the hotel and location was a HUGE disappointment to us. Since the day we were married we often thought of this being our ideal anniversary vacation. WRONG. I have to agree with some of the other reviews, saying that the hotel staff catered to the needs of Japanese clients and made any American feel as if we were unwelcomed in their hotel.
