I would definitely say that I felt like a minority just walking around the lobby. Rarely would you see a smiling face, helpful person, or anyone speaking english without a HEAVY accent. I have no problem with other cultures or Japanese people but I do have a problem with how unwelcomed I felt.  The worst thing about this hotel is the location. I guess it's true that location means everything and this hotel really proved it to me. We had paid for an "oceanview" room and all we saw was one high rise building after the other. If you looked really hard, you may see the ocean between two other high rise hotels that were ON the beach. This is the LOUDEST place that I have ever stayed at and I felt very unsafe at night. We stayed in a higher room, second floor from top, and I could still hear music and noise booming until 1:00 a.m. I was looking forward to a relaxing, romantic trip and my nerves were on edge from no sleep whatsoever.  Oahu is a beautiful island, but I was certainly dissappointed in Waikiki. I will never stay in Waikiki again. Some people may love it, but I tend to hate commercial areas, and it has taken over. If you do go to the island of Oahu, spend most of your time on the NORTH shore of the island. This part of the island is gorgeous. Waikiki is too commercial and not the Hawaiin paradise I hoped for. One thing that I do recommend is the picnic basket that you can order from room service the night before. My husband and I took a picnic basket (which was absolutely wonderful and fresh) to the North shore for some privacy and relaxation, and it was the best day we had. We also had room service the night we arrived, and it was one of the best meals we had the entire trip. Another recommendation would be to go to Germaine's Luau. The staff was so friendly and it was an absolute blast. This is a great Luau and you can't leave Hawaii without going to one.  The Sheraton P.K. is a loud, unfriendly hotel with very limited accommodations. Don't expect much with your room. But I will have to say that my room was clean and consistently so during my trip. Dresser space was almost nil. My clothes were either hung(limited-no hangers/room) or in my suitcase. Positives- Room service, cleanliness and staff was friendly as you arrive in front of hotel. Unfortunately, that is where the friendliness ends as well. I hope if you are going to Waikiki that you will have your Hawaiin paradise. I was certainly dissappointed in mine.

We usually stay on the North Shore, but when we do stay in Honolulu, we're always at this hotel. Just a hop, skip and a jump from International Market and other downtown festivities. The pool and lounge is great. The staff is excellent. We'll be back there on July 29, 2005! Can't wait!

This hotel was considered a "bargain" for the price on the website but I feel like we ended up with so much more for the price. From the moment we pulled up to the front entrance to the minute we left, they were courteuos and friendly. The bell man helped with our luggage and since we were early, tagged it and stored it for us. After grabbing a bite to eat, we checked in around 3 pm. First off, being a Sheraton Starwood Preferred member, our room was upgraded from an "Ocean View" to a "Deluxe Ocean View". We stepped off one of the four quick elevators and walked straight ahead to room 918. The room was beautiful and clean and had an AWESOME VIEW. We booked a hotel "across from Waikiki" to save on cost but also because we didn't plan on spending a lot of time in the room. But this was soooo great for the money. Our lanai was directly above the pool and had a perfect shot of Waikiki ocean and the stage downstairs where the bands perform. Instead of going out, we ended up spending most nites by making some cocktails, getting our deck of cards and playing rummy 500 in the warm hawaiian air, listening to the bands on our lanai. I couldn't have asked for anything better...I think we spent every nite we stayed there on that lanai.Other good stuff was great cleaning service, nice pool and friendly staff. Down at the pool they give you nice big towels to use, in the afternoons they have fresh pineapple (and it is sooo yummi!) and also later in the afternoon, ice cold hand clothes they pass out to each of you. Even the food was good at the Moyohama Sushi restaurant. We had a 15% off coupon from the menu, which made the already average pricing for sushi even better. I really would love to stay at this hotel again...and get this exact same room.Pricing was roughly $150 plus tax a nite and we stayed from Monday the 27th until July 1st.

This was a very nice budget hotel. When I say budget, I mean for Waikiki. Close to the beach, but also close to the crowds. The rooms are a little dated, but the hotel is 50 years old. It could use a major renovation to receive a higher rating. Location is great - central to shopping and restaurants. Overall I would highly recommend it for a couple of nights, but not for any longer. But then again, we didn't like Waikiki at all. The band by the pool was very loud at night.

Wow! The hula show and dinner was excellent. It runs about 198.00 for two people for the premium dinner show. But you get a beautiful Orchid lei greeting and we had filet mignon and lobster for dinner. My mother is in a wheel chair so their handicap seating is in the front, right next to the stage. Well worth the money.

My boyfriend and I enjoyed this hotel very much. Being a Travel Agent I received an amazing rate that I certainly couldn't pass up. I mainly chose this hotel due to the location and star rating (compared to other places in the area and prices available for travel agents during that time of the year I planned on going). We were upgraded immediately to a partial ocean view room upon checking in, which was a nice surprise during all of the excitement of finally going to Hawaii! The area around PK is awesome if you're looking for a tourist hub -- relaxing when you want it to be and hustle-bustle if you want it to be. Hawaii is not only beautiful but everyone in Oahu was SO NICE to us. We felt completely pampered! Those working at the PK were accomodating, relaxed, and enjoyable. Japanese tourists definitely seem to rule the roost in Oahu - but we had no problems at all.. things weren't too busy tourist-wise. The AWESOME thing was, that this hotel offers a Hospitality Room/Suite for use by guests that have flights that depart late in the day. The room features a HUGE bathroom w/shower, sink, toilet etc, the sitting area has comfortable couches and lounge chairs and a coffee table, etc. You have the room for a full hour, which gives you time to shower and relax a bit before heading back out to catch a taxi to the airport. I would definitely stay at the PK again. I give it 4 stars out of 5 due to the excellent service and surprisingly easy trip.. everything went without a hitch and it made the trip well worth it --- This truly was a VACATION.$ Tip: Food in Hawaii is up there price-wise... depending on where you go, you can get some wonderful deals on Seafood.. so keep an eye out! Food cost wasn't too big of a deal for us since we'd saved so much money for the trip ahead of time, and we'd gotten such a great deal on the room.Tourist Tip: Go snorkeling in Hanauma Bay! Many tours are available for purchase at the Concierge desk... the agent working is more than happy to assist and answer questions. For less than $20 per person we received a bus transfer round-trip to and from the Bay, snorkeling equipment, etc. The only thing not included is your food -- you can bring your own food or purchase from their snack bar (pricey but ok when you're starving!). Keep in mind that there is a small additional fee per person to get into Hanauma Bay (as it is a state park and wildlife preserve).

This hotel is in a great location, in between the International Market Place and just a short walk through the Sheraton Moana Surf, the beach. One thing you can come not to expect very much of in Hawaii is service so make sure you at least enjoy your hotel. The Sheraton Princess is one of the very few Sheraton's that doesnt utilize the Service Promise philosophy. The rooms were very basic, the walls were paper thin and the staff were very difficult to deal with. If you are looking in the budget priced hotels, I would entertain the Outrigger's as you can get some good deals on even the ones on the beach, the Outrigger Reef or the Outrigger Waikiki on the Beach.

First time in Oahu Hawaii, stayed at PK for 3 nights in May. Overall: Average. Ambience was pretty good, sometimes live night entertainment for their almost daily pool-side buffet (plenty of food and variety was great -- must have the SWEET pineapples!). Small-Med Pool is closed at night and early morning during breakfast time. Staff was nice and helpful. When we arrived, they had to fix double booking error (no problem). Our room was disappointing, old decor, and beds were too soft, and sagged in the middle. Clean enough, but not spectacular bath. 2 or 3 of our 4 lamps didn't work so we called down to fix, which they did while we were gone and surprised us with a nice complimentary basket of snacks. Balcony view wasn't great - got the side of a building. Lobby sells fresh leis for 5 dollars, which we took back on our 5 hr flight for family members. Location was pretty convenient: easy walk to the beach, and walked several blocks for shopping and other eateries. We went on one of those Bus Day Tours, and one shuttle tour. Our tour guides were great, but the tours were not...most of the time is spent on the road, looking out the window and about 5, 10 or 15 minutes at stops. Luau was fun (sorry don't remember the name), but we paid $100 ea. and it was about an hour drive to another beach on a bus (FUN RIDE, great people). Be prepared to tip every driver and tour guide you use (they expect it). TIPS: Recommend exploring sites on bus or trolleys and enjoy at your leisure. P.S. The Don Ho show - ok for seniors but pretty slow and dull for younger crowd.

We stayed during easter week at SPK. It was ideal for us since we wanted to enjoy the hustle and bustle in Waikiki. The SPK is in a great location! It is right next to the International Marketplace and across the street from Waikiki Beach. We were upgraded to the 29th floor with great views of Honolulu and partial ocean views of Waikiki Beach. However, the first two days were unusually windy so we could hear the wind howling from the top floor but the rest of the week was awesome! I would definitely stay here again!

The SPK is a great place to stay if you are on a budget and are looking for a clean and relatively friendly place to stay!I stayed there with 3 friends between March 10 and March 18, we were in Hawaii for a holiday and to see the sights. All we wanted was a nice and clean room to rest out weary heads at night, and that is what we got!SPK as with most of Honolulu and Wiakiki is very Asian orientated, if you can get past that you will have a great time!

Stayed at the Princess from March 4 to March 13. The hotel is in a great location in terms of access to the beach and shopping. If you are expecting a typical Sheraton, you will be extremely disappointed. The outside of the hotel, lobby, bar, and restaurants all looked fabulous and the staff was very warm and welcoming. Shock was the room. VERY poorly maintained. Bedspreads are thin, decor is horrible, refrigerator barely worked, and the room was quite small. If the winds are blowing you will be up all night as the wind shook our balcony door so hard that it just continually rattled.Didn't feel as cheated the first 7 nights of the stay because I had a conference rate of $105/night, but it really hurt to pay $150 for the next two nights in the same room...I had no problems with parking and I thought that $10/day was reasonable. However, traffic in Waikiki is horrible so think twice about renting a car if you plan to just hang around downtown.Food was o.k., but VERY pricey. Dinner buffet at the hotel was 32.50/person and the breakfast buffet was 16.50/person. Both were good, but not worth the price.According to one of the Assistant Managers, the hotel is scheduled for an upgrade this summer, so if I ever go back, I might stay just to check out the difference. Your best bet is the Hilton Hawaiian Village (little further uptown) or the Sheraton Moana Surfrider which is right across the street.Also, be prepared for the Japanese invasion. I found that the staff seem to cater to them more than Americans. Most of the Japanese folks that I encountered were friendly, but a lot were obnoxious about cutting in front of you when standing in line and they seemed to have a real sense of entitlement--that did not apply to anyone else...

My friend and I booked a great deal through Priceline.com. It was last minute- so I was nervous about it, especially after reading some of the reviews about the Sheraton Princess at Waikiki. It was the only hotel left. I'm glad we went ahead and booked and stayed. It was GREAT!!! The staff was very accommodating and knowledgeable. The hotel lobby area was beautiful and they had nightly concerts. The rooms are fine- not plush or anything but fine. We had a great view of the beach and mountains. The hotel even has a complimentary room for you to use if you have to check out and your flight doesn't leave until late. So- we freshened up prior to leaving for the airport. The best place to eat is the Diamond Head Market and Grill. It's nothing fancy and it's a to go kinda place but they have small tables outside. The food is the BEST! If you like ribs- GO GET SOME. They melt in your mouth. The Salmon and Ahi steak are really good too. For dessert try the Diamond Head Torte. This place is on the left going towards Diamond Head Crater. If you like hiking do that too. Peace.

Pros-----* Great Location - a Half Block from the Center of Waikiki Beach* Nice Lobby* Some Friendly Staff* Live Entertainment in Lobby Area that can be Enjoyed from Your Room if you Open Your Window to Bacony unless You like to Sleep Early* Will Address Your Problems & Will Upgrade You or Compensate You for Problems* Great Complementary Toiletries* Nice View from Balcony in Most Rooms* Close to Shops, Restaurants, Entertainment - in the Heart of WaikikiCons-----* Old & Rundown, Needs Updating like Most Hawaiian Hotels* Has Ants & Geckos in Some Rooms - Avoid by Asking for a Higher Floor away from Foliage in Front of Hotel* Rooms not too Spacious* Old & Loud Mini Refrigerator, No Microwave in Room* Thin Walls - Can Hear Neighbors* Some Staff Not Friendly at All & Can be Difficult to Deal With* Expensive for the Quality & Is not up to Par with Other Sheraton Hotels, Tries to be High Class, but Fails at it by being so Run Down* May not Refill Toiletries such as Facial Tissue* Parking Garage always Cramped & Full - Customers Park outside of Designated Parking Spaces* Expensive Parking Rates - $10 a Day* Rooms not Exceptionally Clean* Hallways & Lobby not Air Conditioned, only Rooms were, Relied on Open Windows, which does not work in Hot Hawaii* Small Pool for such a Large Hotel* Traffic Jams near Hotel* Service to Room will Take a WhileA decent hotel near the beach, but don't be fooled by the Sheraton Name, it does not live up to the quality expected by a Sheraton Hotel, especially for the prices they charge

We have stayed at this proerty many times and love the location and views from the high floors. Rooms are lovely. Poolside dining at the Pikake Buffet has great food and reasonable prices. Only drawback is the noise of the city, which finds its way to even to the 27th. floor. The hum of the city without traffic at 4 AM is noisy. Otherwise, I highly recommend this property. The folks who work here try very hard to please. It is a very good value for the money and near everything.

We booked an economy package from Vancouver Canada and luckily picked the Sheraton Princess K hotel  It exceeded our expectations--we were on the 11th floor and there was a little traffic noise but it was clean, staff was friendly and helpful, there was a room with free internet/email access, and an interesting pool area with entertainment nightly.  The lobby is spacious and we met several couples from other hotels who were using it as they preferred it to their hotels.  Conveniently located one block from the beach.  Unless we win the lottery, we'll definitely stay there on our next trip to Waikiki

Stayed at the PK Jan 15-22, 2005. Was worried due to mixed reviews I had read. Were in the tower with a partial ocean view, overlooking the pool. The room was clean, service was great and friendly, room was quiet at night so I had absolutely no problems and no complaints.

I loved my visit here. The best thing about it is the Sheraton policy of "Stay at one, play at all" which allows you to use the facilites of all 5 Honolulu Sheraton properties and you can sign for things with your room card key! My ONLY negative comment is that the 5 story parking garage has NO ELEVATOR. You'd think the ADA would force them to get one, but no, it hasn't. But the $10.00 a night parking fee is VERY reasonable for a Waikiki hotel.

Yeah, it's a bustling place right in the middle of Waikiki, but that's exactly what we wanted on our first trip to Hawaii! This may not be the place for the Four Seasons crowd but we had an exceptional stay January 15-22, 2005. Our room was on the 7th floor of the new wing with a partial ocean view overlooking the pool and outdoor stage. It was wonderful sitting on our balcony, sipping Kona coffee in the morning watching the sunrise and even better in the evening, watching the stage show from our very own private perch. The housekeeping staff seemed to have radar, knowing exactly when we would be out of the room and surprising us with a clean room, even at 10am after we returned from a walk on the beach. The staff was wonderful and "mahalo" to Tammy who gave us a late checkout on our final day so we could soak up a few more hours of the Hawaiian sunshine. My wife and I would definitely return to the Sheraton PK!

My husband and I loved the atomsphere, the service, and the beautifulhotel. We were there in December 2003. We had a pleasant stay. It isin the heart of everything. Eateries and shops all around. We would stay there again.

Its a large hotel & that means busy and impersonal. The Japanese seem to like it and it caters very well for large groups of Japanese tourists who seem to be a permanent fixture in the entrance halls. The JAL crew are also accomodated here.The old Kaiuliani Wing is in dire need of renovation. Its quite clean, but definitely cracking at the edges. The "courtyard" rooms all overlook the multi storey car-park and rubbish bins (which are emptied daily at 6.30am beep beep!) It's not the most picturesque places.If you stay there as part of a cruise package, then you will definitely be in these rooms - be prepared to pay a hefty upgrade fee if you want a tower room with a limited view of the sea.It is in the middle of everything - if that's what you want, then fine. It is typical of Waikiki, but does not represent the rest of Hawaii which is a beautiful place. Waikiki is a god-forsaken concrete jungle!

What a wonderful place to stay. My husband and family enjoyed the comfort this hotel offered. The atmosphere most desire when traveling to the islands is definitely present here. PK offers cultural entertainment nightly beside the poolside. We loved the convenience of being close to the beach, restaurants and the International Marketplace. The zoo and aquarium are located a few blocks up the street as well. The rooms are perfect for travel. They were cleaned daily and our housekeeper left lots of fresh towels and plenty of delicious Royal Hawaiian Coffee. When we arrived we requested a room that overlooked the pool and we were accomodated by Sonny at the Front Desk. He was very friendly and welcoming to us.This hotel has restaurants for every budget....from $3 on up. We enjoyed our stay and would definitely stay there again!A----loooooo------ha! Ken and Yvette Brownstone of Ventura, California

I like the location of this hotel - it's right off the main street, the beach is literally 30 seconds away. If you are looking for a romantic get-away, this is NOT the place to stay. Go for Halekulani. But if you are looking for a comfortable accomodation at a great price, this is the hotel for you. About around $120-$150/night, there's not a lot of service to speak of, but it's a clean room and a clean bathroom - which is a lot more than I can say about some of the other hotels around the area (i.e. the various Ohanas). But if you want a nice swimming pool, this is not the place for you. Then again, the ocean is 30 seconds away. Why would you want to be sitting by the pool? I've been to Hawaii 4 times this year and stayed at PK 3 times...Next time when I go back, PK would most likely be the hotel I would stay at if I can't get a good deal at the Halekulani (which I LOVED, which happens to be twice, if not three times more expensive than PK)

After reading the reviews of the p.k. I was afraid we had made a mistake! We recieved a very nice free upgrade when we presented our starwood card. The staff was friendly. Our room was fresh and clean. Fresh pineapple was offered free at the pool area. We had no problems using beach towels at the surf rider. This was a great place to stay for the price! Our whole family enjoyed it.

We have just returned from 2 weeks at the PK, and had a fantastic time. Before our holiday I read some of the reviews and was ready to cancel, but thankfully I didnt, I thought we must be staying in a different hotel because we couldnt fault it !! After an 18 hour flight and feeling very tired the bell desk immediately had our bags ready to take to our room, unfortunatley we couldnt get an upgrade and as i expected we were put in the'old' tower, it wasnt bad and after all you only have to sleep there. The hotel staff were always friendly, the pool size was fine and the hotel in general was in a great location, just across the road from the beach. As for the prostitutes that stand outside the hotel at night well we didnt see one and if they were there, they certainly kept themselves to themselves !We'd definately go back every year if it wasnt for the flight time and the jet lag !!!

My wife and I had modest expectations for this hotel when we booked three nights here in early November 2004. However, we were very pleasantly surprised by the quality of the Princess Kaiulani. Our room were simple, but quite clean and comfortable, with a spacious lani. Staff and facilities were above average. Perhaps the best feature of this hotel is it's excellent Waikiki location. The hotel lies right in the center of things, just across the street from the beach and a half block from both the beach park and the International Market place. We would stay here again.

Spent 5 nights here October through November of 2004, 3 nights one week then 2 the next week. Great service, good staff. I would recommend this hotel to anyone staying in Honolulu. Beach is maybe 4 minutes away, convenient to everything. Only thing to be careful of is the "working girls" downstairs by the street at night and nobody seems to take notice of them. I say this because there is a police station just across the street and maybe two buildings over. Go figure.

We stayed at the Sheraton Princess Kaiulani Hotel for 6 days in October. Arrived at 11am and were immediately provided with our room. As a Sheraton Preferred Guest I had booked the Standard Room rate of $119 with the limited view and was pleasantly advised that we had been upgraded to the 6th floor overlooking the pool. Rooms are dated but clean and provide all the necessities. Big problem is the neighbouring room noise. You can hear the television and EVERYTHING else (must have been honeymooners in room 626!!!). Great location and easy access to shops, restaurants, beach and transport. No need to take beach towels. These are provided for use by the pool and at the beach. Also provided are beach mats and chairs. Great service. Pineapple juice and freshly cut pineapple is served by the pool on Fridays. The best pineapple you will EVER taste. There is easy access to the beach via the lobby of the Sheraton Moana Surfrider and be sure to purchase your blow up rings from the ABC Store for about $3.50 and experience swimming with sea turtles each afternoon about 100 metres straight out from the Surfrider. We will definitely be back to the Sheraton Princess Kaiulani next year.

I booked with the Princess Kaiulani through my Starwood Preferred membership and then stayed from Oct. 11-15th, 2004. While I was familiar with the PK and knew it was not up to the multi-star status of other Sheratons, I was not prepared for the terrific service I experienced during my stay. Traveling alone on business can be tiresome and a bit daunting for a female. However, the PK made my stay memorable. For instance: the hall light outside my room was out, but within 15 mins. of my call downstairs, an electrician was there fixing the light. On another occasion, the room hairdryer didn't function, and again within 15 mins. I had a new hairdryer. Repeatedly, whenever I needed something or whenever I had a problem or a question (directions, billing etc.), the staff was professional and accommodated my request. I also received an excellent rate from the hotel and was given 2 upgrades to a larger room with a partial ocean view.While there are inherent problems in the hotel (i.e. one has to walk through the dining area to go anywhere), there are an equal as well as greater number of advantages: excellent floor shows, no beach or pool towel nazis, helpful concierage, great room attendants (spotless room). I thought the PK was an excellent value and an excellent facility.

Creation: Polynesian Odyssey at the Princess Kaiulani is a dinner/show. Our hotel offered a 2 for 1 deal on tickets so we decided to check it out. It was a waste of $--even with the 2 for 1 deal. Food was bland and it wasn't the typical luau food. Performances weren't that great either. We left early...

We stayed at the Sheraton Princess over Memorial Day weekend for $119/night. We had some difficulty checking in with the $50 credit we got through spg--- (we are starwood members) - but the front desk staff was helpful and tried their best. It was the Starwood/Sheraton headquarters office phone number they called that was giving so much trouble. The hotel lobby is nice and the location is great - you can walk right across the street to the Sheraton Moana Surfrider out onto the sand/beach. However, the hotel rooms were not up to Sheraton standards by any means - they were pretty outdated - but it was a decent deal for $119/night. The walls were pretty thin also so bring earplugs. I would rather pay more next time to stay at a nicer hotel like the Surfrider across the street. Although I did not see the actual rooms, I assume with the higher cost to stay there that the rooms were in better condition and the lobby is magnificient.We had 1 meal at this hotel - the seafood buffet that wasn't really worth the price. With all the restaurants in Waikiki, I think you'd be better off there than at the hotel.On a separate note - if you love sushi, check out Sansei - they're in Honolulu but not right in Waikiki. Also, the Honolulu Coffee Co. is across the street attached to the Moana Surfrider, they had great coffee and breakfast pastries. A nice change from the usual Starbucks.

We booked this hotel though Priceline and it fit our vacation nicely. It's in central Waikiki so very convenient (near bus stops, beach, stores, eateries). It's kinda noisy but quiets down around 11PM. The hotel constantly has stuff going on (vendors, musical performers at night). Our room in the Tower was decent size, clean, comfortable (bathroom was nice size). We didn't eat there at all and didn't enjoy passing through the buffet eating area every time we had to get to the elevators, which made the lobby smell of food constantly. Really liked how they provided us with a hospitality room after checking out so we can freshen up and rest a bit. A good choice for a package.

This was our first time to Hawaii and the PK made it a memorable one. I did book through expedia so our rooms were fairly cheap, so when we checked in we automatically upgraded to a room over the pool and I must say that made all the difference at our stay at the PK. We loved the live music every night by the pool. The food was pretty expensive I would recommend staying away from the Japanese restaurant, not worth the price!!! Overall a wonderful stay and I would definitely return.

Stayed for 8 days from August 18. I've been here 4 times already. What I expected in a Waikiki hotel - on a busy street with lots of shops all over the place. The rooms were small but all you need is a place to sleep. We had the partial Ocean view and if you lean out over the balcony enough you will see some ocean. Location wise it was a little North where most of the Japanese tourist stay. We had the choice of the Waikiki beach with waves or the quiet Kuhio beach( bring a float to lay in). Food at hotel was expensive but cheaper alternatives around (see Fatty's). There were prostitutes on the side street at night but they did not stick out that much. Excellent staff especially Naomi the Concierge. Lots of street noise especially some drummer on Kaiopolani. Tiny and deep pool which we never used. Overall not a bad place.

I've stayed at the "PK" a couple of times with mixed results. If your room was in the back and not in the Tower or facing the pool then yeah, I believe you had a lousy room. However, as a Starwood Member, you can upgrade to a nice room.For an extra $20 a night, I had an big room in the tower with an ocean view. Do your homework: ask if your room is by the parking garage, overlooking the pool or even with a partial ocean view. If it's anywhere near the garage, upgrade!

We booked two rooms at the Sheraton Princess Kaiulani in Waikiki. When we checked into our rooms, I was shocked when I saw how dirty the carpet and the bathrooms looked. There was nail clippings in the corner of the carpet and piled dust that hasn't been vacuumed for ages. There was human hair in the bathroom, particularly on the sink. Yuck.Dust everywhere. The blankets have holes in them. You would assume that since it's part of the Sheraton Family of hotels, it would be a decent, clean place to stay. The property needs major improvement in the management of room service. To say the least, I was very disappointed. I wouldn't recommend anyone to stay at this hotel.

I stayed at the PK in 2003. This was my second trip to Hawaii & i wasn't dissapointed. The entrance to the hotel is beautiful & the lobby is very grand. The pool area is lovely & every evening have live bands & Hula dancers. Although the swimming pool itself has an extremely deep, deep end! Strange as you are not allowed to actually dive into it! My room was clean & comfortable & quite spacious. The air conditioning was a little noisy, but i'd rather have the noise than sleep in a hot room! We had breakfast most mornings in the hotel, this wasn't cheap & we had to end up sharing it with lots of pigeons & doves!! Better was a cafe just next to the hotel which served much cheaper food. I am going for my third trip to Hawaii in October 2004 & although i'm staying in a different hotel i would definately stay at the PK again & recommend anyone to stay there.

We stayed at the Sheraton Princess Kaiulani Hotel for 2 weeks during July31-Aug.14th (2 weeks), and all I can say was, it was wonderful. Mind you, I did my homework before we booked with this hotel, I read all the reviews re: this hotel and I knew what tower to stay in before we booked. I heard bad reviews about the Kaiulani Tower and I knew I didn't want to stay in that tower. But I read great reviews re: the Princess Tower, so I knew that I wanted to get a room in that particular tower. Well, the first day we got there and the clerk booked us in the Kaiulani Tower which I refused to go to, but the clerk was really nice and managed to find a room available in the princess tower the next day. So we were to spend 1 night in the Kaiulani tower and then the following day they would move our suitcases to the princess tower which we wanted. Well.....the reviews for the kaiulani tower were right, the room was awful. We were on the 5th floor, balcony facing a dark parking lot, the room was dark, the room was so small, the bathroom was old and the beds looked really small and we were 4 people. The air condition was so noisey throughout the night, that we didn't sleep well at all. The next day, they moved us in later on in the day a the princess tower, wow.......what a transition......the room was bigger, we were on the 5th floor, facing the poolside and the street, the room also had a small couch and it was much more spacious and brighter with sunshine coming through our window. The air conditioner was newer and quieter, we didn't think it was on, thats how quiet it was. We stayed in this room for 2 wonderful weeks. It is our second time in Hawaii and we will be back for a third. We love Hawaii, the people are friendly and helpful and kind. But most of all we love the beaches, they are breathtaking. I'm hoping we go back in 5 years and I can't wait. I highly recommend this hotel, if you stay in the right tower, the people and staff are very friendly and really go out to make your stay comfortable. The service for breakfast, lunch and dinner are fantastic. The food is good too!A

I vacationed at the PK from Aug 19-26th. I visit Hawaii every other year and usually stay at the Waikiki Beachcomber but decided to try the PK for a change of pace. What a big mistake! The front staff was cordial and booked me in the older wing...what a huge dump! It appears that no improvements or routine maintenance has been done to the older wing in decades! The room I had was extremely small and the bathroom appeared as it did in the 1940's (i.e. pale yellow floor tiles, a public restroom type toilet, old sink that hasn't seen a can of Ajax cleanser in decades). What really threw me were the millions of TERMITES found crawling along the baseboards, in the light fixtures AND a few on the bed! This room is not fit for anyone to stay in!!! I immediately called the front desk and was moved to the newer wing on the second floor. It was somewhat of an improvement. The carpet and bathroom were clean. No termites, however there were these tiny black bugs that seemed to appear out of nowhere and then disappear just as fast. Gross!! The guest services manager sent up a food basket, but not for the bugs...he sent a basket for an AC problem that we called about...hmmm, we hadn't even complained about the A/C! This should be indicative of how this hotel works!Take your money to another hotel. The newer rooms are OK, the older ones aren't fit to house even the prostitutes who can be found in droves on the side of the PK hotel. Go to the Waikiki Beachcomber instead.

if i could leave a worse star rating i would. what a dump. rooms look like they haven't been upgraded since '81. the beds are small...i had a FULL bed, not a queen. Yet hotel mgmt insisted i had a queen. The real kicker is that I reserved a KING bed, which they refused to give me. hotel staff was most unhelpful across the board.

In reply to TripAdvisor User, Dallas TX August 2 2004 - I stayed at the PK November 1999 and as the PK is owned by a Japanese Company it is where the JAL crew stay between flights. I had a great time watching the Japanese weddings, and enjoyed watching children. The ladies of the evening work most of the streets after 11 pm.When I return to Honolulu I shall have no hesitation in booking a room at the PK.

I stayed at the princess the first week of april and to be honest, it was ok for the price. I received a airline discount (friends are in the industry) and ended up paying around 79/night. The room we had wasnt what i consider 5 star(more 3 or 3 1/2), but it had a decent bed and excellent view of the pacific and the koolaus. Normally, this room would run around $250US a night, which personally it wasnt worth. Seeing that this is an older hotel, the price is certainly is not worth the product.This hotels main business seems to lie in two groups: Airline industry(saw alot of JAL flight crews coming in) and the asian tourist market(lots of japanese weddings and families with kids). I also saw a smattering of anglo,black and latins to even out the mix. My only real complaints about this place are A)The hotel seems only concerned about their asian market business(JAL,asian weddings) and not their other clientel and B) Ladies of the evening work the corner after 11pm.All in all, its a hotel that could use some improvement.

We got a room through Priceline for US$90. Well worth it! Super location, almost on the beach. Enjoyed the poolside entertainment and mai tai's! Nice quiet room, minimal view, but clean and comfortable. Highly recommended.

i loved staying at the pk. My room was very clean and neat. Pool was wonderful as well as the entertainment. Hawaii is so beautiful and being at the pk made it worth the long flight. But plan a luai when u visit. the trip was pleaseant. SPK WAS GREAT!!!!!!!!

Had a great time! Traveled to Hawaii for the first time in January of 2003. It ended up being two couples and we made a request for adjoining rooms and the were pleasantly able to accomadate us! We were upgraded to the "ocean view" room after expecting a view of nothing for the price we paid. Very convienent to everything, we never ate at the hotel, due to the prices that were posted in the hotel's lobby. There are too many decent priced restaurants around to justify the cost of eating at the hotel. Our group didn't rent a car from the airport we took a cab from the airport and found it easy to walk around. When we did more sightseeing we renting a car at Avis right around the corner and returned it that day to avoid the park charges, and by the way it is expensive to park anywhere. The beach was very easy to get to we walked right through the lobby of the Moana Surfrider and walked right onto the sand. The staff at the Moana were very nice and pleasantly served us drinks when we took many breaks from the sun. Had to laugh at the amount of hookers that line the street in front of the hotel at night. The only problem we had was on a rainy night the water ran on the inside portion of the window glass, this could explain the musty smell, but other than that no complaints on the room. The service is a little slower but isn't that what vacation is for, to slow down? Everyone there was very pleasant and would stay there again.

The Princess Kaiulani is fine. It is not a luxury resort but you will have a nice, clean room. The lobby and poolside lounge are very beautiful. The rooms look like they haven't been updated for a while but they are clean and comfortable. You're hardly ever in the room anyway. It is only a block from the beach and is within walking distance to many shops and resturants. I wouldn't advise upgrading to a "partial ocean view" however. When we got there, we were told that we had been upgraded as a courtesy. The view wasn't much, but we didn't pay for it so we didn't care. Looking straight out we saw the tops of the International Market Place. The ocean was mostly obscured by other buildings between us and the beach. We didn't have anything to complain about and our stay was fine. If you want to be really pampered in luxury this is not the place. But if you just want a decent place to sleep and be close to the beach, it's a good deal.

We visited the PK for 10 nights in March 04. We spent our first night in one of PK's more average rooms but the following day we were upgraded to a beautiful, 14th floor, full ocean view room - for no extra charge!! We found the staff at the PK extremely friendly, and the location of the hotel is by far one of the best on Waikiki. We plan to visit Oahu next year and will definitely be booking into the PK.

My husband and I stayed in the Sheraton Princess from March 6th to March 13th. Needless to say, I was very worried before our departure based on some of the reviews read on this website. To our surprise, our room was great: clean, spacious, quiet, with a nice lanai. Although the view was not spectacular because we took the cheapest deal on priceline, it was lovely for its value. The service was very professional. We got help for our travalling needs. Everybody was courteous and accommodating in spite of the large crowds we found during our stay. The location could not be better: in the hear of Waikiki, close to all the bus lines, and across the street from the beach. The swimming pool is small, but who needs a swimming pool when you have one of the best beaches literally two minutes walk from the hotel? Overall, great place to stay for its money value.

I had booked my trip to the PK prior to reading the reviews here. Needless to say, I was very anxious about how the hotel would turn out. Everything was absolutely fine. We were treated wonderfully by the entire staff...and were upgraded without asking to a king bed/ partial oceanview room which looked down on the pool area. Very pleasant. The location is great....and the price is reasonable. The room could have been "updated" a bit.... but it was spotless. If someone is a 'high end' traveler...and is used to, say, a Four Seasons, then yes, they will be disappointed. But for an average person, its fine.

My husband and I stayed at the PK March 2 & 3 as part of a travel agent's package arrangements. We had just landed after an 8 hour non-stop flight and I was exhausted from a flu I caught the day before embarking. Thanks to the reviews here, I had some ideas when we arrived, like: drop off your luggage at the front door and watch them while your husband parks the rental car in the ramp. That way, you don't have to lug them down from the ramp. The bell hop/porter person was very good with service and friendly. Also, I learned that getting a Starwood card before leaving on my trip helped at check-in. The young woman was very courteous at the front desk. We were late checking in because of a HORRENDOUS car rental experience with Alamo (also set up by the Travel agent). I was dreading seeing the room and as we went down the hallway, I realized we were not in the newer tower part! But as we entered the room I was pleasantly surprised to find we were in a corner room and up high enough to watch surfers on Waikiki from our balcony! I nervously peeked into the bathroom and...glory be! No bugs! No mold or mildew! Everything looked like it had been scrubbed and was quite clean, freshly painted, wallpapered and the carpet looked shampooed! The beds were 2 doubles put together, but since my husband snores, I didn't mind- they were comfortable enough. My only complaint was the stupid street performers below and the terrible noise one of them made with his boom box playing such stupid lame-o music! His act was uncreative, untalented and dumb, yet he attracted lots of Japanese tourists for some reason. Even with the doors and windows shut and the heavy drapes pulled that awful music was blaring and finally stopped at 11:00 pm! With the Waikiki police station practically across the street one would think these pests could be controlled! Other than that, we enjoyed our time in Honolulu. The breakfast buffet was fine - our waitress was so nice and suggested fresh papaya for my tummy. It works! We ate in the hotel restaurant for dinner and the food was so-so. Someone earlier mentioned that they cater to Japanese tourists and I think I agree, but that is the case ALL over Honolulu!

The Princess Kaiulani Hotel was a great experience from the time I entered until I left to return home. I stayed there in June 2003. I purchased a Vacation pachage through Expediathat included hotel/air/and car. After arriving in Honolulu, I picked up my car from the rental agency and drove to Waikiki. I checked in early in the afternoon and was upgraded to a better room from the one booked. The room was very clean and maintained. The location of the Hotel was near everything. The international Market place was next door,Denny's 1 block away, Great places to eat all around, and close access to the Freeway to get to anywhere you may want to go. The staff was great, always courteous and helpful with what ever my needs were. Although this Hotel was listed as a three star, I had a four star experience. I will vacation again in Hawaii and will stay at the Princess Kaiulani.

not even sure where to begin....my wife and I just came back on 28 Feb from our 'honeymoon' and we stayed at the Sheraton PK. First of all, the "Oceanview" room that we paid a premium for $325/night looked directly into another hotel, if you strained your neck from the lanai you could catch a glimpse of the ocean. The agent downstairs would only respond by saying "well those are the ocean view rooms" This was room 2467, ask them to see it if you don't believe me. It probably was "oceanview" when it was built, but since then many many many more developments have gone up around this place, and your views are of urban sprawl. Do not let them con you into one of these rooms.Secondly, their policy of "pay at one, play at all three" is a flat out LIE. My wife and I went across the street to the Sheraton Moana Surf-Rider, which was on the beach.....we told the attendant that we were from their sister property and their response was "okay, you can swim in our pool, and use our beach BUT, DO NOT use our towels, DO NOT sit on our chairs or pool furniture, and DO NOT lay on our beach....if you would like to sit, there is a patch of grass in the corner" I had to say I have never felt like a 2nd class citizen until this point.Never EVER will I stay at a Sheraton again. The only people who were cordial were the waitstaff/bartenders in the Pikake lounge, and that is probably because we were paying $2-3 more for drinks than we could get a few storefronts down the road.So not worth it. Trust me, don't stay here.The rooms themselves were miserable, and don't even get me started on the nasty bathrooms.Please, don't end up having to apologize to your new wife all week long like I did.......when all I was trying to do was give her a nice week somewhere.......

Stayed here for two nights during late December 2003.Found it to be a great hotel; staff was very friendly and upgraded us to a bigger room (facing the street; across from the ocean) when we showed our Starwood Preferred card. Conceirge was very helpful. The nightly live entertainment by the pool was great. The restaurant was ok.It is across the street from the beach; not directly on the beach, but this was not a concern for us.Enjoyed our stay; if back in Waikiki, would stay here again.

My husband and I spent three days at this hotel in June, 2003. In light of what we paid per night, I was a little disappointed. The hotel has a musty smell and the pool is a joke. Lucky for us, we were only at the hotel to sleep so it didn't cause a problem. If you intend to spend little to no time at this hotel, then it's a decent place to stay. If not, I'd go with another place -- there are plenty of other options.

The room was clean. I would stay here again. The show was great. A good place to eat is Dukes across the street. Go down about 6 Hotels and it's in the back by the water. This is where i'll stay if i came back. we were there 2-1-04 for 6 nites.

February 18, 2004. Stayed at the Sheraton Princess Kaiulani for our last night on the Hawaiian Islands. This hotel is located in a very nice location in Waikiki and was very busy. This said we were treated very well when we checked in and the Bell Person brought us our luggage must faster then I had expected (seeing the pile of luggage outside when we arrived). The rooms were small and a bit musty smelling but we were upgraded to an Ocean View for some reason (Maybe because I am a Starwood Preferred Guest). This gave us a balcony overlooking the pool and the ocean could be seen over the other hotels. One of the best perks we were provided and I have never been offered anywhere else was the availability of a hospitality room. Checkout was at 11:00 and they could not extend it because they were in a sold out state, however, they offered us a room that we could check out and use for 1 hour to shower and clean up before we had to leave for the airport. We arrived at 2:30 pm after going to the beach and were able to get prepared for our trip home. The eight hour flight was much more tolerable. I would definitely stay here again.

I was worried after we booked at this hotel when I read some reviews that mentioned ants. There was no way I was staying in a room with ants! Well, I didn't have to. We were upgraded (thankfully, because I would hate to see the original room). Our room was clean enough to be free of ants, but we never unpacked our clothes into the drawers because they just didn't seem clean enough. We weren't expecting much, and that's what we got. We didn't stay in the worst wing, which looked like it was in drastic need of renovation (we accidentally ended up there once). I guess it is a case of getting what you pay for, as the rate we got was not bad. But I think next time I might pay the extra $ and go to the Moana Surfrider.

I stayed at the PK January 20th - 24th and had a very pleasant experience. I wouldn't rate my room an A+, but it was a good solid B which is what I expected given the moderate price. I really enjoyed the central location and its proximity to the International Market. I never ate at the PK other than 1 room service breakfast that was quite good so I can't comment on their buffet (I don't like buffets anyway). The staff was very friendly and helpful and I really enjoyed the pool the one time I used it. If I were travelling with someone else to share the room cost, I probably wouldn't stay at the PK, but given the price and location I would stay there again on a solo trip like this one.

Just returned from a stay at the Kaiulani from Jan. 17-21. We weren't expecting much given the reviews on this site, however, I was hoping that with the Sheraton name we could at least expect a minimum level of quality. Boy were we wrong. The room was small and old, as most other report. The meals at the buffet were horrible. I know not to expect too much from buffets, but we stayed at other hotels in Honolulu and Maui and the Sheraton's food was pure slop in comparison. The pool was small and poorly located. (Though this might not be a concern given the location of the beach across the street. Also, if you are traveling with children (or even if you aren't), be prepared for the hordes of prostitutes that hang out in this area every night. While it didn't feel dangerous, it wasn't exactly the environment that we were looking for. Overall, you're travel expenditures are better off being spent elsewhere.

Luckily I only stayed for two nights at this Sheraton because it was absolutely horrendous - the room was smaller than the rooms in NYC hotels and it was in need of major renovation. The word that comes to mind is 'shabby'. One would expect that it being a Sheraton it would at least be clean but that it was not. I can't belive that Sheraton would associate its name with a room of such low caliber. I did ask for a room change but I was told that because I had gotten a special rate through priceline I could not even pay for an upgrade. The staff was not hospitable or friendly and I was glad to leave there. By the way, afterwards we went to the Waikiki Beachcomber where the room was much bigger and cleaner but also in need of some renovation. I don't know how priceline rates its hotels but these were definitely not 3-star rooms by AAA standards.

This hotel may be the worst of the 4 Sheratons on Waikiki. Checking in (daytime), there were only 2 or 3 clerks, the check-in process took 10+ minutes, due to the slow cmptr system. Within a few minutes, a line of people quickly formed behind me... yet, the same pple were (still) checking-in, and no new agents were to be found. A Manager popped in and out of the back, but offered no help to the agents, nor sent more pple out! I avoided the front desk whenever I could... but even cashing some traveller's checks proved to be a 10 minute 'experience.' And the agents, when you finally got to the front desk, did not seem happy to serve you! Sort of... 'take the money and run' attitude. I am a frequent visitor to HNL but I will avoid the "PK" -- not a pleasant stay!

We stayed at the Princess Kaiulani from January 15-18, 2004. We received an upgrade from a standard room to a room with an ocean view without any problem. The room itself was fine, the bathroom appeared to have been recently remodeled. The room was clean although the carpet appeared worn in a couple spots and also had a couple stains. The staff was very courteous and prompt. Maintenance was called to our room once and the problem was corrected quickly, we also received a call from the hotel apologizing. I thought the food was overpriced within the hotel and only ate lunch there once. There are a variety of restaurants to choose from that are near the hotel. Overall, I would recommend the Kaiulani.

My husband, his sister and I stayed at the PK, Oct 26, - Oct 31, 2003. We upgraded to an Ocean View room from a city view. We liked the hotel and staff very much. Our room gave us a gorgeous view of the beach and the street below. The lobby is beautiful and we liked being in the heart of Waikiki

My Husband and I fled here after a surprise of the bad sort at the Continental Surf Hotel. We fell in love. First night we stayed on the 9th floor and had a partial ocean view, w/ a great view of "Kings Street" (behind the Hyatt). Then the 2nd night, my hubby bumped us up for $20.00 more a night to an Ocean View room, w/ a fabulous view of Diamond head. It was the best! the rooms are kinda old and small, but the bed was great and the bathroom was clean. WE LOVED the staff, they were all fabulous. We never ate at the PK, but spent most of our meals at the Outrigger's Duke's restraunt.YUMMY!. We did enjoy watching the nightlife in the pool area below from the seclusion of our room. WE will definitely stay here again!

We booked our room thru Priceline.com and got a great rate. For the money we paid this place was a deal! However - our room had a TERRIBLE view. We overlooked the parking garage and garbage cans. Thankfully - the days we stayed there we actually were only in the room to sleep so the view didn't bother us enough to request a different room. GREAT location! I prefer a smaller hotel but the Princess Kaiulani was nice. It was clean and convenience. Besides the horrible view - our only other complaint was paying $10 per day to park and then having to walk up 5 flights of stairs to get our car. Continental breakfast is not included. Overall - if you pay full price for this hotel you can find better quality. At $50 / night it can't be beat!

We stayed here twice in one month. The staff were extremely friendly and they made us very welcome on our return with a beautiful fruit basket. We loved our first room so much that they booked the same room for us for our next visit. Lovely view of Waikiki from the balcony. Room was good, hilarious incident when our toilet overflowed one morning, but the staff were there in minutes to fix it AND compensate us with a choice of goodies, vouchers or Starwood points. We could not fault the service. Location is perfect. This is where we will stay again if we are ever lucky enough to return to beautiful Hawaii!

Had a great, but too short, holiday staying at the Sheraton P.K. The entire staff was attentive and friendly, very eager to please. Yes, the rooms are a little small, but who goes to Hawaii to stay in their room? I would highly recommend this hotel to anyone who is visiting the island.

My husband and I were there for our honeymoon this past New Year. We had high expectations of the hotel since (1st) we paid good money for it, (2nd) we figured it's Sheraton -silly me, and (3rd) the lobby was welcoming. When we walked into our room, it was horrible. We requested a king size bed, we got a full size bed. The room's air conditioner was so loud, I couldn't hear myself talking. The room was incredibly small. The bathroom was disgusting. The tiles and the toliet looked dirty and rusty. When I went to ask for a room I reserved, I was treated unprofessionally. The manager asked if I knew what "request" means because I only requested a king size bed so therefore I didn't get one. I was told that I would be notified once a room with a king size bed became available, no one ever contacted me as to whether or not a room was available. I was then brushed off and the manager went back to her office. I was extremely disappointed with the quality of the hotel and its service. I strongly advise others not to stay there.

We just returned from a five week visit at the Princess Kaiulani Hotel on Oahu. Our visit was sensational. We were treated with nothing but kindness, fruit baskets and flowers delivered to our room upon arrival. Candy sent to us upon discharge. The superb service and ambience around the pool area leaves little to desire. A walk acrossed the street to the ocean and located right in the heart of Waikiki. My hats off to the front desk staff and pool staff at the Princess Kaiulani Hotel. We will definitely be back again.

The Princess Kaiulani is a rather large hotel, so the quality of your room could vary considerably. Basically, there are two main "areas" of the hotel building -- the low rise wing buildings, and the high rise single building. The lobby area is very luxuriously appointed and certainly holds true to its 3 star rating. This hotel caters largely to the Japanese tourist package market, and as such, the hotel really only cares about them. The best rooms are therefore located in the high rise tower, with the rooms being larger and more recently renovated. The old low rise buildings are for the most part, very old and in dismal condition. I got a chance to stay in the low rise section and was shocked throughout my one night stay. Just stepping into the room will reveal the old, dirty, carpeting. The air conditioning unit looked like it came out from the WWII era, all dusty, rusted, and just hideous for being in a hotel room. The bathroom screamed Welcome to 1965, being disgustingly dirty with old water stains everywhere. On the positive side, there is a true balcony for all the rooms on the low rise side, albeit there is not much to see as the "views" look towards the city streets and adjacent buldings. Because this building is so low, street noise is an incredible issue if you want to turn in early. All I heard until midnight was booming stereos from nearby clubs, cars burning rubber, sirens, and the occasional drunken pedestrian shouting. Oh well, at least you'll get some fresh air. The staff works hard to make the experience even less appealing for you. Not once did any staff member smile at me, or make me feel welcomed in any way. Upon check in, I was treated like an annoyance to the desk clerk. And even when I left the parking structure (adjacent to the hotel), the attendant was extremely rude when I passed him the parking voucher indicating I already paid for the room through the hotel directly. All in all, I will not stay here ever again. The low rise buildings are representative of a 1 star establishment. However, I did visit a relative on a later date in the high rise tower and their room was a lot cleaner and larger, but like I said, this hotel caters to the tourist package market so good luck trying to get a hotel in the tower at a decent rate.

This place was OK, stayed here for 7 nights in July 2002. The room was very small, but kept nice and clean. The hotel itself was very average...didn't feel very Hawaiian to us. The location is pretty decent, just a short walk over to the beach which was nice. Parking was outrageous at 11 or 12 bucks a night. We stayed here because it was one of the cheapest packages we could find. Wouldn't pay too much for this hotel, but not a bad place for budget travel, not a bad place at all. Oh and the breakfast buffet was expensive, and rather nasty!

Stayed at this hotel in June 2002. Service was fine. Got upgraded to from a suresaver room to a poolside view room. Not bad considering the room was on the second floor so of course that means the elevator ride wouldn't be a long ride down or up!! Got to our room (rm 206) the first day and it wasn't bad at all. However, in the bathroom we noticed some black spots moving quickly. As we looked closely they were tiny insects. How gross!! We called the front desk to advise them of this issue and to maybe spray some insect spray. Well, it took about one hour for them to arrive. The bellman said they were ants but it didn't look like ants. But I guess that's what they were! They had moved us to another room (rm 202). That was the least they could do but sure enough there were those nasty insects again near the mini refrigerator and some near the lamps. We did't complain no more but just wiped the area and tried to get rid of them. Eventually, after day two they disappeared or at least I didn't see any when I did look for them! As far as the hotel room itself was not bad at all. The concierge was helpful, the staff was friendly and the nightly entertainment was wonderful.
